revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=February 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2018}} <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Andrew Geddis leading sauce anglais in 1.jpg|thumbnail|300px| As chairman of the [[Royal Western India Turf Club]] (1931–1939) leading in Sauce Anglais winner of the Juhu Plate, April ‘45 ridden by his daughter ]] --> '''Andrew Geddis''' (July 1886 – 23 February 1976) was a leading business man and sports enthusiast in [[Bombay]] in the decades leading up to independence. <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:D M & DFC Poona Races Aug '43 1.jpg|thumb|left|350px|With daughter, Margaret and future son-in-law [[Donald Callander]] at Poona Races in Aug '43]] -->
==Biography== He was Chairman of the [[Royal Western India Turf Club]] (1931–1939) and instigated Mumbai Races's A.Geddis Plate. His extensive business interests included a directorship of the [[Bank of India]] Ltd and co-founding Geoffrey Manners & Co. Ltd., which became a leading distributor and manufacturer of Consumer Healthcare products and Pharmaceuticals across India until its amalgamation in April 2003 with the [[Wyeth]] Corporation, formerly known as American Home Products (AHP),one of the largest [[pharmaceutical company|pharmaceutical companies]] in the world.
He left [[Bruntsfield|Bruntsfield Place]] in [[Edinburgh]] for Bombay in 1907 to work for James Finlay & Co. Ltd. and went on to become extensively involved in the [[Ahmedabad textile industry]] becoming a Director of the Ahmedabad Jubilee Spinning & Manufacturing Co., Ltd. and the Ahmedabad Manufacturing & Calico Printing Co. Ltd., as well as Director of the India Cotton Association and the Chairman of Mill Owners' Mutual Insurance Association Ltd from its inception. [[File:Kamal mahal in 1940.jpg|thumbnail|350px|left| Kamal Mahal atop [[Cumballa Hill]] in 1940]]
His wider interests included, as well as co-founding Geoffrey Manners & Co. Ltd., directorships of the Tata Hydroelectric Power Supply Co., Ltd., the Indian Radio & Cable Communications Co.and the Bank of India Ltd. He was a member of the G. 1. P. Railway Advisory committee for 13 years and was appointed to the Board of Trustees for the Bombay Port trust in 1920.. A keen horse racing enthusiast, as well as his chairmanship of the Western India Turf Club was also Chairman of the Turf Club House, Poona. Other interests included being Chairman of the Bombay Scottish Orphanage Society and Chairman of the Caledonia Society of Bombay.
On arrival in India he stayed in the [[Pali Hill]] ''Chummery''. After his marriage to Jean Gunn, daughter of Dr [[Alexander Gunn (doctor)|Alexander Gunn]] of Edinburgh in 1915, he moved to Dharbanga Masions on [[Cumballa Hill]] before finally moving to the fourth floor apartment on the left below the penthouse in the iconic art deco Kamal Mahal building,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/mumbai/High-life-Flat-on-Carmichael-Rd-fetches-Rs-33-cr-/articleshow/5875055.cms|title=High life: Flat on Carmichael Rd fetches Rs 33 cr" : Times of India, Apr 30, 2010 | work=The Times Of India | date=30 April 2010}}</ref> originally called Sethna House, on [[Carmichael Road]] in South Mumbai, which together with the adjacent [[Altamont Road]] was rated the tenth dearest address in the world in a in 2009 survey.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wealth-bulletin.com/home/content/2451423982 |title=Wealth Holding Page |publisher=Wealth-bulletin.com |date= |accessdate=2009-09-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100420053915/http://www.wealth-bulletin.com/home/content/2451423982 |archivedate=2010-04-20 |df= }}</ref> He also had a beach house at [[Juhu]].
==References== {{reflist}} {{coord missing|Maharashtra}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Geddis, Andrew}} [[Category:1886 births]] [[Category:1976 deaths]] [[Category:History of Mumbai]] [[Category:People of British India]] [[Category:businesspeople from Edinburgh]] [[Category:Scottish people of the British Empire]] [[Category:Scottish businesspeople]]

{{Italic title}} {{Infobox artwork | image_file = Andrew W. Mellon Memorial Fountain.jpg | painting_alignment = Front | image_size = 300px | title = Andrew W. Mellon Memorial Fountain | alt = | other_language_1 = | other_title_1 = | other_language_2 = | other_title_2 = | artist = [[Sidney Waugh]] | year = {{Start date|1951}} | type = [[Bronze]], [[Granite]], [[Quartz]] | height_imperial = | width_imperial = 38 | length_imperial = | imperial_unit = ft | metric_unit = m | city = [[Washington, D.C.]], [[United States]] | museum = | coordinates = |owner = [[Department of the Interior]] }} The '''''Andrew W. Mellon Memorial Fountain''''' is a bronze fountain sculpture by [[Sidney Waugh]] as a memorial to [[Andrew W. Mellon]]. It is located in [[Washington D.C.]], [[United States]], just north of the [[National Gallery of Art]], at [[Pennsylvania Avenue (Washington, D.C.)|Pennsylvania Avenue]], [[Constitution Avenue]], and 6th Street NW.{{cite web | author= | year=1993| title=Andrew W. Mellon Memorial Fountain, (sculpture).| work=[[Save Outdoor Sculpture!]] | publisher=[[Smithsonian Institution]] | url=http://siris-artinventories.si.edu/ipac20/ipac.jsp?&profile=all&source=~!siartinventories&uri=full=3100001~!323065~!0#focus | accessdate= 18 April 2010}} The fountain is maintained by the [[Department of the Interior]] and was dedicated on May 9, 1952, by [[Harry S. Truman]].{{cite web|author= |year= |title=Mellon Memorial Fountain Dedication |work=Truman Library Photographs |publisher=[[Harry S. Truman Presidential Library and Museum]] |url=http://truman.doit.missouri.edu/photographs/view.php?id=42552&rr= |accessdate=18 April 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110831123829/http://truman.doit.missouri.edu/photographs/view.php?id=42552&rr= |archivedate=31 August 2011 }}{{cite news |title=From the Collection:Washington's Prize Possessions |author=Paul Richard |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |date=24 August 2006 }} ==Description== The round [[fountain]] is made up of three small-to-large nested [[bronze]] basins, which sit in a [[granite]] outer basin. The outer, and largest, bronze basin is decorated in [[zodiac sign]]s which sit in their "correct [[astrological]] position for the sun's rays." The small basin serves as the venue for a 20 foot{{cite news |title=Sculpture Under the Sun |author=Rita Kempley |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |date=23 August 1982 }} tall water spouting jet. The water then proceeds to spill over the small basin and over the edge of the other basins, eventually over and into the granite basin. Surrounding the fountain is a seven foot wide granite walkway and a semi-circular granite [[bench (furniture)|bench]]. The inscription on the bench reads: :1855.ANDREW W. MELLON.1937 :FINANCIER.INDUSTRIALIST.STATESMAN :SECRETARY OF THE TREASURY 1921-1932 AMBASSADOR TO GREAT BRITAIN 1932-1933 :FOUNDER OF THE NATIONAL GALLERY OF ART 1937 :THIS FOUNTAIN IS A TRIBUTE FROM HIS FRIENDS ==Information==
"''It sits like an island, traffic whizzing by on the three major arteries.''" - Gary Tischler{{cite news |title=Water becomes art at area fountains; Visitors find visual appeal, relief from heat |author=Gary Tischler |newspaper=[[The Washington Times]] |date=22 June 2000 }}
The fountain serves as a tribute to [[Andrew Mellon]] who served as [[Secretary of the Treasury]] from 1921–1932 and [[ambassador]] to [[Great Britain]] from 1932-1933. The fountain shares a [[Classical architecture]] style with{{cite book |last=Benoliel|first=Alice L. |coauthors= |title=DK Eyewitness Travel Guide: Washington, Part 3 |publisher=[[DK Publishing]] |year=2010 |month= |isbn=}} and sits close by to the [[National Gallery of Art]] where Mellon donated his art collection, as well as funding to build the art museum. This memorial fountain cost $300,000, which was donated by Mellon's friends through the Andrew W. Mellon Memorial Committee. The fountain was dedicated on May 9, 1952 and sits on the former site of the Saint James Hotel.{{cite book |last=Ovason|first=David |coauthors= |title=The Secret Architecture of Our Nation's Capital: The Masons and the Building of Washington, D.C. |publisher=[[Harper Paperbacks]] |date=March 2002|isbn=0-06-095368-3}} ===Creation=== Its creation was authorized by [[U.S. Congress|Congress]] on July 16, 1947 by the Joint Resolution 1701: {{Quote box |quote = ''Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives of the United States of America in Congress assembled,'' That the Secretary of the Interior is hereby authorized and directed to grant authority to the Andrew W. Mellon Memorial Committee to erect a memorial fountain on public grounds in the vicinity of the intersection of Pennsylvania and Constitution Avenues, in the District of Columbia, such grounds being now owned by the United States: ''Provided'', That the design and location of the memorial shall be approved by the National Commission of Fine Arts and the National Capital Park and Planning Commission, and the United States shall be put to no expense in or by the erection of this memorial: ''Provided further'', That unless funds, which in the estimation of the Secretary of the Interior are sufficient to insure the completion of the memorial, are certified available, and the erection of this memorial begun within five years from and after the date of passage of this joint resolution, the authorization hereby granted is revoked. 80TH Congress, 1ST Session -Chapter 257 - July 16, 1947 }} The fountain's cascading design was inspired by a fountain in [[Genoa]], Italy. Tuck and Eipel served as the [[structural engineers]] and Edward E. Ashley Associates were the [[mechanical engineers]]. While excavating for the fountain a 7 ft. x 8 ft. [[underground tunnel]] was discovered. The tunnel had to be backfilled with [[concrete]] to make a proper [[bearing capacity]] for the fountain. Two [[concentric]] rings of 30-ton concrete piles had to be driven down 30–40 ft. into the ground to ensure that the ground was level. The largest bronze basin was the largest of its kind ever cast at the time and required "casting in four sections" which had to be fitted together "with great precision." The fountain was cast by the General Bronze Company and Modern Art Factory may have cast the zodiac signs. The [[pink granite]] used is from the Swenson Pink Granite Quarry in [[South Berwick, Maine]].{{cite web | author= | year=2011 | title=Quarries in Maine & Quarry Links, Photographs, and Articles (Continued) | publisher=Stone Quarries and Beyond | url=http://quarriesandbeyond.org/states/me/me-quarries_8.html | accessdate= 23 April 2011}} The [[Aries (astrology)|Aries]] zodiac faces directly east with the [[Libra (astrology)|Libra]] symbol facing west and the [[Virgo (astrology)|Virgo]] symbol arranged along Pennsylvania Avenue, leading to some believing that [[Masonic]] influences were essential in the architecture. On the [[vernal equinox]] the sun directly hits Aries, which then faces the rising sun a month later. ===Condition=== In 1993 the fountain was surveyed by the [[Smithsonian Institution]]'s [[Save Outdoor Sculpture!]] program and was described as "well maintained." ==Artists== ===Paul Manship=== {{Main|Paul Manship}} ===Sidney Waugh=== [[Sidney Waugh]], who designed the zodiacs, also designed the sculptures seen outside of the [[National Archives and Records Administration]] and the [[Federal Reserve Board]] buildings in Washington, D.C.{{cite web | author= | year=2011 | title=Andrew W. Mellon Memorial Water Fountain | publisher=DCpages | url=http://www.dcpages.com/gallery/Capitol-Square-Compass-Tour/DSC09637.jpg.html | accessdate= 23 April 2011}} ==See also== * [[List of public art in Washington, D.C., Ward 6]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==Further reading== *(15 May 1947). [http://proquest.umi.com/pqdweb?did=88781127&sid=1&Fmt=10&clientId=31812&RQT=309&VName=HNP "Mellon Memorial is Favored"]. [[New York Times]]. ==External links== *[http://www.life.com/image/med500048 ''Andrew Mellon Memorial Fountain''] photograph from [[Life (magazine)|Life]] *[http://dcmemorials.com/index_indiv0000330.htm The fountain] in photographic detail on DCMemorials {{coord|38|53|32.59|N|77|1|9.9|W|region:US|display=title}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Andrew W. Mellon Memorial Fountain }} [[Category:1951 sculptures]] [[Category:Fountains in Washington, D.C.]] [[Category:Monuments and memorials in Washington, D.C.]] [[Category:Outdoor sculptures in Washington, D.C.]] [[Category:Bronze sculptures in Washington, D.C.]] [[Category:Mellon family]]

{{pp-pc1|expiry=December 9, 2018}} {{more citations needed|date=December 2013}} {{Infobox settlement |official_name = Bonifacio Global City |native_name = |image_skyline = {{Photomontage | photo1a = BGC.jpg | photo2a = Bonifacio Global City 2.jpg | photo3a = FvfPArmy0240 06.JPG | photo3b = VenicePiazza.jpg | size = 260 | spacing = 1 | color = transparent | border = 0 }} |image_caption = Clockwise from top: BGC Skyline, Bonifacio High Street, Philippine Army Entrance Gate, Venice Grand Canal Mall |image_flag = |flag_link = |seal_size = 120px |image_blank_emblem = Bonifacio Global City Logo.png |nicknames = ''BGC''
''Global City''
''The Fort'' |motto = |image_map = Bonifacio Global City location map.svg |map_caption = Bonifacio Global City and surrounding localities |pushpin_map = Metro Manila |pushpin_label_position = bottom |pushpin_mapsize = |pushpin_map_caption = Location of Bonifacio Global City within Metro Manila |coordinates = {{coord|14|33|02.9|N|121|3|3.5|E|display=inline, title}} |subdivision_type = Country |subdivision_name = [[Philippines]] |subdivision_type1 = Region |subdivision_type2 = City |subdivision_type3 = Barangay |subdivision_name1 = [[Metro Manila|National Capital Region]] |subdivision_name2 = [[Taguig]] |subdivision_name3 = [[Fort Bonifacio]] |established_title = |established_date = February 7, 1995 |government_type = |leader_title = Head of the District |leader_name = Allan Oliman (Brgy. Fort Bonifacio) |unit_pref = |area_footnotes = |area_total_km2 = |area_land_sq_mi = |elevation_footnotes = |elevation_m = 16.0 |elevation_max_m = 40 | elevation_max_footnotes ={{cite news|last1=Remo|first1=Amy|title=Rise of the new city|url=http://business.inquirer.net/246143/rise-new-city|accessdate=10 May 2018|work=Philippine Daily Inquirer|date=17 February 2018}} |population_total = 11,739 |population_as_of = 2015 |population_footnotes = [https://www.census.gov.ph/data/sectordata/2010/2010CPH_ncr.pdf Total Population by Province, City, Municipality and Barangay: as of May 1, 2010] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120625152554/http://www.census.gov.ph/data/sectordata/2010/2010CPH_ncr.pdf |date=2012-06-25 }} - Philippine Statistics Authority |population_density_km2 = auto |population_note = |postal_code_type = [[Zip code]] |postal_code = |area_code = 2 |website = [http://www.bgc.com.ph/ www.bgc.com.ph] |footnotes = |type = [[Districts of the Philippines|Central Business District]] |timezone = [[Philippine Standard Time|PST]] |utc_offset = +8 |timezone_DST = |utc_offset_DST = }} '''Bonifacio Global City''' (also known as '''BGC''', '''Global City''', or '''The Fort''') is a financial and lifestyle district in [[Metro Manila]], [[Philippines]]. It is located {{convert|11|km|abbr=on}} south-east of the center of [[Manila]]. The district experienced commercial growth following the sale of military land by the [[Bases Conversion and Development Authority]] (BCDA). The entire district used to be the part of the main [[Philippine Army]] camp. It is under the administration of the city government of [[Taguig]]. The local governments of [[Makati]] and [[Pateros, Metro Manila|Pateros]] also claims jurisdiction. In February 7, 1995, Bonifacio Land Development Corporation (BLDC) started planning a major urban development—Bonifacio Global City. BLDC made a successful bid to become BCDA's partner in the development of the district. The [[Ayala Corporation]] through Ayala Land, Inc., and Evergreen Holdings, Inc. of the Campos Group purchased a controlling stake in BLDC from [[Metro Pacific]] in 2003. BCDA and the two companies now control Fort Bonifacio Development Corporation, which oversees the master planning of Bonifacio Global City. ==History== {{main|Fort Bonifacio}} {{Refimprove section|date=April 2013}} [[Image:FortMcKinley.jpg|thumb|left|220px|[[Philippine Scouts]] at Fort McKinley (called today Fort Bonifacio) firing a 37-mm antitank gun in training]] During the [[History of the Philippines (1898–1946)|American colonial period]], the US government acquired a 25.78 square kilometre property within what was then disputed area between Makati, Taguig and Pateros for military purposes. This area (TCT dated 1902) was turned into a camp then known as [[Fort William McKinley]] after the 25th US president, [[William McKinley]]. After the Philippines gained its political independence from the United States on July 4, 1946, the US bestowed to the Republic of the Philippines all rights of possession, jurisdiction, supervision and control over the Philippine territory except the use of their military bases. On May 14, 1949, Fort McKinley was turned over to the [[Philippine government]] by virtue of US Embassy Note No. 0570.[https://www.loc.gov/law/help/us-treaties/bevans/b-ph-ust000011-0178.pdf] Under the AFP leadership of Gen. Alfonso Arellano, Fort McKinley was made the permanent headquarters of the Philippine Army in 1957 and was subsequently renamed [[Fort Bonifacio]],[http://www.taguig.gov.ph/portal/contents/about_Taguig/barangays/west_rembo_r.html Barangay West Rembo Profile]{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} after the Father of the Philippine Revolution against Spain, [[Andres Bonifacio]], whose father, Santiago Bonifacio, was a native of Taguig (then part of the Province of Manila / Tondo). On December 9, 1937 the Deed of Absolute sale executed by the owner, Don Anacleto Madrigal Acopiado in favor of the American Government covering the area of 100 hectares, portion of Bicutan, Taguig, annotated at the back of TCT No. 408. During the American Commonwealth, it was converted to a Military base, named Fort McKinley. It was during the presidency of the late President [[Ferdinand E. Marcos]]' administration when Fort McKinley was renamed Fort Bonifacio and transferred to Makati. Taguig got the jurisdiction over Fort Bonifacio after winning the case against Makati in filed in the Pasig Regional Trial Court in 1993. Makati appealed the ruling, but the Pasig RTC in 2011 still sided with Taguig, saying that Fort Bonifacio including the -EMBO Baranggays are all part of Taguig. Makati then asked the Court of Appeals to review the case. The Court of Appeals overturned the Pasig Regional Trial Court's decision and reverted jurisdiction of the BGC in favor of Makati. As of date, Taguig has filed a Motion of Reconsideration at the Court of Appeals seeking to revert the decision. Status quo (meaning the latest ruling) remains with Makati. Taguig currently has de facto control over the area.{{cite web |url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/320707/news/nation/rich-get-richer-makati-gains-while-taguig-loses-fort-boni-in-court-decision |author=Mark Merueñas|title=Rich get richer: Makati gains while Taguig loses Fort Boni in court decision |publisher=GMA News Online |date=5 August 2013 |accessdate=6 November 2015}} In February 7, 1995, Bonifacio Land Development Corporation, a consortium led by [[Metro Pacific]], made a successful bid to become BCDA's partner in the development of Bonifacio Global City (BGC), the Home of Passionate Minds. [[Ayala Corporation|Ayala Land, Inc.]] and Evergreen Holdings, Inc. of the Campos Group purchased a controlling stake in BLDC from Metro Pacific in 2003. BCDA and the two companies control Fort Bonifacio Development Corporation, which oversees the master planning of Bonifacio Global City. The Bonifacio Global City is a rich district with a high number of skyscrapers, even as the city is still rising. Many skyscrapers are under construction and will be built in future.{{citation needed|date=April 2013}} ==Description== [[File:Bonifacio Global City.png|thumb|right|Map of Bonifacio Global City.]] Bonifacio Global City is between [[EDSA (road)|EDSA]] and [[C-5 Road]]. There are seven major access points: access from the North and West through [[Kalayaan Avenue]] which connects it to the North Gate and the [[Kalayaan Flyover]], access from Taguig in the West via EDSA through [[McKinley Road]] and to the McKinley Gate; the three main entrances (Upper East Gate, Sampaguita Gate, and Lower East Gate) from C-5 highway in the East; and from the airport through the [[Villamor Airbase]] to the South Gate by Fifth Avenue and [[Lawton Avenue]].{{citation needed|date=July 2015}} BGC is home to residential condominiums such as 8 Forbes Town Road, Bellagio, Essensa, [[Serendra]], [[Pacific Plaza Towers]], [[One McKinley Place]], The Luxe Residences, Bonifacio Ridge Twin Towers, and Regent Parkway and corporate office buildings such as Net One and Bonifacio Technology Center. Many Filipino and multinational corporations have acquired properties and have committed to relocate their global, regional or national headquarters in the business district.{{citation needed|date=July 2015}} ==Developments== {{Refimprove section|date=April 2013}} ===Bonifacio High Street=== [[File:Bonifacio Global City 2.jpg|thumb|right|[[Bonifacio High Street]] is BGC's central retail and entertainment hub]] The [[Bonifacio High Street]] forms the physical core of the Bonifacio Global City and is essentially designed as a three-by-three matrix of high-tech offices and residential buildings, retail outlets and pedestrian-friendly roads and walkways. The grid approach ensures a city center that is easy to navigate. The 5th and 11th Avenues and 32nd and 26th Streets serve as the boundaries of the city center.{{citation needed|date=April 2013}} At the north, The One Bonifacio High Street, Where the PSE Tower, which houses the unified trading floor of the [[Philippine Stock Exchange]], along with the [[Shangri-La at the Fort, Manila]] is also located here. The Retail Promenade which encompasses the 29th Street is characterized by landscaped areas. Its design concept is centered on an east-west central access with business establishments and activity pods. It offers retail at the ground level and offices at the second floor. The City Square Blocks feature landscaped areas and parks.{{citation needed|date=April 2013}} ===North Bonifacio=== The P20-billion tower was estimated to start construction by late 2008, by Federal Land, Inc. (led by its president Alfred Ty), on a 27-hectare North Bonifacio district lot (jointly owned by the [[Metropolitan Bank and Trust Company|Metrobank]] Group of Companies and the Bases Conversion Development Authority). The tower is the 65-storey [[Grand Hyatt Manila]] which currently is one of the tallest skyscrapers in [[Metro Manila]], beside that is the [[Grand Hyatt Manila]] Residences.{{cite web|url=http://www.manilastandardtoday.com/?page=news4_sept9_2008|title=Manila Standard|publisher=}}[http://www.gmanews.tv/story/118957/RPs-tallest-building-soon-to-rise-in-Taguig RP's tallest building soon to rise in Taguig] gmanews.tv/story ===Forbes Town Center=== [[File:Burgos Circle in Bonifacio Global City.jpg|thumbnail|[[Burgos Circle]] at Forbes Town Center]] The Forbes Town Center{{cite web|url=http://megaworldfort.com.ph/townships/forbes-town-center/|title=Forbes Town Center Township - Condos for Sale - Megaworld Fort|website=Megaworld Fort}} is Megaworld's 5-hectare township community, where 8 Forbestown Road,{{cite web|url=http://megaworldfort.com.ph/projects/8-forbestown-road/|title=8 Forbestown Road - Condos for Sale - Megaworld Fort|publisher=}} Forbeswood Heights, Forbeswood Parklane{{cite web|url=http://megaworldfort.com.ph/projects/forbeswood-parklane/|title=Forbeswood Parklane - Condos for Sale - Megaworld Fort|publisher=}} and Bellagio{{cite web|url=http://megaworldfort.com.ph/projects/bellagio/|title=The Bellagio - Condos for Sale - Megaworld Fort|publisher=}} condominiums are. It has a combination of low density residential development, shopping strip, dining outlets, and other service facilities. ===Uptown Bonifacio === Uptown Bonifacio{{cite web|url=http://megaworldfort.com.ph/townships/uptown-bonifacio/|title=Uptown Bonifacio Township - Condos for Sale - Megaworld Fort|website=Megaworld Fort}} is a new 15-hectare property located in the northern district of Fort Bonifacio. Megaworld{{cite web|url=http://www.megaworldcondominiums.com|title=Megaworld Condominiums|date=10 July 2015|publisher=}} Corporation plans to build new residential condominiums (Uptown Parksuites,{{cite web|url=http://megaworldfort.com.ph/projects/uptown-parksuites/|title=Uptown Parksuites - Condos for Sale - Megaworld Fort|publisher=}} Uptown Ritz{{cite web|url=http://megaworldfort.com.ph/projects/uptown-ritz/|title=Uptown Ritz Residence - Condos for Sale - Megaworld Fort|publisher=}} and One Uptown Residence){{cite web|url=http://megaworldfort.com.ph/projects/one-uptown-residence/|title=One Uptown Residence - Condos for Sale - Megaworld Fort|publisher=}} and mixed-use business and commercial developments in the area that cater to upper to middle class markets. The area is near the zone where the British, Japanese, and American international schools, and other local schools are located. === McKinley Hill=== [[File:VenicePiazza.jpg|thumb|Venice Piazza at McKinley Hill]] Among Megaworld's development projects in Metro Manila, the 50-hectare McKinley Hill{{cite web|url=http://megaworldfort.com.ph/townships/mckinley-hill/|title=McKinley Hill Township - Condos for Sale - Megaworld Fort|website=Megaworld Fort}} is by far the biggest, where The Venice Luxury Residences,{{cite web|url=http://megaworldfort.com.ph/projects/the-venice/|title=The Venice Luxury Residences - Condos for Sale - Megaworld Fort|publisher=}} Viceroy{{cite web|url=http://megaworldfort.com.ph/projects/viceroy/|title=Viceroy at McKinley Hill - Condos for Sale - Megaworld Fort|publisher=}} and The Florence{{cite web|url=http://megaworldfort.com.ph/projects/the-florence/|title=The Florence at McKinley Hill - Condos for Sale - Megaworld Fort|publisher=}} condominiums are located. Situated in [[Pinagsama|Barangay Pinagsama]] in Taguig. McKinley Hill has over 4,713 condominium units in 34 residential condominium buildings, 482 residential lots, and close to 300,000 square meters of office space spread across 17 offices. There are three international schools, which are the [[Chinese International School Manila]], the first English-Mandarin bilingual school in the country; the management school [[Enderun Colleges]], which is partnered with Les Roches International School of Hotel Management in Switzerland, Alain Ducasse Education in France and Thunderbird School of Global Management in the United States; and the [[Korean International School Philippines]], the first in the country. ===McKinley West=== McKinley West{{cite web|url=http://megaworldfort.com.ph/townships/mckinley-west/|title=McKinley West Township - Condos for Sale - Megaworld Fort|website=Megaworld Fort}} is a 34.5-hectare township by Megaworld, where St. Moritz{{cite web|url=http://megaworldfort.com.ph/projects/st-moritz/|title=St. Moritz Private Estate - Condos for Sale - Megaworld Fort|publisher=}} condominium is located. Turnover of the project is 2019. ===Heritage Park=== Heritage Park was developed by BCDA. It is a 76-hectare high-value, multi-use memorial park designed with landmarks and equipped with interment services, crematory and other facilities situated in [[Pinagsama|Barangay Pinagsama]]. The park opened in the first quarter of 2001. Heritage Park is located along Bayani Road. It is between [[Heroes' Cemetery|Libingan ng mga Bayani]] and The [[Manila American Cemetery and Memorial]].{{citation needed|date=July 2015}} ==Historical sites== {{unreferenced section|date=July 2015}} [[File:Aerial view of the Manila American Cemetery.JPG|thumb|Aerial view of the [[Manila American Cemetery|Manila American Cemetery and Memorial]]]] The [[Fort Bonifacio Tunnel]] (Bonifacio War Tunnel) is a tunnel in Bonifacio Global City, a district of Metro Manila, [[Philippines]]. It is considered to be a historical site by the Bases Conversion Development Authority. It is situated at the property of former military base Fort Bonifacio and now called Bonifacio Global City. It has since become hidden underneath the streets that traverse C-5 and Kalayaan Avenue. The [[Heroes' Cemetery|Libingan ng mga Bayani]] (Heroes' Cemetery) is a memorial ground housing 33,520 Filipino soldiers killed in Bataan, Corregidor and other battlefields in World War II. Presidents of the Philippines, national artists and other Filipinos deemed honorable are also buried here. The Vietnam War Memorial and Korean War Memorial are located in the Libingan ng mga Bayani. The [[Manila American Cemetery and Memorial]] is on a prominent plateau in the limits of Fort Bonifacio. It contains the largest number of graves (17,206) of American soldiers who fought in World War II. Most of the soldiers buried at the American Cemetery lost their lives in operations in New Guinea and the Philippines. ==Health and education== [[File:International school manila.gif|thumb|[[International School Manila]]]] [[St. Luke's Medical Center, Inc.]] operates [[St. Luke's Medical Center - Global City|a hospital]] at the Bonifacio Global City. BGC has several major educational institutions, mostly located at the University Parkway district. The [[University of the Philippines|University of the Philippines System]] (through the constituent units of [[University of the Philippines Diliman|UP Diliman]] and [[University of the Philippines Open University|UP Open University]]) and [[De La Salle University]] are two most prominent universities which offer graduate programs for professionals working in the district.{{cite news|title=Classes begin August at new U.P. campus in BGC|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/nation/metro-manila/03/01/16/classes-begin-august-at-new-up-campus-in-bgc|accessdate=19 March 2017|agency=ABS-CBN News|publisher=ABS-CBN News|date=2 March 2016}}{{cite news|last1=Suarez|first1=Bianca|last2=Rustia|first2=Josemaria|title=Changes in the College of Law: Semestral shift, BGC Campus|url=http://thelasallian.com/2015/11/24/changes-in-the-college-of-law-semestral-shift-bgc-campus/|accessdate=19 March 2017|publisher=The Lasallian DLSU|date=November 24, 2015}} Other educational institutions in the area include the [[Leaders International Christian School of Manila]], [[British School Manila]], [[International School Manila]], [[Manila Japanese School]], [[Korean International School Philippines]], Everest Academy Manila, [[STI College]], and [[MGC-New Life Christian Academy]] - Global City, [[Treston International College]]. ==Transport== {{see also|List of BGC Bus routes}} [[Bonifacio Transport Corporation]] maintains bus routes (BGC Bus) serving the business district, as well as [[Jeepneys]] and [[UV Express]], with a terminal located at the [[Market! Market!]] The Bonfacio Global City is also located near the [[Buendia MRT station]], and will serve the future [[Metro Manila Subway]]. ==Fort Bonifacio dispute== [[File:Bonifacio Global City contested between Taguig and Makati.svg|thumb|Contested territory between [[Makati]] and [[Taguig]] which includes Bonifacio Global City]] The city governments of [[Makati]] and [[Taguig]] have recently fought over the jurisdiction of Fort Bonifacio because of the area's growth potential. A portion of the base, including the Libingan ng mga Bayani and the American Cemetery, lies within Taguig, while the northern portion where the Global City development is centered was considered part of Makati. A 2003 ruling by a judge in the Pasig Regional Trial Court upheld the jurisdiction of Taguig over the entirety of Fort Bonifacio, including the Bonifacio Global City and Pinagsama.[https://web.archive.org/web/20081205080132/http://elibrary.supremecourt.gov.ph/decisions.php?doctype=Decisions%20%2F%20Signed%20Resolutions&docid=a45475a11ec72b843d74959b60fd7bd646f43d0ea63cd Supreme Court E-Library - G.R. NO. 168781: CITY OF Taguig, PETITIONER, VS. THE HON. JUDGE BRICCIO C. YGAÑA, PRESIDING JUDGE, REGIONAL TRIAL COURT, PASIG CITY, BRANCH 153, AND MUNICIPALITY OF TAGUIG, RESPONDENTS DECISION], elibrary.supremecourt.gov.ph; accessed July 9, 2015. ===Ruling=== The Supreme Court on June 27, 2008 per [[Leonardo Quisumbing]], dismissed the suit of the [[Makati]], seeking to nullify Special Patents 3595 and 3596 signed by [[Fidel Ramos]] conveying to the Bases Conversion and Development Authority public land in Fort Bonifacio, [[Taguig]] City. Due to a pending civil case filed by the Taguig City government asking the court to define its territorial boundaries, Makati cannot halt Taguig from collecting taxes on land located in Fort Bonifacio because it does not have any other sufficient source of sufficient income.{{cite web|url=http://www.manilastandardtoday.com/?page=police2_june30_2008 |title=Court junks Taguig’s suit to nullify Ramos patents|website=www.manilastandardtoday.com|accessdate=July 9, 2015}}[http://www.supremecourt.gov.ph/jurisprudence/2008/june2008/163175.htm ''Pateros v Taguig'', G.R. No. 163175, June 27, 2008] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080710102645/http://www.supremecourt.gov.ph/jurisprudence/2008/june2008/163175.htm |date=July 10, 2008 }} supremecourt.gov.ph[http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/inquirerheadlines/metro/view/20080630-145531/Court-rules-against-Taguig-in-property-dispute-case Court rules against Taguig in property dispute case], {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130922180914/http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/inquirerheadlines/metro/view/20080630-145531/Court-rules-against-Taguig-in-property-dispute-case |date=September 22, 2013 }} inquirer.net; accessed July 9, 2015. ===Reclaim by Pateros=== The municipality of [[Pateros, Metro Manila|Pateros]], the only municipality in [[Metro Manila]] and located near Fort Bonifacio, claims that its original land area was not its present land area of 2.10 km2 but 1,040 hectares (10.4 km2) including Fort Bonifacio, particularly Barangays Comembo, Pembo, East Rembo, West Rembo, Cembo, South Cembo and Pitogo which are now part of Makati City and Bonifacio Global City, Aranai, Ususan and Palar, Pinagsama which was made part of Taguig, based on documents and official maps obtained from some libraries and offices including USA Library of Congress and USA Archives. ("Susi ng Pateros Newsletter", 2000) Pateros' decrease in territory was accounted to a cadastral mapping in Metro Manila conducted in 1978. The late Pateros Mayor Nestor Ponce challenged the map through an objection letter dated June 23, 1978. In January 1986, former President Ferdinand Marcos issued Proclamation No. 2475 which stated that Fort Bonifacio is in [[Makati]] and it's open for disposition. Because of that, a boundary dispute arose which moved Pateros to request a dialogue about that with then Municipal Council of [[Makati]] in 1990. Pateros also filed a complaint against Taguig at the Makati RTC in 1996 but the trial court dismissed the case for lack of jurisdiction. The case was moved to the Court of Appeals in 2003, but was denied. The same case was moved to the Supreme Court in 2009, and it was denied again."Susi ng Pateros Newsletter", 2009. ===Supreme Court Decision=== The Supreme Court, on June 16, 2009, per Antonio Eduardo B. Nachura denied Pateros’ petition against Taguig but ruled out that the boundary dispute should be settled amicably by their respective legislative bodies based on Section 118(d) of the Local Government Code.Panaligan, R. 2009, June 22. [http://www.mb.com.ph/articles/207737/sc-wants-ft-bonifacio-land-dispute-settled-amicably "SC wants Ft. Bonifacio land dispute settled amicably"]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, {{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} mb.com.ph; accessed July 9, 2015. Pursuant to the decision, Pateros invited Taguig to a council-to-council dialogue on October 8, 2009. Four meetings were held and at the fourth dialogue on November 23, 2009, a joint resolution was made stating that Taguig is requesting a tripartite conference between Pateros, [[Taguig]] and [[Makati]].{{citation needed|date=July 2015}} ===Court of Appeals Decision=== On August 5, 2013, after just a year and a half, the 20-year-long battle was decided in a 37-page decision that was written by Justice Marlene Gonzales-Sison of the Court of Appeals. It says that jurisdiction over Fort Bonifacio has reverted to Makati from Taguig. The Court upheld the constitutionality of Presidential Proclamations 2475 and 518, both of which confirmed that portions of the aforementioned military camps are under the jurisdiction of Makati. The decision also cited the fact that voters from the barangays that are subject of the dispute between Makati and Taguig have long been registered as voters of Makati, thus bolstering the former's jurisdiction over Fort Bonifacio. However, Taguig Mayor Lani Cayetano maintained that this decision was not yet final and executory, and asked Justice Gonzales-Sison to recuse from the case as it was discovered that her family has close ties with the Binays of Makati.{{citation needed|date=July 2015}} ===Status quo remains=== On August 22, 2013, the Taguig city government filed a Motion for Reconsideration before the Court of Appeals's Sixth Division affirming its claim on Fort Bonifacio.{{cite web|url=http://www.taguig.gov.ph/taguig-reaffirms-claim-over-fort-bonifacio |title=Taguig City files a Motion for Reconsideration|website=www.taguig.gov.ph| accessdate= July 9, 2015}} With the filing of the said Motion for Reconsideration, Taguig's jurisdiction forces itself over Fort Bonifacio. According to Taguig's legal department, jurisprudence and the rules of procedure in the country's justice system all say that the filing of a motion for reconsideration suspends the execution of a decision and puts it in limbo.{{citation needed|date=July 2015}} ===Supreme Court's Second Decision=== On August 1, 2016, in a 27-page decision by the Second Division of the Supreme Court, the decision sought Makati government found guilty of direct contempt for abusing the legal processes over the jurisdiction of BGC.{{cite news|title=Makati guilty of direct contempt over BGC row with Taguig|last=Torres-Tupas|first=Tetch|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/801669/makati-guilty-of-direct-contempt-over-bgc-row-with-taguig|publisher=''[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]''|date=August 1, 2016|accessdate=January 22, 2017}} ===Final decision, recognition of Taguig's jurisdiction=== On October 3, 2017, the Court of Appeals upheld its final decision in favor of the city government of Taguig and not Makati. The SC also sought Makati guilty of forum shopping after simultaneously appealing the Pasig RTC ruling and filing a petition before the CA, both seeking the same relief.{{cite news|title=CA: Taguig owns BGC, not Makati|last=Ramos|first=Marlon|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/943180/ca-taguig-owns-bgc-not-makati|publisher=''[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]''|date=November 6, 2017|accessdate=December 18, 2017}}{{cite news|title=It’s final: BGC belongs to Taguig|last=Punay|first=Edu|url=http://www.philstar.com/metro/2017/11/06/1756019/its-final-bgc-belongs-taguig|publisher=''[[The Philippine Star]]''|date=November 6, 2017|accessdate=December 18, 2017}} ==Gallery==
File:BGC.jpg|Bonifacio Global City last 2016. File:Bonifacio Global City 2.jpg|The [[Bonifacio High Street]] with the Bonifacio Global City at the Background (2015). File:Bonifacio Global City (BGC) skyline - from FTI Tenement (Taguig)(2018-04-02).jpg| Bonifacio Global City from the [[Arca South]]. File:Bonifacio Global City (BGC Taguig) skyline at sunset, with Pasig River (El Pueblo, Santa Mesa, Manila; 2017-01-27).jpg| Bonifacio Global City including the [[Poblacion, Makati|Makati Poblacion]]. File:Bonifacio Global City - skyline (view from Pioneer) (Taguig and Makati)(2018-04-24) cropped.jpg|The Bonifacio Global City Skyline in 2018. File:Grand Hyatt Manila (Federal Land Tower) (BGC, Taguig)(2018-06-04).jpg|The [[Grand Hyatt Manila]]. File:Pacific Plaza Condominium (Bonifacio Global City, Taguig)(2012) 2.jpg|The [[Pacific Plaza Towers]]. File:Finance Centre, The Infinity and South of Market condo (BGC, Taguig)(2018-06-04).jpg| The Finance Centre, The Infinity and The South of Market. File:Philippine Stock Exchange (BGC, Taguig)(2018-06-04).jpg| The Philippine Stock Exchange Tower, also known as the One Bonifacio High Street Tower, is the New Headquarters of The [[Philippine Stock Exchange]]. File:BGC Taguig skyline - view from Pasig River (Kalawaan, Pasig)(2017-05-06).jpg| The BGC Skyline from the [[Pasig River]]. File:Globe Telecom (Bonifacio Global City (Bgc), Fort Bonifacio, Taguig; 2015-06-07).jpg|[[Globe Telecom]] Headquarters.
==See also== * [[Camp Aguinaldo]] * [[Clark Global City]] ==References== {{Reflist}} * [http://www.mb.com.ph/articles/223811/documents-back-pateros-claim-over-7-Taguig-villages mb.com.ph]{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} * [http://www.mb.com.ph/articles/216625/Taguig-council-refuses-to-discuss-boundary-dispute-with-pateros mb.com.ph]{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} *{{cite web|url=http://sc.judiciary.gov.ph/jurisprudence/2009/june2009/157714.htm|title=G.R. No. 157714|publisher=sc.judiciary.gov.ph|accessdate=2014-07-25}} ==External links== {{commons category|Fort Bonifacio Global City}} * {{official|http://www.bonifacioglobalcity.com.ph/ Official Website of Bonifacio Global City}} * [http://www.taguig.gov.ph/ Official Website of Taguig City] * [http://ilovetaguig.wordpress.com/fort-bonifacio/ Fort Bonifacio from Taguig City Blog] * [http://www.bgcmycity.com/ BGCMyCity] * [http://www.ayalaland.com.ph/estate/bgc-bonifacio-global-city/ Bonifacio Global City] {{Bonifacio Global City}} {{Metro Manila populated places}} {{Metro Manila}} {{Taguig}} [[Category:Bonifacio Global City| ]] [[Category:Districts in Metro Manila]] [[Category:Taguig]] [[Category:Central business districts in the Philippines]] [[Category:Economy of Metro Manila]] [[Category:Financial districts]] [[Category:Planned communities in the Philippines]] [[Category:Makati]] [[Category:Pateros, Metro Manila]] [[Category:Internal territorial disputes of the Philippines]]

{{italic title}} '''''Boys in the Pits: Child Labour in Coal Mines''''' is a 2000 book by Robert McIntosh, published by [[McGill-Queen's University Press]]. The book is about [[child labour]] in Canada in the 19th and early 20th centuries, with special reference to the history of boys, aged 8 to 15, who worked in [[coal mines]]. These boys worked underground, leading horses along subterranean roads, manipulating ventilation doors, helping miners cut and lift tons of coal, and filling wagons with freshly mined coal.<ref name=boys>[http://www.bls.gov/opub/mlr/2001/03/bookrevs.htm Book reviews]</ref><ref>[http://eh.net/bookreviews/library/0424 Boys in the Pits: Child Labour in Coal Mines]</ref>
Robert McIntosh is an employee at the [[National Archives of Canada]].<ref name=boys/>
==See also== *''[[Big Coal: The Dirty Secret Behind America's Energy Future]]'' (2006) *''[[Coal River (book)|Coal River'']] (2008) *''[[King Coal (book)|King Coal'']] (1917) *''[[Miners' Lung: A History of Dust Disease in British Coal Mining]]'' (2007) *''[[Moving Mountains: How One Woman and Her Community Won Justice From Big Coal]]'' (2007)
==References== <references/>
[[Category:Books about coal]] [[Category:2000 non-fiction books]] [[Category:Coal mining]] [[Category:Mining in Canada]] [[Category:Coal in Canada]] [[Category:Child labour]] [[Category:Works about mining]] [[Category:Canadian non-fiction books]]

{{good article}} {{Infobox person | name = Brian Halligan | image = Brian Halligan head shot.jpg | imagesize = | caption = Brian Halligan in 2010 | birth_date = | birth_place = | occupation = Executive, author | networth = | spouse = | children = | residence = | alma_mater = [[University of Vermont]]
[[MIT Sloan School of Management]] | website = [http://www.hubspot.com/ HubSpot] | signature = | footnotes = }} '''Brian Halligan''' is an American executive and [[author]].{{cite web | url = http://www.hubspot.com/company/management/brian-halligan/ | title = HubSpot Management Team, Brian Halligan, CEO & Founder | publisher = HubSpot | accessdate = December 3, 2011 }} He is CEO and co-founder of [[HubSpot]], an inbound marketing and sales software company based in [[Cambridge, Massachusetts]], and is also a senior lecturer at [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology|MIT]]. Halligan uses the term ''[[inbound marketing]]'' to describe the type of marketing he advocates.{{cite web |url=http://inboundmarketing.com/brian |title=Brian Halligan, HubSpot CEO & Co-Founder |publisher=Inbound Marketing |accessdate=December 3, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111118030556/http://www.inboundmarketing.com/brian |archivedate=November 18, 2011 |df= }} He has co-authored two books on [[marketing]]: ''Inbound Marketing: Get Found Using Google, Social Media, and Blogs''{{cite book | isbn = 0-470-49931-1 | year = 2009 | publisher = John Wiley & Sons Inc | title = Inbound Marketing: Get Found Using Google, Social Media, and Blogs | first1 = Brian | last1 = Halligan | first2 = Dharmesh | last2 = Shah }} with HubSpot co-founder Dharmesh Shah and ''Marketing Lessons from the Grateful Dead: What Every Business Can Learn from the Most Iconic Band in History''{{cite book | isbn = 0-470-90052-0 | year = 2010 | first1 = David Meerman | last1 = Scott | author1-link = David Meerman Scott | first2= Brian | last2 = Halligan | publisher = John Wiley & Sons Inc | title = Marketing Lessons from the Grateful Dead: What Every Business Can Learn from the Most Iconic Band in History. | url = http://www.davidmeermanscott.com/books_grateful-dead-marketing.htm }} with [[David Meerman Scott]]. ==Early life, education and career== Halligan was born in Westwood, Massachusetts, and grew up and attended public schools in Westwood, Massachusetts. He received a Bachelor of Science degree in Electrical Engineering from the [[University of Vermont]] and an MBA from [[MIT Sloan School of Management]] in 2005.{{cite journal | url = http://mitsloan.mit.edu/alumnimagazine/pdf/Fall2009%20-%20Five%20MIT%20Sloan%20companies%20to%20watch.pdf | title = Five MIT Sloan companies to watch #3 HubSpot, Moving the World to Inbound Marketing | publisher = MIT Sloan | journal = MIT Sloan Alumni Magazine | accessdate = January 14, 2012 | date = Fall 2009 | page = 29 }} His career began at [[Parametric Technology Corporation]] in several roles leading up to senior vice president of the Pacific Rim. Wanting to work in a smaller company,{{cite web | url = http://venturebeatprofiles.com/company/profile/hubspot/key_people | title = HubSpot: Key People: Management: Brian Halligan, CEO & Founder | publisher = VentureBeat Profiles | accessdate = December 2, 2011 }} he joined [[Groove Networks]] as vice president of sales, where he worked from 2000 to 2004 before it was acquired by [[Microsoft]] and rebranded as [[Microsoft SharePoint Workspace]].{{cite web |url=http://entrepreneurship.mit.edu/services/nurture/eir/brian-halligan/entrepreneur-residence-brian-halligan |title=Entrepreneur In Residence: Brian Halligan |accessdate=December 3, 2011 |publisher=[[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120102015735/http://entrepreneurship.mit.edu/services/nurture/eir/brian-halligan/entrepreneur-residence-brian-halligan |archivedate=January 2, 2012 |df= }}{{cite news | url = http://www.microsoft.com/presspass/features/2005/mar05/03-10GrooveQA.mspx | publisher = Microsoft | title = Microsoft, Groove Networks to Combine Forces to Create Anytime, Anywhere Collaboration | date = March 10, 2005 | accessdate = December 19, 2011 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20111208083130/http://www.microsoft.com/presspass/features/2005/mar05/03-10GrooveQA.mspx | archivedate = December 8, 2011 | df = }} After a period as a venture partner at Longworth Ventures{{cite web | url = http://www.generalcatalyst.com/entrepreneurs/brian-halligan | title = Brian Halligan | publisher = General Catalyst Partners | accessdate = December 3, 2011 }} he co-founded HubSpot in June 2006. In HubSpot's 2016 Year In Review, the company reported $271 million in total revenue and 1,597 employees with headquarters in Cambridge, MA and offices in Dublin, Ireland (EMEA HQ); Berlin; Singapore; Sydney, Australia; Tokyo, Japan; and Portsmouth, NH.{{cite web|url=https://cdn2.hubspot.net/hubfs/53/assets/hubspot.com/year-in-review/2016/yir-2016.pdf|title=HubSpot 2016 Year In Review|last=|first=|date=|year=2017|work=[[Hubspot]]|accessdate=June 15, 2017}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.hubspot.com/contact|title=Contact Us {{!}} HubSpot|last=HubSpot|website=www.hubspot.com|language=en|access-date=2017-06-16}} He credits the company's success, in part, to innovations like the "Alpha, Beta, Version One" policy, in which employees begin proving their ideas might profit the company "nights and weekends" (the alpha phase) before receiving additional resources (the beta and version one phases).{{cite journal | url = http://www.inc.com/magazine/201109/inc-500-brian-halligan-hubspot.html | title = My Story: Brian Halligan of HubSpot | first = Eric | last = Markowitz | work = [[Inc. (magazine)|Inc.]] | date = September 2010 | accessdate = December 3, 2011 }} From 2014 to 2016, Halligan also served on the board of directors of [[Fleetmatics]],{{Cite web|url=https://www.fleetmatics.com/fleetmatics-group-expands-its-board-of-directors|title=Fleetmatics Group Expands Board of Directors {{!}} Fleetmatics|website=www.fleetmatics.com|language=en|access-date=2017-06-15}} a provider of fleet management solutions delivered as software-as-a-service, leading up to their acquisition by Verizon for $2.4 billion.{{Cite web|url=https://www.fleetmatics.com/news/verizon-completes-acquisition-of-fleetmatics|title=Verizon Completes Acquisition of Fleetmatics {{!}} Fleetmatics|website=www.fleetmatics.com|language=en|access-date=2017-06-16}} ==Publications, speeches, and awards== Halligan's first book, ''Inbound Marketing,'' was co-authored with HubSpot co-founder Dharmesh Shah. The thesis of the book is that because people now block marketing that interrupts them, such as advertisements and spam, companies need to instead provide information that is useful to prospects, who will then self-identify. Reviewing the book, Meryl Evans said that it contains "elementary stuff..." but it "does a good job for those who don’t have a clue about how to use social media for business." {{cite news | url = https://www.nytimes.com/external/gigaom/2010/03/09/09gigaom-inbound-marketing-a-social-media-primer-59761.html | first = Meryl | last = Evans | publisher = The New York Times/GigaOm | date = March 9, 2010 | accessdate = December 19, 2011 | title = Inbound Marketing: A Social Media Primer }} It was also reviewed in ''The Boston Globe''.{{cite news | url = http://www.boston.com/business/technology/innoeco/2009/10/brian_halligans_todo_list_run.html | title = Brian Halligan's To-Do List: Run Company, Write Book, Raise $16 Million | work = The Boston Globe | first = Scott | last = Kirsner | date = October 19, 2009 | accessdate = December 3, 2011 }} As of July 2011, the book was in its seventh printing, had sold 40,000 copies, and had been translated into nine languages.{{cite web | url = http://influencers.smallbiztrends.com/small-business-leaders/brian-halligan/ | title = Brian Halligan, Nominated for a Small Business Influencer Award in: Leaders | publisher = Small Business Influencers | date = July 2011 | accessdate = December 3, 2011 }} The book was revised and updated in 2014 in a second edition. | url = http://www.wiley.com/WileyCDA/WileyTitle/productCd-1118896653.html | publisher = Wiley | date = August, 2014 [[File:David-meerman-scott-brian-halligan.png|thumb|300px|With co-author [[David Meerman Scott]], Brian Halligan (right) on the ''Marketing Lessons...'' book tour. The background photo montage includes Jerry Garcia, co-founder of The Grateful Dead]]His second book, ''Marketing Lessons,'' was co-authored with David Meerman Scott. It uses the marketing activities of the rock band [[The Grateful Dead]] as an example of this. Scott Kirsner, reviewing this book in ''The Boston Globe'',{{cite news | url = http://www.boston.com/business/technology/innoeco/2010/07/new_book_casts_the_grateful_de.html | title = New book casts the Grateful Dead as brilliant marketers | first = Scott | last = Kirsner | work=The Boston Globe | date=July 16, 2010 | accessdate=December 19, 2011 }} mentions that the authors say that they were inspired, in part, by an article in [[The Atlantic]] by [[Joshua Green (journalist)|Joshua Green]].{{cite news | url = https://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/2010/03/management-secrets-of-the-grateful-dead/7918/ | title = Management Secrets of the Grateful Dead | authorlink = Joshua Green (journalist) | first = Joshua | last = Green | work = [[The Atlantic]] | date = March 2010 | accessdate = December 3, 2011 }} In 2017, Halligan purchased the [[Jerry Garcia#Musical equipment|"Wolf"]] guitar once owned by Garcia for $1.9M at a charity auction. An anonymous donor made an additional donation of $1.6M and so the total benefit the [[Southern Poverty Law Center]] was $3.5M.{{Cite web | title = Jerry Garcia's Legendary Wolf Guitar Sells for $1.9 Million at Auction | first = Jon | last = Blistein | work = Rolling Stone | date = 2017-06-01 | accessdate = 2017-06-05 | url = https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/jerry-garcias-wolf-guitar-sells-for-19-million-w485198 | language = | quote = }}{{Cite web | title = HubSpot’s Brian Halligan buys Jerry Garcia’s guitar for almost $2 million - The Boston Globe | first = Andy | last = Rosen | work = BostonGlobe.com | date = 2017-06-01 | accessdate = 2017-06-05 | url = https://www.bostonglobe.com/business/2017/06/01/hubspot-brian-halligan-buys-jerry-garcia-guitar-for-almost-million/ozLYpKCaPzS5K1W3SiMaEL/story.html | quote = }}{{Cite news|url=https://www.splcenter.org/news/2017/06/01/auction-legendary-guitar-benefit-splc|title=Auction of legendary guitar to benefit SPLC|work=Southern Poverty Law Center|access-date=2017-06-16|language=en}} Halligan speaks on marketing and business topics, including at [[TED (conference)#Other programs|TEDx]].{{cite web | url = http://tedxboston.org/adventure/meet-with-angel-investor-joe-caruso | title = How do you catch an angel investor's eye? | publisher = TEDx Boston | date = June 29, 2011 | accessdate = December 7, 2011 | first1 = Brian | last1 = Halligan | first2 = Dharmesh | last2 = Shah | first3 = Joe | last3 = Caruso }} He was an entrepreneur in residence at MIT and is a senior lecturer, teaching "Designing, Developing, and Launching Successful Products in an Entrepreneurial Environment".{{Cite web|url=https://stellar.mit.edu/S/course/15/sp15/15.392/index.html|title=15.392 Class Home|website=stellar.mit.edu|access-date=2017-06-16}} He previously taught "Entrepreneurial Product Development and Marketing" with Elaine Chen.{{cite web |url=http://entrepreneurship.mit.edu/course/15s16-special-seminar-management-entrepreneurial-product-marketing-and-development |title=15.S16 H2 Special Seminar in Management: Entrepreneurial Product Marketing and Development |accessdate=December 6, 2011 |first1=Elaine |last1=Chen |first2=Brian |last2=Halligan |publisher=MIT |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120214073646/http://entrepreneurship.mit.edu/course/15s16-special-seminar-management-entrepreneurial-product-marketing-and-development |archivedate=February 14, 2012 |df= }} He is also an occasional lecturer at Sloan on the science of selling and marketing.{{cite web | url = http://mitsloan.mit.edu/newsroom/2011-marketing-conference.php | publisher = MIT Sloan | title = MIT Sloan’s inaugural Marketing Conference to reveal the future of engaging the digital consumer | accessdate = January 14, 2012 | date = September 1, 2011 }} ==Daniel Lyons incidents== In his book ''[[Disrupted: My Misadventure in the Start Up Bubble]]'', which is sharply critical of HubSpot's management and culture, former HubSpot employee [[Daniel Lyons]] accused Halligan of age discrimination.Primack, Dan (April 16, 2016) [http://fortune.com/2016/04/06/tech-workers-and-investors-should-read-disrupted/ "Why Tech Workers and Investors Should Read 'Disrupted."] Forbes. (Retrieved 8-16-2016). Materials obtained under the [[Freedom of Information Act]] showed that certain Hubspot executives working under Halligan considered the book "a financial threat to HubSpot, its share price, and the company’s future potential." The FBI report discusses "tactics such as email hacking and extortion" in the attempt to prevent the book from being published.[https://www.bostonglobe.com/business/2016/03/23/documents-released-hubspot-probe-involving-author-dan-lyons/VZH4CN4kR5p7iyhsKEdwJI/story.html Extortion, hacking claims sparked HubSpot investigation, FBI records show], Boston Globe, 24 March 2016. Halligan was forced to pay financial penalties by the HubSpot board of directors because he failed to promptly alert the board after he discovered that staff members at HubSpot behaved inappropriately. "There was definitely some fishiness. But I didn’t report it. That was my bad," Halligan said about the incident.[http://www.betaboston.com/news/2015/07/29/hubspot-fires-marketing-chief-sanctions-ceo-over-incident-involving-book-about-the-company/ beta Boston][http://fortune.com/disrupted-excerpt-hubspot-startup-dan-lyons/ My Year in Startup Hell], Dan Lyons in ''Fortune'', April 2016{{Cite news | title = Extortion, hacking claims sparked HubSpot investigation, FBI records show | first = Curt | last = Woodward | work = [[The Boston Globe]] | date = 2016-03-24 | accessdate = 2016-04-12 | url = https://www.bostonglobe.com/business/2016/03/23/documents-released-hubspot-probe-involving-author-dan-lyons/VZH4CN4kR5p7iyhsKEdwJI/story.html | quote = Chief executive Brian Halligan was fined for failing to promptly alert the company’s board of directors after finding out about the incident. }}{{Cite news | title = HubSpot CEO and CTO discuss firing of company’s ‘third founder’ over attempts to obtain book manuscript | first = Scott | last = Kirsner | work = The Boston Globe | date = 2015-07-30 | accessdate = 2016-03-16 | url = http://www.betaboston.com/news/2015/07/30/hubspot-ceo-and-cto-discuss-firing-of-companys-third-founder-over-ethical-lapse | quote = I did the math on how many days I’ve been a working professional. It’s something like 6,250, and yesterday was the worst. }} ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== * [http://www.wiley.com/WileyCDA/WileyTitle/productCd-1118896653.html ''About the authors'' page at Wiley for ''Inbound Marketing...''] * [https://books.google.com/books?id=ldty5Dy9RVsC&lpg=PP1&dq=brian%20halligan&pg=PA163#v=onepage&q&f=false ''About the authors'' page at Google Books from ''Marketing Lessons...''] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Halligan, Brian}} [[Category:1967 births]] [[Category:American business theorists]] [[Category:American business writers]] [[Category:American technology chief executives]] [[Category:American technology writers]] [[Category:Business speakers]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Marketing speakers]] [[Category:Massachusetts Institute of Technology alumni]] [[Category:MIT Sloan School of Management alumni]]

{{refimprove|date=July 2015}}
[[File:Zhang Bishi.jpg|thumb|Cheong Fatt Tze]]
'''Cheong Fatt Tze''' or '''Tjong Tjen Hsoen''' ({{zh|s=张弼士|zh|t=張弼士|p=Zhāng Bìshì}}; 1840 – 1916) was a Chinese businessman and politician. He was a powerful [[Nanyang (region)|Nanyang]] industrialist and a first-class [[Mandarin (bureaucrat)|Mandarin]] in the Manchu government; he was made Consul-General in Singapore and economic advisor to the Empress Dowager.
==Early life== He was born in 1840 in [[Dabu County|Dabu]], [[Guangdong Province]] in South [[China]]. As he came from a poor [[Hakka people|Hakka]] family, he started working at an early age as a cowherd back in his village. In 1856, [[Taiping Rebellion|civil war]] ravaged much of China, and in that same year another war had broken out between the [[Emperor of China]] and the [[England|English]], known as the [[Second Opium War]] (1856–1862). The people had experienced hardship and suffering during the war. As a result, Cheong Fatt Tze migrated to [[South-East Asia]] together with other coastal Chinese families to seek their fortune.
==Career== He started as a water-carrier and then became a shopkeeper in [[Jakarta]], [[Indonesia]]. After his marriage, he established a trading company with the help of his father-in-law. Gradually, he began to accumulate his wealth through hard work and perseverance. In 1877, he expanded his business from [[Jakarta]] to [[Medan]]. His business was based on [[agricultural]] products such as [[rubber]], [[coffee]] and [[tea]] but he branched out to the financial sector by acquiring a bank. This move made him a wealthy man.
In 1886, he expanded again to [[Penang]], [[Malaysia]]. As his business grew, he owned three ships which plied between Penang and Medan. In the course of his work, he occasionally resided in Penang and owned a [[Cheong Fatt Tze Mansion|mansion]] in Leith Street, which stands to this day as protected heritage building.
==Political career== In 1890, in recognition of his hard work and contribution, he was appointed the Chinese Consul, based in Penang. This office was shifted to [[Singapore]] when that city became established as a well-known trading port in [[South-East Asia]]. As the Chinese Consul, he worked tirelessly for the interests of overseas Chinese residents through diplomatic channels with the [[British Empire|British]] authorities.
In 1899, he was summoned to China twice by the [[Emperor of China]] and instructed to present a national development plan, which was well received by the government of the [[Qing dynasty]]. As a result, he was promoted to be the Minister for agriculture, industries, roads and mines for the provinces of [[Fujian]] and [[Guangdong]]. Later he was instructed to conduct a study of trade and education in Penang and Singapore. Subsequently, the Singapore Chinese Chamber of Commerce was established. In 1904, he established the first Chinese school in Southeast Asia, the [[Chung Hwa Confucian School]] in Penang.
In 1912, the [[Kuomintang]] overthrew the Qing and established a [[Republic of China (1912–49)|republican government]]. Cheong was appointed as a member of the Legislative Assembly so that he could be actively involved with politics. He was also appointed as the Chairman of the Chinese national Chamber of Commerce, which was well received by all parties.
In 1915, he was sent to the [[United States]] to study all aspects of industrialization of that nation. During his journey, when he stopped over in [[Hong Kong]], he was awarded a [[Ph.D.]] in [[Law]].
==Death== Cheong Fatt Tze died in [[Indonesia]] in 1916. His body was sent back to China to be buried. On its final journey through Penang, Singapore and Hong Kong, the overseas Chinese were greatly saddened by the loss of this great personality. The Chinese government sent a high-ranking official to his funeral and ordered the National Archives to record his life in historical documents so that his contributions would always be remembered. Both the British and the [[Dutch Empire|Dutch]] authorities ordered flags to be flown at half mast to honour the man who was known as ''"the [[John D. Rockefeller|Rockefeller]] of the East"''. He had eight wives and owned many residences throughout his trading empire (mostly [[Southeast Asia]]) but made Penang his base, where he raised his six sons.
==Legacy== In 1894, [[Chung Keng Quee]] hosted in his own gardens, in the name of Vice Consul Chang, Pi Shih (Cheong Fatt Tze), a dinner to welcome Admiral Ting (see Battle of Yalu River (1894) and Battle of Weihaiwei) and the Chinese Imperial Fleet of warships that he commanded.
Cheong Fatt Tze first introduced grape vineyards in China's Shandong province, and later brought in Austrian wine-producing experts to improve the vineyard in Yantai, Shandong. Cheong Fatt Tze also gave shelter to Sun Yat Sen and Sun Yat Sen 's fourth wife in Penang, Cheong Fatt Tze also helped Sun Yat Sen with Money to promote a Chinese Nationalist movement in China after 1911.
A street in George Town, Penang, which was formerly named Hong Kong Street, was renamed after him, Jalan Cheong Fatt Tze. His blue mansion, [[Cheong Fatt Tze Mansion]], is a heritage building, located at Leith Street in George Town. It is open for guided tours, and also offers accommodation and has an on-site restaurant.<ref>{{cite web|title=Cheong Fatt Tze Mansion|url=http://www.minorsights.com/2016/08/malaysia-cheong-fatt-tze-mansion.html|work=Minor Sights|accessdate=17 August 2016}}</ref> He left another mansion in his birthplace, Dabu, Guangdong Province, China.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.cheongfatttzemansion.com/ Mansion], Cheong Fatt Tze *{{YouTube|svsL1qOR9GA|Video of a 3D model of Cheong Fatt Tze Mansion from Google Earth}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Cheong, Fatt Tze}} [[Category:1840 births]] [[Category:1916 deaths]] [[Category:Chinese philanthropists]] [[Category:Indonesian people of Hakka descent]] [[Category:Indonesian philanthropists]] [[Category:Malaysian people of Hakka descent]] [[Category:Malaysian philanthropists]] [[Category:Malaysian businesspeople]] [[Category:Indonesian businesspeople]] [[Category:People from Dabu]] [[Category:Qing dynasty politicians from Guangdong]] [[Category:Republic of China politicians from Guangdong]] [[Category:Politicians from Meizhou]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Meizhou]] [[Category:Republic of China people born during Qing]]
