[[File:6870 Freezer Mill.jpg|thumb|300px|An Example of a [[solenoid]] powered cryogenic grinder]] [[File:COIL1.gif|thumb|300px|How cryogenic grinding with a solenoid works]]
'''[[Cryogenics|Cyrogenic]] grinding''', also known as '''freezer milling''', '''freezer grinding''', and '''cryomilling''', is the act of cooling or chilling a material and then reducing it into a small particle size. For example, [[thermoplastic]]s are difficult to grind to small particle sizes at [[ambient temperature]]s because they soften, adhere in lumpy masses and clog screens. When chilled by dry ice, liquid carbon dioxide or liquid nitrogen, the thermoplastics can be finely ground to powders suitable for electrostatic spraying and other powder processes.<ref>http://composite.about.com/library/glossary/c/bldef-c1386.htm Cryogenic Grinding</ref> Cryogenic grinding of plant and animal tissue is a technique used by [[microbiologists]]. Samples that require extraction of [[nucleic acid]]s must be kept at −80 °C or lower during the entire extraction process. For samples that are soft or flexible at room temperature, cryogenic grinding may be the only viable technique for processing samples.<ref>[http://www.retsch.com/dltmp/www/102499-8ba31387ae33/tr_elastic_plastics_pah_sm300_cryo_0709_en.pdf]</ref><ref>[http://www.spexcsp.com/pdfs/application%20note%20sp%20008%20(fm%20polymers).pdf] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080907081627/http://www.spexcsp.com/pdfs/application%20note%20sp%20008%20%28fm%20polymers%29.pdf |date=2008-09-07 }}</ref> A number of recent studies report on the processing and behavior of nanostructured materials via cryomilling.<ref>http://filer.funmat.no/FUNMAT_meeting_2006/FridayII_H2/9_deledda_0106.pdf{{dead link|date=August 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
==Freezer milling== Freezer milling is a type of cryogenic [[Mill (grinding)|milling]] that uses a solenoid to mill samples. The solenoid moves the grinding media back and forth inside the vial, grinding the sample down to analytical fineness. This type of milling is especially useful in milling temperature sensitive samples, as samples are milled at [[liquid nitrogen]] temperatures. The idea behind using a solenoid is that the only "moving part" in the system is the grinding media inside the vial. The reason for this is that at liquid nitrogen temperatures (–196°C) any moving part will come under huge stress leading to potentially poor reliability. Cryogenic milling using a solenoid has been used for over 50 years and has been proved to be a very reliable method of processing temperature sensitive samples in the laboratory.
==Cryomilling== Cryomilling is a variation of mechanical [[Mill (grinding)|milling]], in which metallic powders or other samples (e.g. temperature sensitive samples and samples with volatile components) are milled in a [[cryogen]] (usually [[liquid nitrogen]] or liquid argon) [[slurry]] or at a [[cryogenic]]s temperature under processing parameters, so a nanostructured microstructure is attained. Cryomilling takes advantage of both the cryogenic temperatures and conventional mechanical milling.<ref>''Suryanarayana C. Mechanical alloying and milling'', Progress in Materials Science 46 (2001) 1–184</ref> The extremely low milling temperature suppresses recovery and recrystallization and leads to finer grain structures and more rapid grain refinement.<ref>''Suryanarayana C. Mechanical alloying and milling'', Progress in Materials Science 46 (2001) 1-184</ref> The embrittlement of the sample makes even elastic and soft samples grindable. Tolerances less than 5 µm can be achieved. The ground material can be analyzed by a [[laboratory analyzer]].
==Applications in biology== Cryogenic grinding (or "cryogrinding") is a method of cell disruption employed by molecular life scientists to obtain broken cell material with favorable properties for protein extraction and affinity capture.<ref>http://www.ncdir.org/public-resources/protocols/ General methods</ref><ref>http://www.biotechniques.com/rapiddispatches/Improved-methodology-for-the-affinity-isolation-of-human-protein-complexes-expressed-at-near-endogenous-levels/biotechniques-330982.html {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130331030021/http://www.biotechniques.com/rapiddispatches/Improved-methodology-for-the-affinity-isolation-of-human-protein-complexes-expressed-at-near-endogenous-levels/biotechniques-330982.html |date=2013-03-31 }} Application to human tissue culture</ref> Once ground, the fine powder consisting of broken cells (or "grindate") can be stored for long periods at –80°C without obvious changes to biochemical properties – making it a very convenient source material in e.g. proteomic studies including affinity capture / mass spectrometry.
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Cryogenics]] [[Category:Microbiology techniques]] [[Category:Grinding and lapping]] [[Category:Plastics industry]]

{{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} '''David Combe''' (born 26 April 1943) was National Secretary of the [[Australian Labor Party]] (ALP), a political consultant and lobbyist, an Australian Trade Commissioner, a Senior Vice-President International of [[Southcorp Wines]], and a consultant to the Australian wine industry. ==Early life== Harvey David Mathew Combe was born in 1943 in [[Adelaide]], South Australia, and was educated at [[Prince Alfred College]] and the [[University of Adelaide]], where he earned a BA.. He became interested in politics at university and joined the ALP, partly through his friendship with [[Don Dunstan]]. (He has been Patron of the Don Dunstan Foundation since 2004.){{rp|pp.230,240}} ==Career== Combe was National Secretary of the [[Australian Labor Party]] (1973–1981), a political consultant and lobbyist (1981–1985), and an Australian senior trade commissioner (1985–1991), and has held senior executive and board positions within the Australian wine industry (1991–2008). ===Politics=== In 1973 Combe became the youngest-ever National Secretary of the Australian Labor Party after [[Australian federal election, 1972|the election of the first Labor government for 23 years]]. In November 1975, he was allegedly co-instigator, with [[Gough Whitlam]] and [[Bill Hartley (activist)|Bill Hartley]], of an unsuccessful approach to [[Saddam Hussein]]'s Iraq for a gift of 500,000 U.S. dollars to help in funding Labor's 1975 election campaign.Parkinson, Tony ''[http://www.theage.com.au/news/tony-parkinson/shame-whitlam-shame/2005/11/14/1131951094949.html Shame, Whitlam, Shame]'' The Age, 15 November 2005 Labor lost the [[Australian federal election, 1975|election]]. In an article published in ''The Bulletin'' in January 1982 Combe propagated the notion that Labor's defeat was partly due to the influence of the [[CIA]].{{rp|p.232}} Combe remained National Secretary until July 1981, when he resigned to establish a lobbying business, David Combe and Associates Pty Ltd. It reportedly "received a great fillip in [[Australian federal election, 1983|March 1983]], when the Labor Party was re-elected to office. Business perceived Combe as the most influential lobbyist then working in Canberra."{{rp|p.1}} ====Combe-Ivanov affair ==== In 1983 Combe was accused of compromising Australia's national security in dealings with a Soviet diplomat, [[Valery Ivanov]].Blesing, Meena. ''Was Your Dad a Russian Spy? The Personal Story of the Combe/Ivanov Affair.'' Sun Books, 1986.
The National Library of Australia [http://catalogue.nla.gov.au/Record/2041882 catalogue entry] states: "by David Combe's wife, Meena Blesing".Milliken R ''[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/obituaries-harvey-barnett-1594211.html Harvey Barnett Obituary]'' The Independent, London, 1 August 1995Cain, Frank ''The Australian Security Intelligence Organization: An Unofficial History'', Abingdon: Frank Cass & Co Ltd 1994 {{ISBN|0-7146-3477-8}}. Preview at [https://books.google.com/books?id=Pi80__UBKmEC&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_v2_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q=&f=false Google books]. Of particular relevance, Ch. 10: [https://books.google.com/books?id=Pi80__UBKmEC&pg=PA223&source=gbs_toc_r&cad=9#v=onepage&q=&f=false ASIO in the 1980s] pp223-252;
"Australian-Soviet Trade" pp.227–228,
"The Third Man – Lawrence Matheson" pp228-230 and
"The Rise and Fall of David Combe" pp230-234.
The rest of the chapter discusses "ASIO and the Combe-Ivanov affair" and "Justice Hope's Royal Commission". The Combe-Ivanov affair developed out of a trip Combe and his wife made to the USSR in 1982, in the course of preparations for which they met and developed a relationship with Valery Ivanov, then the First Secretary at the Soviet Embassy in Canberra. Soon after the formation of the [[Bob Hawke|Hawke]] government ASIO raised concerns that Combe, closely aligned to the ALP, might be being compromised by a Soviet citizen with KGB links. Ivanov was expelled from Australia in 1983 by Prime Minister Bob Hawke.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/12/world/around-the-world-australia-scandal-erupts-over-soviet-diplomat.html |title=''Australia Scandal Erupts Over Soviet Diplomat'' |date=12 May 1983 |publisher=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=20 April 2009}} The highly publicised events were investigated by the Hope Royal Commission on Australia's security and intelligence agencies of 1983–1984. The commission found that Combe had indeed been targeted by the Soviets, but there was no proof of intelligence breaches or of any threat to national security. Pryor, Geoff, [http://www.nla.gov.au/apps/cdview/?pi=nla.pic-an23136639], National Library of Australia, retrieved 1 July 2015. ===Trade commissioner=== Combe was Australia's senior trade commissioner in Western Canada from 1985 to 1989, and in Hong Kong from 1990 to 1991. ===Wine industry=== Combe was Senior Vice-President International and ran the European operations of Penfolds and Southcorp Wines during the rise in popularity of Australian wines in the 1990s. He is credited with developing significant export business for [[Southcorp Wines]], whose exports increased in value from 40 million Australian dollars in August 1991 to 300 million dollars in June 2000. In 2000 Combe was named Australia's Top Export Salesman by ''Overseas Trading'' magazine and was included in the list of "Twenty Five Most Influential Australians in Asia" published by ''Business Asia'' magazine.[http://www.claxtonspeakers.com.au/speakers_profile/60 Speaker's profile: David Combe], at Claxton Speakers (undated) From March 2001 to November 2003 Combe was a non-executive director for the Western Australian wine producer Evans and Tate Limited.Evans & Tate media release, 22 February 2001 [http://www.zoominfo.com/Search/ReferencesView.aspx?PersonID=67226540 copy available here] In 2004, in a speech at Bordeaux, he lambasted the wine-purchasing policies of UK supermarkets, which, he said, "if committed in Australia, would represent major breaches of the trade practices laws".Erhlich, R ''[https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/food-and-drink/features/my-round-state-of-independence-559243.html My Round: State of Independence]'' The Independent, London, 11 April 2004 In June 2004 he was appointed Chairman of Simon Gilbert Wines,[http://cache.zoominfo.com/CachedPage/?archive_id=0&page_id=1849970857&page_url=%2f%2fwww.skalliandrein.com%2fwinevolution%2fspeaker_david_combe.php&page_last_updated=4%2f4%2f2007+12%3a46%3a10+AM&firstName=David&lastName=Combe Speaker's Profile], David Combe, Chairman of Simon Gilbert Wines Limited, Australia. Skalli & Rein "Wine Revolution" Conference, www.skalliandrein.com. Cached at cache.zoominfo.com (2007). Retrieved on 1 September 2009. He retired as a director and chairman in February 2007, "to take up another position within the wine industry".Simon Gilbert Wines [http://www.coonawarravineyard.com.au/content/pdf/capt/archive/SGV%20Proposed%20Rights%20Issue%2014022007.pdf board statement], 14 February 2007. ==Portrait== In 1983, [[Keith Looby]] painted Combe's portrait. The portrait was an unsuccessful entry in the [[Archibald Prize]] of 1983, and conspiracy theories on this matter abound. David Combe said in 1998 that there was 'circumstantially a good case to believe that some trustees were heavied by the Party' into rejecting the work.[http://www.portrait.gov.au/site/collection_info.php?searchtype=advanced&searchstring=:::::1:&irn=28 David Combe and the portrait], National Portrait Gallery, Canberra In 1998, Combe donated his portrait to the collection of the [[National Portrait Gallery (Australia)|National Portrait Gallery]] in Canberra, "through the Australian Government's Cultural Gifts Program". ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== * Marr, David. ''The Ivanov Trail''. Melbourne: Nelson, 1984. {{ISBN|0-17-006405-0}} [http://catalogue.nla.gov.au/Record/2694984 NLA catalogue], [http://www.middlemiss.org/lit/authors/marrd.html more info] * Aarons, Laurie. ''The Stumblebum Syndrome: ASIO and David Combe: The "Security" Threat to Australian Democracy''. Sydney : Red Pen Publications, 1984. {{ISBN|0-909913-59-5}} [http://catalogue.nla.gov.au/Record/1071486 NLA catalogue] * Royal Commission on Australia's Security and Intelligence Agencies, ''General Report'', Canberra: Australian Government Publishing Service, 1985. {{ISBN|0-644-04094-7}} [http://catalogue.nla.gov.au/Record/1582598 NLA catalogue] {{s-start}} {{S-ppo}} {{S-bef|before=[[Mick Young]]}} {{S-ttl|title=[[Australian Labor Party|National Secretary of the Australian Labor Party]]|years=1973-1981}} {{S-aft|after=[[Bob McMullan]]}} {{s-end}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Combe, David}} [[Category:1943 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Australian businesspeople]] [[Category:Combe–Ivanov affair]] [[Category:People from Adelaide]] [[Category:University of Adelaide alumni]]

'''Denis Kessler''' (born 25 March 1952 in [[Mulhouse]]) is a [[French people|French]] [[businessman]]. He has served as the Chairman of the Board of Directors and Chief Executive Officer of [[SCOR SE]] since 2002.<ref name="scor">[http://www.scor.com/en/the-group/organisation/executive-committee.html SCOR Executive committee]</ref><ref name="forbes">[https://people.forbes.com/profile/denis-kessler/45219 Forbes profile]</ref><ref name="businessweek">[http://investing.businessweek.com/businessweek/research/stocks/people/person.asp?personId=1745802&ticker=SCR:FP&previousCapId=873976&previousTitle=BNP%20PARIBAS BusinessWeek profile]</ref> Prior to this, he served as Vice-Chairman of [[MEDEF]] and CEO of [[AXA]].<ref name="scor"/><ref name="businessweek"/><ref>'Denis Kessler quitte le Medef pour présider Scor', in ''[[L'Expansion]]'', 05/11/2002 [http://lexpansion.lexpress.fr/entreprise/denis-kessler-quitte-le-medef-pour-presider-scor_97285.html]</ref><ref name="invesco">[http://www.invesco.com/portal/site/global/Directors/ Invesco Board of Directors]</ref>
==Biography== He graduated from [[HEC Paris]], and received a PhD in Economics from the [[University of Paris]].<ref name="scor"/><ref name="forbes"/><ref name="businessweek"/><ref name="invesco"/>
He is a Board member of [[BNP Paribas]], [[Bolloré]], [[Dassault Aviation]], [[Invesco]], and [[Fonds stratégique d'investissement]].<ref name="forbes"/><ref name="businessweek"/> He is member of the Supervisory Board of [[Yam Invest N.V.]].<ref name="forbes"/><ref name="invesco"/><ref>[http://www.yaminvest.com/en/index.php?page=organes_de_direction Yam Invest Supervisory Board]</ref> He served as the President of [[Le Siècle (think tank)|Le Siècle]] from 2007 to 2010.<ref name="lefigaro">AFP, '"Le Siècle": Nicole Notat présidente', in ''[[Le Figaro]]'', 12/11/2010 [http://www.lefigaro.fr/flash-actu/2010/11/12/97001-20101112FILWWW00603-le-siecle-nicole-notat-presidente.php]</ref>
He has criticized the [[Keynesian]] reaction to the [[2008 financial crisis]], and he has suggested the end of the [[Euro currency]] is a real possibility.<ref>François Vidal, 'Denis Kessler : « Alors que la crise pourrait s'aggraver, nous n'avons plus de munitions »', in ''[[Les Échos (France)|Les Echos]]'', 12/09/2011 [http://www.lesechos.fr/journal20110912/lec1_entretien_du_lundi/0201622348947-denis-kessler-alors-que-la-crise-pourrait-s-aggraver-nous-n-avons-plus-de-munitions-217690.php]</ref><ref>Daniel Roland, 'Denis Kessler: "nous n'avons plus de munitions", la zone euro peut exploser', in ''[[L'Express]]'', 12/09/2011 [http://www.lexpress.fr/actualites/1/economie/denis-kessler-nous-n-avons-plus-de-munitions-la-zone-euro-peut-exploser_1029110.html]</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kessler, Denis}} [[Category:1952 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Mulhouse]] [[Category:French businesspeople]]
{{France-business-bio-stub}}

{{other uses|DGM (disambiguation){{!}}DGM}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{Use British English|date=October 2013}} [[File:-Possible Productions knotwork- by Steve Ball.svg|right|thumb|alt=A knotwork, a design often associated with Celtic knots. The outer design is a circle, surrounding what appears to be a triangle surrounded by a Celtic knot at first glance. Closer inspection of the triangle reveals that it is in fact an organic part of the inner knot, which seems to have two continuous segments linked by knots. At first glance, the knotwork appears to be symmetric; closer inspection reveals that the right-hand knots seem to be the reverse of the left-hand knots and there are small differences among the "twin knots"; the right and left hands of the design have variations, much as our right and left hands have subtle distinctions. The design is not symmetric with respect to 120 degree rotations: The center of the pseudo-triangle is above the center of the surrounding circle, but visual balance is maintained by extra knots below the lower pseudo–line-segment. The background is crimson.|Discipline Global Mobile logo, whose copyright, per the company's philosophy regarding creative works, was maintained by its designer rather than the company.]] '''Discipline Global Mobile''' ('''DGM''', or '''Discipline GM''') is an [[independent record label]] founded in 1992 by [[Robert Fripp]] (best known as guitarist and main composer for the band [[King Crimson]]) and producer/online content developer [[David Singleton]].{{cite news|title=The Wire|date=Aug 2014}} DGM has released solo music by Fripp as well as work by various affiliated musicians and bands including King Crimson, The Vicar, the [[California Guitar Trio]] and others.{{cite web|last1=About DGMLive|title=Statement at foot of homepage|url=http://www.dgmlive.com/index.php}} The label has offices in [[Salisbury]], [[England]], and [[Los Angeles]], [[California]];[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]], 1998 DGM has aimed to be "a model of ethical business in an industry founded on exploitation, oiled by deceit, riven with theft and fueled by greed," according to Fripp.{{harvtxt|Fripp|1998|p=9}} according to {{harvtxt|Bruns|2003|p=3}} Its policy is that its artists retain all copyrights; consequently, even DGM's corporate logo is owned by its designer. The label was an early adopter of the digital download system. DGM's aims have been hailed as "exemplary", and the label has been credited with having expanded "the possibilities of experimental music" and having improved the environment for King Crimson. The DGM label name is derived from the title of a 1981 King Crimson album (''[[Discipline (King Crimson album)|Discipline]]'') and from the name of Singleton’s previous recording business (The Mobile). The label logo also partly reflects the artwork for the ''Discipline'' album (featuring a new but similar knotwork commissioned from the artist Steve Ball).Discipline Global Mobile - Ball Diary 13 ==Foundation and business aims== [[File:Robert Fripp.jpg|right|thumb|alt=Robert Fripp ergonomically plays electric guitar while sitting in a posture developed through years of application of the Alexander Technique.|The founder of Discipline Global Mobile, [[Robert Fripp]] has called music "an industry founded on exploitation, oiled by deceit, riven with theft and fueled by greed".]] Having been a professional musician since the mid-'60s (and the guitarist for King Crimson since 1969), by the late 1980s [[Robert Fripp]] found himself in conflict with his longtime record label [[E.G. Records]] and management company (E.G. Management) over royalties allegedly owed by E.G. to himself and to other band members. During this period, Fripp met and began working with producer and online developer [[David Singleton]], initially on a [[Guitar Craft]] tour in 1990 and subsequently on the production of two albums - the League of Crafty Guitarists' ''Show of Hands'' and the eponymous album for the Fripp-and-[[Toyah Willcox|Toyah]]-fronted group [[Sunday All Over the World]]. Fripp and Singleton's production partnership was sealed by work on two King Crimson boxed sets (1991's ''Frame by Frame'' and 1992's ''The Great Deceiver'') and continues to the present day under the name of TonProb. After seven years, Fripp and E.G. reached a settlement {{harvtxt|Bruford|2009|p=[https://books.google.com/books?hl=sv&id=R4iW0tsxLqQC&dq=Bill+Bruford&q=EG%2C%20Virgin%2C%20EMI%2C%20Fripp&f=false#v=snippet&q=EG%2C%20Virgin%2C%20EMI%2C%20Fripp&f=false 142]}} but the experience left Fripp determined to take control of his own work and financial affairs wherever possible. As part of this aim, he founded Discipline Global Mobile (DGM) as an independent music label in 1992, as a fifty-fifty partnership with Singleton.{{cite news|date=3 August 2012|time=7:27 pm|title=The day the music died: In a rare interview, prog rock legend Robert Fripp speaks about standing up to the music industry|first=Ludovic|last=Hunter-Tilney|url=http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/2/f588e100-d7ee-11e1-9980-00144feabdc0.html#axzz22cThb6xb|newspaper=The Financial Times|ref=harv|accessdate=5 August 2012}}, {{harvtxt|Bambarger|1998}} {{harvtxt|Atton|2001|p=39}} DGM's [[mission statement]] consists of five "DGM business aims", as follows: * "The first aim of DGM is to help bring music into the world which would otherwise be unlikely to do so, or under conditions prejudicial to the music and / or musicians.",{{cite web |url=http://www.dgmlive.com/about.htm |title=About DGM: DGM business aims |publisher=Discipline Global Mobile |ref=harv |access-date=25 March 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120302061103/http://www.dgmlive.com/about.htm |archive-date=2 March 2012 }} * "The second aim of DGM is to operate in the market place, while being free of the values of the market place." * "The third aim of DGM is to help the artists and staff of DGM achieve what they wish for themselves." * "The fourth aim of DGM is to find its audience." * "The fifth aim of DGM is to be a model of ethical business in an industry founded on exploitation, oiled by deceit, riven with theft and fueled by greed."{{harvtxt|Bambarger|1998|p=86}}{{harvtxt|Atton|2004|loc=[https://books.google.com/books?id=fZa_x8DEP_oC&pg=PA103&dq=%22Discipline+Global+Mobile%22&source=gbs_toc_r&cad=3#v=onepage&q=%22Discipline%20Global%20Mobile%22%2C%20copyright&f=false Chapter 6 "Fan culture and the Internet: Musicians and fanzines", p. 153]}} [[File:John Paul Jones - 2010.jpg|left|thumb|alt=John Paul Jones plays bass guitar|Formerly the bass guitarist of Led Zeppelin, [[John Paul Jones (musician)|John Paul Jones]] has recorded albums with DGM without signing a contract, stating that the relationship "is pure trust".]] These aims were called "exemplary" by Bill Martin, who wrote that "Fripp has done something very important for the possibilities of experimental music" in creating DGM, and that DGM "has played a major role in creating favorable conditions for" King Crimson.{{harvtxt|Martin|1997|p=[https://books.google.com/books?id=APmUFlgm0R4C&dq=Prog+Rock&q=Discipline+Global+Mobile#v=snippet&q=Discipline%20Global%20Mobile&f=false 269]}} Since at least the early 1960s, the recording industry has required artists to sign over [[copyright]]s and [[moral right (copyright)|moral right]]s to their cover art, music, and lyrics. DGM rejects this practice, and since its 1992 founding has maintained its policy that its artists retain the copyrights and the moral rights to their works, be those works musical or visual art. Fripp wrote,
"The phonographic copyright in these performances is operated by Discipline Global Mobile on behalf of the artists, with whom it resides, contrary to common practice in the record industry. Discipline accepts no reason for artists to assign the copyright interests in their work to either record company or management by virtue of a 'common practice' which was always questionable, often improper, and is now indefensible."{{harvtxt|Kozar|2012|loc=[http://www.popmatters.com/pm/feature/150412-robert-fripp-an-appreciation/P1 "Fripp's aim was to move his music in new directions that others did not always understand", p. 2]}}
This extends even to DGM's [[Celtic knot|knotwork]] corporate logo, the copyright of which is owned not by the company, but by its designer,{{harvtxt|Fripp|1998a|p=3}} Steve Ball.{{cite web |url=http://www.steveball.com/words/archive/2001/2001-10-01.htm#saturday |first=Steve |last=Ball |title=Saturday September 29 |department=Steve Ball diary |date=1 October 2001 |website=Steve Ball |ref=harv |access-date=25 March 2012}}

{{harvtxt|Ball|2001}} cites as the original inspiration for the first cover for ''Discipline'' a design by {{harvtxt|Bain|1973|loc=[https://www.amazon.co.uk/Celtic-Art-Methods-Construction-Instruction/dp/0486229238/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1332253259&sr=1-1#reader_0486229238 "Pictish knotwork borders from Gospels of Lindifarme and Book of Kells", p. 40]}}: {{cite book|first=George|last=Bain|authorlink=George Bain (artist)|title=Celtic art: The methods of construction |year=1973|publisher=[[Dover Publications]]|location=Mineola, New York|isbn=0-486-22923-8|origyear=1951|edition=Reprint of Constable Press|ref=harv}}{{cite web |url=http://www.steveball.com/words/presskit/#history |first=Steve |last=Ball |title=Steve Ball extended history |department=Steve Ball Roadshow |website=Steve Ball |ref=harv |date=21 May 2009 |access-date=25 March 2012}}Robert Fripp wrote, "Steve Ball is ... designer of the [League of Crafty Guitarists] & Discipline knotworks (among others & in which he holds the copyright)." {{cite book|first=Robert|last=Fripp|title=Robert Fripp's diary|chapter=Sunday, 22nd August 1999|date=August 1999|url=http://www.dgmlive.com|publisher=Discipline Global Mobile|ref=harv|accessdate=25 March 2012|authorlink=Robert Fripp}} {{Bad linked references|section|date=January 2013}}

{{harvtxt|Hegarty|Halliwell|2011|loc=[http://cipg.codemantra.us/UI_TRANSACTIONS/Marketing/UI_Marketing.aspx?ID=WP9780826423320&ISBN=9780826423320&sts=b "Illustration credits: Chapter 9", p. xii]}} DGM does not require that its artists sign written contracts.{{cite news|title=Been a long time: John Paul Jones hitting the road 19 years after Zeppelin's demise|newspaper=Rocky Mountain News|location=Denver, CO|date=22 October 1999|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-67423491.html|first=Michael|last=Mehle|id={{subscription required}}|accessdate=14 April 2012|ref=harv}} Former [[Led Zeppelin]] bassist [[John Paul Jones (musician)|John Paul Jones]] said, "It's pure trust," and noted that "there are dangers on both sides. I could have a successful album and just sign with a major, or they could decide not to pay me." Jones explained that he was accustomed to "working in situations that do rely on trust and integrity, those old-fashioned words" because Led Zeppelin had no contract with [[Peter Grant (music manager)|its manager]].{{cite news|first=Fiona|last=Shepherd|title=Recognise the face of bass? (Clue: Think Led Zeppelin)|newspaper=[[The Scotsman]]|publisher=ECM Publishers, Inc|year=1999|accessdate=14 April 2012|ref=harv|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-18707295.html|id={{subscription required}}}} Another DGM band, alternative rock group {{anchor|Rosenbergs}}The Rosenbergs, opted to work with the label following conflicts with their previous label [[Universal Records]], which had even demanded control of the band's [[domain name]]: in contrast, DGM had encouraged them to retain control of their own [[master recording]]s and provided them with funds for touring and promoting their album.{{harvtxt|Spellman|2002|p=[https://books.google.com/books?id=wAwFYg56rAYC&q=Discipline&hl=sv#v=snippet&q=Discipline&f=false 87]}}) Royalties are paid above the prevailing rate, as announced at DGM's launch. In return, DGM artists are responsible for promoting their albums through concert tours and interviews. ==Artists and back catalogue== [[File:Adrian Belew (2006).jpg|right|thumb|alt=Adrian Belew plays electric guitar|King Crimson guitarist [[Adrian Belew]] has recorded several albums with DGM.]] Discipline Global Mobile specializes in art rock, progressive rock, jazz, and assorted experimental and crossover music (the label has also released recordings of Renaissance lute music and mainstream alternative rock). DGM has released more than a hundred King Crimson recordings, including remastered albums with bonus tracks and DVDs with archival footage. In addition to King Crimson, DGM's current active roster includes assorted Robert Fripp projects and The Vicar (a songwriter project).{{cite journal|last=Cook|first=Richard|title=In praise of older men|journal=New Statesman|publisher=New Statesman Ltd|date=1 January 1996|accessdate=14 April 2012|ref=harv|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P3-38146164.html|id={{subscription required}}|jstor=}} The label has previously released music by various Fripp-affiliated ensembles; [[The League of Crafty Guitarists]], Les Gauchos Allemagnes, the [[California Guitar Trio]] and the Robert Fripp String Quartet (all of which stem from or are connected with Fripp's [[Guitar Craft]] courses) {{cite journal|last=Molenda|first=Michael|title=California Guitar Trio: Paul Richards, Bert Lams, Hideyo Moriya|journal=Guitar Player|publisher=NewBay Media LLC.|date=1 January 2000|accessdate=14 April 2012|ref=harv|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-57893412.html|id={{subscription required}}}} ===Current/recent DGM artists=== * [[King Crimson]] (over 100 releases of archive material and additional releases outside of current major-label product) * [[The ProjeKcts]] (King Crimson subgroups) * [[Robert Fripp]] (solo releases, Soundscape recordings) * [[Fripp & Eno]] * The Vicar * [[David Sylvian]] & Robert Fripp (reissues) * Jakszyk, Fripp & Collins ===Past DGM artists=== * [[Adrian Belew]] * [[Pat Mastelotto|BPM&M]] * [[Bill Bruford]] (with [[Ralph Towner]] & [[Eddie Gomez]]) * Bill Bruford’s Earthworks * [[Bruford Levin Upper Extremities]] * [[California Guitar Trio]] * [[Europa String Choir]] * Robert Fripp String Quintet * Tony Geballe * Gitbox * [[Trey Gunn]] * [[Peter Hammill]] * Steve Hancoff * Jacob Heringman * [[John Paul Jones (musician)|John Paul Jones]] * [[Tony Levin]] * Los Gauchos Alemanes * Mr McFall's Chamber * [[Bill Nelson (musician)|Bill Nelson]] * Opus 20 * Juan Carlos Quintero * [[The Rosenbergs (band)|The Rosenbergs]] * Ten Seconds ==Mail-order and on-line services== According to a 1998 profile in ''Billboard'' magazine, Discipline Global Mobile had seven staff members in Salisbury, England, and three in Los Angeles, California. DGM "is actually housed in a dull pebbledash building in a village near Salisbury, south-west England". Its label manager reported that the country with the largest market was Japan, where mail-orders accounted for only 10% of sales, but 50% of profits. In 1998, DGM was distributed in Japan by [[Pony Canyon]]; in the United Kingdom by [[Pinnacle Records|Pinnacle]]; and in the United States by [[Rykodisc]]. Sound samples have been offered in addition to DGM's mail-order services. Free downloads from DGM have strengthened the relations between artists and fans. In 2012, DGM's site had the following introduction: "The aim of DGM is to connect music, musician and audience in a way that supports the power of music, the integrity of the musician and the needs of the audience. DGM Live offers music for download with photographs, diary archives and audience commentary for browsing".{{cite web|url=http://www.dgmlive.com|title=Welcome to DGM Live|publisher=Discipline Global Mobile|ref=harv|accessdate=25 March 2012}} DGM's successful transition to an age of digital distribution was called "unique" among music labels in 2009; this success was credited to its provision of legal, high-quality recordings of concerts, which effectively [[Reverse engineering|reverse-engineered]] the [[Fence (criminal)|distribution-networks]] for [[Bootleg recording|unlicensed recordings ("bootlegs")]] of concerts.{{cite news|last=Anonymous|first=''Belfast Telegraph''|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-20648653.html|title=Jam and the joys of music distribution in today's world|newspaper=Belfast Telegraph|publisher=Independent News and Media PLC|date=18 August 2009|accessdate=14 April 2012|ref=harv|id={{subscription required}}}} DGM publishes on-line diaries by Robert Fripp, David Singleton and The Vicar.{{cite web|title=DGM Diaries|url=http://www.dgmlive.com/diaries.htm}} A moderated forum allows fans to ask questions or to leave comments. Together, the diaries and the fan forum display delayed dialogs in which the artists and fans discuss diary-entries and forum-postings. Fripp's public writing of his diary has challenged his readers to become more active listeners and intelligent participants in performances of music.{{harvtxt|Atton|2001|p=43}} ===Conflict with Grooveshark=== Fripp's diaries were internationally discussed following his publication of documents from a dispute with [[Grooveshark]], an on-line distributor of music. Fripp and Singleton complained that Grooveshark had been continuing to distribute his music, even after repeated [[notice and take down|takedown notice]]s and other complaints. Their correspondence with Grooveshark was published by ''Digital Music News''{{cite news|title=Grooveshark lawsuit reveals details of Universal Music Group's allegations|first=Glenn|last=Peoples|date=21 November 2011|newspaper=Billboard.biz|publisher=Billboard.com|url=http://www.billboard.biz/bbbiz/industry/legal-and-management/grooveshark-lawsuit-reveals-details-of-universal-1005549582.story|ref=harv|accessdate=30 May 2012}}{{cite journal|title=King Crimson can't get their music off of Grooveshark, so they cc'd ''Digital Music News''..|date=13 October 2011|ref=harv|url=http://www.digitalmusicnews.com/stories/101311cc|first=Paul ("paul")|last=Resnikoff|journal=[[Digital Music News]]|accessdate=30 May 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111123003659/http://www.digitalmusicnews.com/stories/101311cc|archivedate=23 November 2011|df=dmy-all}} and in his DGM diary.{{cite web|title=Robert Fripp's diaries|url=http://www.dgmlive.com|ref=harv|date=12 August – 20 October 2011|publisher=Discipline Global Mobile, DMG Live!|first=Robert|last=Fripp|authorlink=Robert Fripp|accessdate=30 May 2012}}:

August: "Friday, 12th August 2011", "Saturday, 13th August 2011", "Monday, 15th August 2011", "Tuesday, 16th August 2011", "Wednesday, 17th August 2011";

September: "Wednesday, 7th September 2011", "Saturday, 10th September 2011", "Monday, 12th September 2011", "Wednesday, 14th September 2011", "Thursday, 15th September 2011", "Wednesday, 21 September 2011", and "Monday, 26th September 2011";

October: "Thursday, October 13th, 2011" and "Thursday, 20th October 2011". {{Bad linked references|section|date=January 2013}} Fripp's exchange with Grooveshark was included in a suit against Grooveshark by Universal Music Group, which was filed in November 2011.{{cite news|title=Sony and Warner are said to sue web music service|first=Ben|last=Sisario|date=14 December 2011|newspaper=New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/12/15/business/media/sony-and-warner-are-said-to-join-suit-against-grooveshark.html?_r=1|ref=harv|accessdate=30 May 2012}}[http://news.cnet.com/8301-31001_3-57327815-261/lawsuit-claims-grooveshark-workers-posted-100000-pirated-songs/ Lawsuit claims Grooveshark workers posted 100,000 pirated songs]. Greg Sandoval, CNET, 21 November 2011 ==See also== * [[List of record labels]] * [[P. J. {{about|the Major League Soccer franchise|the United Soccer League team|FC Cincinnati (2016–18)}} {{Use mdy dates|date=May 2018}} {{Infobox football club | nickname = Orange and Blue | clubname = FC Cincinnati | image = FC_Cincinnati_primary_logo_2018.svg | upright = 1 | caption = | fullname = Football Club Cincinnati{{cite web|url=http://www.wvxu.org/post/football-club-cincinnati-check-out-fc-cincinnatis-new-branding|title=Football Club Cincinnati: Check Out FC Cincinnati's New Branding|first=Tana|last=Weingartner|publisher=|accessdate=November 13, 2018}} | motto = | founded = {{start date and years ago|2018|5|29|mf=yes}} | owner = [[Carl H. Lindner III]] | chrtitle = | chairman = | mgrtitle = | manager = [[Alan Koch (soccer)|Alan Koch]]{{cite web|url=https://www.cincinnati.com/story/sports/soccer/fc-cincinnati/2018/10/26/fc-cincinnatis-alan-koch-man-lead-club-into-mls/1684468002/|title=FC Cincinnati's Alan Koch: The man to lead the club into Major League Soccer|publisher=|accessdate=November 13, 2018}} | league = [[Major League Soccer]] | season = [[2019 MLS season|2019]] ([[Major League Soccer]]) | position = | website = http://www.fccincinnati.com | American = false | stadium = [[Nippert Stadium]]
[[Cincinnati, Ohio]] | capacity = 33,800{{cite news|author=FCC staff|title=Record Crowd Watches FCC Take on Crystal Palace|url=http://www.fccincinnati.com/news_article/show/670352|website=FCCincinnati.com|date=July 16, 2016|accessdate=October 7, 2016}} | current = 2019 FC Cincinnati season | pattern_la1 = | pattern_la2 = | pattern_la3 = | pattern_b1 = | pattern_b2 = | pattern_b3 = | pattern_ra1 = | pattern_ra2 = | pattern_ra3 = | pattern_sh1 = | pattern_sh2 = | pattern_sh3 = | pattern_so1 = | pattern_so2 = | pattern_so3 = | leftarm1 = | leftarm2 = | leftarm3 = | body1 = | body2 = | body3 = | rightarm1 = | rightarm2 = | rightarm3 = | shorts1 = | shorts2 = | shorts3 = | socks1 = | socks2 = | socks3 = }} '''FC Cincinnati''' is a [[association football|soccer]] club based in [[Cincinnati]], [[Ohio]], that will begin play in [[Major League Soccer]] (MLS) in 2019. The team will succeed the [[FC Cincinnati (2016–18)|lower-division team]] of the same name and was announced on May 29, 2018, when MLS awarded an expansion franchise to Cincinnati.{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/soccer/major-league-soccer/story/3512103/fc-cincinnati-to-join-mls-as-expansion-team-next-season|title=FC Cincinnati to join MLS as expansion team|publisher=|accessdate=November 13, 2018}} The club's ownership group is led by [[Carl H. Lindner III]]. ==History== The owners of [[FC Cincinnati (2016–18)|the USL club]] began negotiations with Major League Soccer over a potential expansion franchise in early 2016, and Cincinnati was announced as one of ten cities that had expressed interest in the slots for teams 25 to 28.{{cite news |last=Couch |first=Ben |date=December 15, 2016 |title=MLS announces expansion process and timeline |url=https://www.mlssoccer.com/post/2016/12/15/mls-announces-expansion-process-and-timeline |work=MLSsoccer.com |accessdate=May 29, 2018}}{{cite news |date=April 23, 2016 |title=FC Cincinnati 'in talks' with Major League Soccer, but no solid plan in the works |url=https://www.wcpo.com/sports/fc-cincinnati/fc-cincinnati-in-talks-with-major-league-soccer-but-no-solid-plan-in-the-works |publisher=[[WCPO-TV|WCPO]] |accessdate=May 29, 2018}} MLS Commissioner [[Don Garber]] visited Cincinnati in December 2016 to tour Nippert Stadium and meet with city and club officials, complimenting the city and its fans.{{cite news |last=Hatch |first=Charlie |date=December 4, 2016 |title=MLS Commissioner Don Garber impressed by Cincinnati after midweek tour |url=https://www.mlssoccer.com/post/2016/12/04/mls-commissioner-don-garber-impressed-cincinnati-after-midweek-tour |work=MLSsoccer.com |accessdate=May 29, 2018}} FC Cincinnati formally submitted its expansion bid in January 2017, including a shortlist of potential stadium locations.{{cite news |last=Brennan |first=Patrick |date=January 31, 2017 |title=FC Cincinnati submits expansion bid to MLS |url=https://www.cincinnati.com/story/sports/soccer/fc-cincinnati/2017/01/31/fc-cincinnati-submits-expansion-bid-mls/97283374/ |work=The Cincinnati Enquirer |accessdate=May 29, 2018}} On May 29, 2018, Major League Soccer announced that Cincinnati would join the league in 2019 as an expansion team under the FC Cincinnati brand.{{cite news |last=Brennan |first=Patrick |date=May 29, 2018 |title=It's official: FC Cincinnati has joined MLS, will begin play in 2019 |url=https://www.cincinnati.com/story/sports/soccer/fc-cincinnati/2018/05/29/its-official-fc-cincinnati-has-joined-mls-begin-play-2019/652201002/ |work=The Cincinnati Enquirer |accessdate=May 29, 2018}}{{cite news|author=MLSsoccer staff|title=Cincinnati awarded MLS expansion club, will start play in 2019|url=https://www.mlssoccer.com/post/2018/05/29/fc-cincinnati-named-26th-mls-team-starting-play-2019|publisher=MLS Digital|website=MLSSoccer.com|date=May 29, 2018|accessdate=May 30, 2018}} A 21,000-seat [[FC Cincinnati stadium|stadium]] in the [[West End, Cincinnati|West End]] is scheduled to open in 2021.{{cite press release |date=May 29, 2018 |title=Cincinnati awarded MLS expansion club, will start play in 2019 |url=https://www.mlssoccer.com/post/2018/05/29/fc-cincinnati-named-26th-mls-team-starting-play-2019 |publisher=[[Major League Soccer]] |accessdate=May 29, 2018}}{{cite news |last=Watkins |first=Steve |date=March 22, 2018 |title=Here's when FC Cincinnati plans to begin play in new stadium |url=https://www.bizjournals.com/cincinnati/news/2018/03/22/here-s-when-fc-cincinnati-plans-to-begin-play-in.html |work=[[Cincinnati Business Journal]] |accessdate=May 29, 2018}} FC Cincinnati signed their first two MLS players, [[Fanendo Adi]] and [[Fatai Alashe]], in July 2018. Adi was the team's first designated player.{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/soccer/major-league-soccer/story/3579476/fc-cincinnati-signs-fanendo-adi-and-fatai-alashe-ahead-of-mls-move|title=FC Cincinnati signs Fanendo Adi, Fatai Alashe ahead of MLS move|publisher=espn.com}} Both players were loaned to the FC Cincinnati [[FC Cincinnati (2016–18)|USL team]] for the remainder of the 2018 season.{{cite web|url=https://www.uslsoccer.com/news_article/show/938424|title=Cincinnati Bolsters Squad with Adi, Alashe|publisher=uslsoccer.com|date=31 July 2018}} FC Cincinnati will select up to five players from certain MLS teams in the [[2018 MLS Expansion Draft|expansion draft]], scheduled to take place on December 11, 2018.{{cite web|url=https://www.wcpo.com/news/local-news/hamilton-county/cincinnati/fc-cincinnati-can-select-5-major-league-players-for-inaugural-roster|title=FC Cincinnati can select 5 major league players for inaugural roster}} == Stadium == FC Cincinnati will play at [[Nippert Stadium]] while their new [[West End Stadium]] is being built.{{cn|date=November 2018}} The new stadium is expected to open in 2021.{{cite news |url=https://www.cincinnati.com/story/sports/soccer/fc-cincinnati/2018/10/19/fc-cincinnati-stadium-break-ground-dec-19-open-march-2021/1694381002/ |title=FC Cincinnati stadium will break ground Dec. 19, open March 2021 |last=Knight |first=Cameron |date=October 19, 2018 |work=The Cincinnati Enquirer |accessdate=October 25, 2018}} == Rivalries == Cincinnati has a potential in-state rival in [[Columbus Crew SC|Columbus Crew]].{{cite web|last1=Reed|first1=Tom|title=It's feeling real in Cincinnati|url=http://www.dispatch.com/sports/20170614/soccer--its-feeling-real-in-cincinnati|website=[[The Columbus Dispatch]]|publisher=[[GateHouse Media]]|accessdate=December 27, 2017|date=June 14, 2017}} Cincinnati's USL team defeated the Crew in a [[2017 U.S. Open Cup]] match known as "Hell Is Real" after a billboard on [[Interstate 71]], the highway between Columbus and Cincinnati.{{cite web|last1=Murphy|first1=Pat|title=Massive Predictions: Hell is Real – Will Hell freeze over or take over Columbus following this U.S. Open Cup Derby?|url=https://www.massivereport.com/2017/6/14/15803776/massive-predictions-hell-is-real-columbus-crew-sc-fc-cincinnati-us-open-cup|website=Massive Report|publisher=[[SB Nation]]|accessdate=December 27, 2017|date=June 14, 2017}}{{cite web|last1=Hatch|first1=Charlie|title='HELL IS REAL,' and so is FC Cincinnati's threat to Columbus|url=https://www.fourfourtwo.com/us/features/hell-is-real-derby-fc-cincinnati-threat-columbus-crew-mls-usl|website=[[FourFourTwo]]|publisher=[[Haymarket Media Group]]|accessdate=December 27, 2017|date=June 14, 2017}} == Ownership == [[File:MLS2Cincy announcement - MLS2Cincy photo op (42393315042) (cropped).jpg|thumb|right|upright=1.2|General manager [[Jeff Berding]], [[Major League Soccer|MLS]] commissioner [[Don Garber]], club owner [[Carl Lindner III]], and Cincinnati mayor [[John Cranley]] at the MLS franchise announcement in 2018]] Former [[Cincinnati Bengals]] executive [[Jeff Berding]] is the president and general manager.{{cite news |last=Kay |first=Joe |date=May 29, 2018 |title=FC Cincinnati to join MLS in 2019 as league's latest expansion team |url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/sports/soccer/ct-spt-fc-cincinnati-mls-expansion-20180529-story.html |work=[[Chicago Tribune]] |agency=Associated Press |accessdate=May 29, 2018}} The CEO and majority owner of the team is [[Carl Lindner III]], CEO of [[American Financial Group]], with [[Scott Farmer (businessman)|Scott Farmer]] also a leading owner.{{cite news |last=Strauss |first=Brian |date=February 1, 2017 |title=MLS expansion city profile: Cincinnati |url=https://www.si.com/planet-futbol/2017/02/01/cincinnati-mls-expansion-city-usl-lindner-harkes-berry |work=Sports Illustrated |accessdate=May 29, 2018}}{{cit web|url=https://www.bizjournals.com/cincinnati/news/2018/05/22/fc-cincinnati-owner-lindner-on-mls-bid-i-think-we.html|title=FC Cincinnati owner Lindner on MLS bid: ‘I think we’re going to get over the finish line'|date=23 May 2018|publisher=Cincinnati Business Courier|last=Watkins|first=Steve}} == Roster == {{Updated|November 26, 2018|https://www.fccincinnati.com/players}} {{FC Cincinnati current roster}} == Sponsorship == {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;margin-left:;" |- ! Period ! Kit Manufacturer ! Shirt Sponsor ! |Ref. |- | 2019 (planned) | rowspan=1| [[Adidas]]https://www.mlssoccer.com/post/2017/08/02/major-league-soccer-and-adidas-extend-landmark-partnership-through-2024 | rowspan=1| [[Mercy Health Partners]] | {{cite web |title=Major League Soccer Awards Expansion Team to Cincinnati |url=https://www.fccincinnati.com/news_article/show/922382 |website=FCCincinnati.com |date=May 29, 2018|accessdate=May 30, 2018}} |} ==References== {{Ref-list}} {{FC Cincinnati|state=expanded}} {{Navboxes | titlestyle = background:#E75204; color:#FFFFFF; {{box-shadow border|a|#1F3A95|2px}} | list= {{FC Cincinnati squad}} {{Major League Soccer}} {{Ohio Sports}} {{Lindner family}} }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Cincinnati}} [[Category:Association football clubs established in 2018]] [[Category:2018 establishments in Ohio]] [[Category:Soccer clubs in Cincinnati]] [[Category:Soccer clubs in Ohio]] [[Category:Lindner family]] [[Category:FC Cincinnati| ]] [[Category:Major League Soccer teams]]

'''Fashion Revolution''' is a not-for-profit global movement with teams in over 100 countries around the world. Fashion Revolution campaigns for systemic reform of the [[fashion]] industry with a focus on the need for greater [[Transparency (trade)|transparency]] in the fashion [[supply chain]]. Fashion Revolution has designated the anniversary of the [[Rana Plaza]] disaster in [[Bangladesh]] as Fashion Revolution Day. In 2014, 2015, 2016 and 2017 millions of people around the world called on brands to answer the question Who Made My Clothes? The [[hashtag]] #whomademyclothes became the no.1 global trend on [[Twitter]].<ref>{{cite magazine |last=Muzaffar |first=Zareen |date=27 April 2015 |title=2 Years Later, Bangladesh's Rana Plaza Debacle Continues to Resonate Globally |url=http://thediplomat.com/2015/04/2-years-later-bangladeshs-rana-plaza-debacle-continues-to-resonate-globally/ |magazine=The Diplomat}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Dearden |first=Lizzie |date=24 April 2015 |title=Fashion Revolution Day: #whomademyclothes campaign remembers Rana Plaza disaster |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/fashion/news/fashion-revolution-day-whomademyclothes-campaign-remembers-rana-plaza-disaster-10201871.html |newspaper=The Independent |location=London}}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine |last=Ayre |first=Josie |date=24 April 2015 |title=It's Fashion Revolution Day! Here's Why It's So Important To Know Where Our Clothes Are Made...|url=http://www.marieclaire.co.uk/news/549144/fashion-revolution-day-2015-carry-somers-interview.html |magazine=Marie Claire}}</ref>
==History== Fashion Revolution was created in 2013 in response to the Rana Plaza disaster in Bangladesh by [[Carry Somers]] and Orsola de Castro. Somers and De Castro had worked as [[fashion designers]] in the UK for over two decades and saw that the factory collapse could act as a catalyst for change in the industry.
==Fashion Revolution Day / Fashion Revolution Week== Fashion Revolution Day takes place annually on 24 April, the anniversary of the [[2013 Savar building collapse|2013 Rana Plaza building collapse]] when 1133 died and over 2500 were injured. In 2016, it expanded into Fashion Revolution Week.
The first Fashion Revolution Day took place on 24 April 2014. Fashion Revolution's hashtag #insideout was the no. 1 global trend on Twitter.<ref>http://www.oxfam.org.uk/education/education-blog/2015/03/fashion-revolution-day</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Hepburn |first=Stephanie |date=14 April 2015 |title=Can a hashtag change the fashion industry? |url=https://www.theguardian.com/sustainable-business/sustainable-fashion-blog/2015/apr/14/can-a-hashtag-change-the-fashion-industry |newspaper=The Guardian}}</ref>
The second Fashion Revolution Day took place on 24 April 2015. The global reach from online news and broadcast media was 16.5 billion and 63 million people from across 76 countries made the hashtag #WhoMadeMyClothes the number one trend on Twitter<ref>{{cite web |url=http://bkaccelerator.com/is-social-media-traceabilitys-new-superman/ |title=Is Social Media Traceability’s New Superman? |date=29 July 2015 |website=Brooklyn Fashion + Design Accelerator}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://stylebubble.co.uk/style_bubble/2015/05/grappling-with-the-true-cost.html |title=Grappling with the True Cost |website=Style Bubble |type=Blog}}</ref> The [[YouTube]] video [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KfANs2y_frk The 2 Euro T-Shirt - A Social Experiment] had over 6.5 million views and won a [[Cannes Lions International Festival of Creativity|Cannes Lions]] award<ref>{{cite press release |title=Ketchum, Fashion Revolution and BBDO Group Germany Win Bronze PR Lion at Cannes Lions International Festival of Creativity |url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/ketchum-fashion-revolution-and-bbdo-group-germany-win-bronze-pr-lion-at-cannes-lions-international-festival-of-creativity-300104161.html |agency=PR Newswire}}</ref>
In its third year, Fashion Revolution activities took place over a week, from 18–24 April 2016. This first Fashion Revolution Week began with Fashion Question Time at the UK [[Houses of Parliament]].<ref>http://www.marycreagh.com/fashion_question_time_in_parliament</ref> and the launch of the first edition of the Fashion Transparency Index which scored 40 of the biggest global fashion companies on the information they disclose to stakeholders and the public about social and environmental issues across their supply chains.<ref>http://fashionrevolution.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/FR_FashionTransparencyIndex.pdf</ref><ref>http://www.ethicalconsumer.org/ethicalcampaigns/fashionrevolution.aspx</ref><ref>http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/entry/fashion-transparency-index_uk_5714b1c7e4b0f22f0219cbd0</ref>
In 2016's Fashion Revolution Week, events took place in over 90 countries around the world. Over 70,000 people around the world asked brands #whomademyclothes with 156 million impressions of the hashtag on social media. [[G-Star Raw]], [[American Apparel]], [[Fat Face]], [[Boden (clothing)|Boden]], [[Massimo Dutti]], [[Zara (retailer)|Zara]] and [[Warehouse (clothing)|Warehouse]] were among more than 1200 fashion brands and retailers that responded with photographs of their workers saying #imadeyourclothes.<ref>https://sourcingjournalonline.com/1000-brands-retailers-respond-fashion-revolution-challenge/</ref> Fashion Revolution achieved online media reach in April 2016 of 22 billion.<ref>http://fashionrevolution.org/about/2016-impact/</ref><ref>http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/entry/fashion-revolution-transparency-index_uk_57cedaa6e4b09f5b5e37d4fd</ref>
On 26 October 2016, Fashion Revolution's [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KfANs2y_frk €2 video, A Social Experiment] was ranked no. 7 in the top global PR campaigns of the year at the Global Sabre Awards ceremony.<ref>http://www.fox19.com/story/33501533/ketchum-and-its-clients-win-two-global-sabre-awards</ref><ref>http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/ketchum-and-its-clients-win-two-global-sabre-awards-300353106.html</ref> The video has received over 7.5 million views.
In its fourth year, Fashion Revolution Week took place from 24–30 April 2017. On Fashion Revolution Day, the second edition of the [https://issuu.com/fashionrevolution/docs/fr_fashiontransparencyindex2017 Fashion Transparency Index] was launched, a review of 100 of the biggest global fashion brands and retailers ranked according to how much they disclose about their social and environmental policies, practices and impact.<ref>https://www.reuters.com/video/2017/04/25/no-fashion-brand-is-fully-transparent-re?videoId=371549837</ref><ref>http://spendmatters.com/2017/05/02/fashion-transparency-index-2017-released-favorite-brands-rank/</ref> 66,000 people attended around 1000 Fashion Revolution events and there were 533 million impressions of social media posts using one of Fashion Revolution's hashtags during April and over 2000 brands and producer groups responded, answering #imadeyourclothes.<ref>http://fashionrevolution.org/about/2017-impact/</ref><ref>http://www.voice-online.co.uk/article/two-million-people-supported-fashion-revolution-week</ref>
In its fifth year, Fashion Revolution Week will take place from 23–29 April 2018.
==Events== During Fashion Revolution Week, hundreds of events take place around the world (and are posted online [https://www.fashionrevolution.org/events/ here]). Fashion Revolution has also organised high level roundtable events on [[ethics]], [[sustainability]] and transparency in the fashion industry.
12 May 2014: Roundtable Debate in UK [[House of Lords]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://sustainable-fashion.com/blog/roundtable-debate/ |title=Roundtable debate |date=19 May 2014 |website=Sustainable Fashion}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.iosh.co.uk/News/Fatal-factory-collapse-must-be-wake-up-call-to-improve-health-and-safety-of-supply-chain-workers.aspx |title=Fatal factory collapse must be wake-up call to improve health and safety of supply chain workers |website=Institution of Occupational Safety and Health}}</ref>
26 February 2015: Fashion Question Time in the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|UK House of Commons]] with [[Mary Creagh]] MP, [[Lily Cole]], Jenny Holdcroft, policy director of [[IndustriALL Global Union]] Catarina Midby, Global Head of Sustainable Communications, [[H&M]] Dilys Williams, Head, Centre for Sustainable Fashion, and [[Anas Sarwar]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://fashionrevolution.org/fashion-question-time-at-the-houses-of-parliament/ |title=Fashion Question Time at the Houses of Parliament |website=Fashion Revolution}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.impossible.com/lily-speaks-at-fashion-question-time-at-the-houses-of-parliament/ |title=Lily speaks at Fashion Question Time at the Houses of Parliament |website=[[impossible.com]]}}</ref>
29 June 2015: Ethical Fashion 2020: a New Vision for Transparency in UK [[House of Lords]].<ref>{{cite magazine |last=Whale |first=Sebastian |date=6 July 2015 |title=IOSH discussion: Towards Ethical Fashion 2020 |url=http://www.totalpolitics.com/features/450361/iosh-discussion-towards-ethical-fashion-2020.thtml |magazine=[[Total Politics]]}}</ref>
2 December 2015: EU roundtable and launch of White Paper on transparency 'It's Time for a Fashion Revolution' in Brussels.<ref>http://fashionrevolution.org/fashion-revolution-launches-white-paper-on-transparency-in-fashion-supply-chain/</ref>
18 April 2016: Fashion Question Time at the Houses of Parliament.<ref>http://www.marycreagh.com/fashion_question_time_in_parliament</ref><ref>http://fashionrevolution.org/fashion-question-time-at-the-house-of-commons/</ref>
During Fashion Revolution Week 2017, 1000 events took place around the country including Fashion Question Time at the Houses of Parliament on 24 April<ref>http://francescorner.com/2017/04/fashion-question-time/</ref> and the launch of Open Studios, a week-long series of events across London, New York, Athens, Prato in Italy, LA and Jakarta.<ref>http://metro.co.uk/2017/04/18/fashion-revolution-announce-their-first-open-studios-as-part-of-whomademyclothes-campaign-6581932/</ref>
==Fashion Revolution publications & podcasts== Fashion Revolution publishes online a [https://www.fashionrevolution.org/resources/free-downloads/ variety of campaign assets], posters, brand guidelines, postcard and letter writing templates, and action kits (for citizens, brands, wholesalers, retailers, distributors, farmers, producers and factories). In addition, it has published the following:
''How to be a Fashion Revolutionary''(2015) which is 'full of inspiration and ideas about how you can use your voice and your power to transform the fashion industry as we know it'. This is available in [https://www.fashionrevolution.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/HowToBeAFashionRevolutionary.pdf English], [https://www.fashionrevolution.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/HowToBeAFashionRevolutionary_Spanish.pdf Spanish] and [https://www.fashionrevolution.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/How-to-be-a-Fash-Revolutionary_portuguese.pdf Portuguese] and was published as part of a touring Fashion Revolution exhibition and film screenings at UK universities.
''It's Time for a Fashion Revolution'' (2015) sets out the need for more transparency across the fashion industry, from seed to waste. This is available in [http://fashionrevolution.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/FashRev_Whitepaper_Dec2015_screen.pdf English] and [http://fashionrevolution.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/FashRev_Whitepaper_Dec2015_Spanish.pdf Spanish].
''Fashion Transparency Index'' (2016 & 2017) ranks the biggest global fashion companies (40 in 2016, 100 in 2017) according to their level of transparency based on a questionnaire and publicly available information about supply chain issues. The 2016 Index - published in collaboration with Ethical Consumer - is available in [http://www.ethicalconsumer.org/portals/0/downloads/fr_fashiontransparencyindex.pdf English] and [https://www.fashionrevolution.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/03/FashionTransparencyIndex2016_ES_Light.pdf Spanish], and the 2017 Index is available in [https://issuu.com/fashionrevolution/docs/fr_fashiontransparencyindex2017?e=25766662/47726047 English], [http://issuu.com/fashionrevolution/docs/fr_fashiontransparencyindex2017_esp?e=25766662/49239838 Spanish] and [http://issuu.com/fashionrevolution/docs/fr_indice_2017?e=25766662/55612348 Portuguese].
[https://www.fashionrevolution.org/resources/fanzine/ ''Money, Fashion, Power''] (2017) is a zine which comprising 72-pages of poetry, illustration, photography, graphic design and editorial exploring the hidden stories behind our clothing, what the price we pay for fashion means, and how our purchasing power can make a positive difference. Collectible hard copies could be purchased and a free digital version was published online.
[https://www.fashionrevolution.org/resources/fanzine2/ ''Loved Clothes Last''] (2017) is a zine comprising 124 pages of poetry, illustration, photography, infographics, and packed with articles, tips and interviews exploring the issue of waste and mass-consumption in the fashion industry, and hopes to inspire you to buy less, care more, and know how to make the clothes you love last for longer. Collectible hard copies could be purchased and a free digital version was published online.
[https://www.fashionrevolution.org/resources/listen-to-the-fashion-revolution-podcast/ ''Fashion Revolution Podcast''] series (2017) comprises three 27 minute recordings in which international fashion journalist Tamsin Blanchard speaks to researchers, supply chain experts, garment workers, politicians and activists about the intersection of sustainability, ethics and transparency in the fashion industry.
''Garment Worker Diaries'' (2017–18) is a project by Microfinance Opportunities in collaboration with Fashion Revolution which, over 12 months, visited the same set of garment workers in Bangladesh, India and Cambodia to 'learn what they could earn and buy, how they spend their time each day, and what their working conditions are like'.<ref>http://workerdiaries.org/#about-id</ref> Its [http://workerdiaries.org/garment-worker-diaries-reports/ (interactive) research reports and podcast] are written to 'advocate for changes in consumer and corporate behaviours and policy changes that improve the living and working conditions of garment workers everywhere'.<ref>http://workerdiaries.org/#about-id</ref>
== Haulternative Campaign == The #Haulternative campaign, in conjunction with the ''[[Daily Telegraph]]'', features fashion [[vloggers]] filming themselves doing an alternative fashion haul.<ref>{{cite news |last=Blanchard |first=Tamsin |date=24 April 2015 |title=Best of the high street's collections |url=http://fashion.telegraph.co.uk/article/TMG11536174/Fashion-Revolution-Day-Youtube-haulers-get-ethical-with-haulternative-campaign.html |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150421043015/http://fashion.telegraph.co.uk/article/TMG11536174/Fashion-Revolution-Day-Youtube-haulers-get-ethical-with-haulternative-campaign.html |archivedate=21 April 2015}}</ref> Haulers who participated included [[CutiePieMarzia]] Noodlerella, Bip Ling, [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3Kbr-pnXD4A Grav3yardgirl] and [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8m_5Wo17-fM Shameless Maya] with combined views of 2 million on [[YouTube]].
== Schools, colleges and universities == In 2014, Fashion Revolution published a quiz and an education pack for school, college and university teachers and students. These were freely available online.
In 2015, a new quiz and separate education worksheets were produced for primary schools (7–11 years), secondary schools (11–16 years), further education colleges (16–18 years) and universities (18+).<ref>{{cite web |url=https://europa.eu/eyd2015/en/fashion-revolution/posts/be-curious-find-out-do-something |title=Be curious. Find out. Do something. |last1=Cook |first1=Ian |website=European Year for Development |accessdate=9 August 2016}}</ref> These were published in English and translated into Spanish, Finnish and other languages by Country Coordination teams.
To encourage students to 'Be curious, Find Out, Do something' about #whomademyclothes, these worksheets continue to be developed and now include : * 'Introduction to Fashion Revolution PowerPoint' (Primary - Universities) * 'Design a Fashion Revolution Poster' (Primary - Universities), * 'What can I find out about my clothes?' (Primary), * 'Where are my clothes made?' (Primary), * 'Write to the person who made my clothes' (Primary), * 'Research my clothes and write to the brand' (Secondary - FE), * 'Fashion Revolution Trump Card Game' (Secondary - Universities), * 'What my jeans say about the garment industry' (Secondary - Universities) * 'Take a selfie and send it to the brand' (Secondary - University), * 'Fashion Revolution Annual Quiz' (Primary - Universities) and * 'Tableau Vivant' (Universities).
In July 2015, a collection of social media postings showing [https://uk.pinterest.com/fashrevglobal/education/ how teachers and students got involved the Fashion Revolution] was published on [[Pinterest]], along with a [https://www.pinterest.com/fashrevglobal/film-library/ 'who made my clothes?' film library], and a collection of [https://www.pinterest.com/fashrevglobal/do-something/ 'imaginative ways in which the work of artists, activists and others can be used to inspire and engage people in the Fashion Revolution']. These continue to be updated.
In August 2016, three sessions were organised at the Annual Conference of the [[Royal Geographical Society|Royal Geographical Society (with Institute of British Geographers)]] conference in London with academic and activist speakers talking to the theme of "Scholar activism and the Fashion Revolution: ‘who made my clothes?’" Session one focused on [http://conference.rgs.org/AC2016/157 connecting producers and consumers], session two on [http://conference.rgs.org/AC2016/191 slow sustainable fashion in practice] and session three on [http://conference.rgs.org/AC2016/225 engaging publics].
In June–July 2017, a free 3 week online course called [https://www.futurelearn.com/courses/who-made-my-clothes 'Who Made My Clothes'] was created in collaboration with the [[University of Exeter]]. Run by and featuring members of Fashion Revolution's Global Coordination Team - Ian Cook, Orsola de Castro, Sarah Ditty and Joss Whipple - it encouraged over 8,000 learners worldwide to Be Curious, Find Out and Do Something about the pay and conditions of people working in the global garment industry. The course will run again in June–July 2018.
==External links== * [http://fashionrevolution.org/ Fashion Revolution website]

revision.comment: Robot - Moving category Business organisations in Switzerland‎ to [[:Category:Business organisations based in Switzerland‎]] per [[WP:CFD|CFD]] at [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/Log/2017 April 2]].
revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{Underlinked|date=September 2014}} {{Unreferenced|date=March 2011}} }}
The '''Federation of the Swiss Watch Industry FH''', with its headquarters in [[Biel/Bienne|Bienne]], is the [[Swiss watch]] industry's leading trade association.
Acting as a private, professional and non-profit oriented association, the FH currently gathers more than 500 members representing more than 90% of all Swiss watch manufacturers ([[watches]], [[clocks]], movements, components, etc.).
On one hand, the FH provides its members with a large series of services in the fields of legal, economic and commercial issues. On the other hand, it acts as a privileged counterparts for the authorities, the media and the public in general, both in Switzerland and in the world.

{{Infobox theatre | name = Film Streams' Ruth Sokolof Theater | native_name = | native_name_lang = | image = Film Streams marquis.jpg | image_size = 220 | image_alt = | image_map = | map_caption = | pushpin_map = | pushpin_map_caption = | address = 1340 Mike Fahey Street | city = [[Omaha, Nebraska]] | country = United States | designation = | coordinates = {{coord|41.26617|-95.93428|type:landmark|display=inline}} | architect = Alley Poyner Macchietto Architecture | owner = | tenant = | operator =Film Streams | capacity = 206, 96 | type = [[Art house]] | opened = July 27, 2007 | reopened = | yearsactive = 2007 to present | rebuilt = | closed = | demolished = | othernames = Ruth Sokolof Theater | production = | currentuse = | website = {{URL|http://www.filmstreams.org/}} }}
'''Film Streams''' is a nonprofit arts organization in [[Omaha, Nebraska]]<ref name=NPR-CreativeBoom-2011>{{cite web|last=Davidson|first=Adam|title=The Indie-Rock Club Behind Omaha's $100 Million Creative Boom|url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/money/2011/06/06/136896920/the-indie-rock-club-behind-omahas-100-million-creative-boom|work=NPR's Morning Edition. Planet Money: The Economy Explained|publisher=National Public Radio (NPR)|accessdate=14 November 2013|format=Audio story and interview|date=June 3, 2011}}</ref> that oversees two cinemas: the Ruth Sokolof Theater, in North Downtown Omaha, and the historic [[Dundee Theatre|Dundee Theater]], Omaha’s longest surviving neighborhood cinema.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://filmstreams.org/about|title=Film Streams — About|last=Shapes|first=Justin Kemerling and Human|date=2017-11-15|website=Film Streams|language=en-us|access-date=2017-11-15}}</ref> It receives funding from corporate and individual donors, members, and the government.<ref name="OmahaCityWeekly-2007">{{cite web|last=Krainak|first=Michael Joe|title=Meet Rachel Jacobson, Omaha’s Movie Maven, founder & director of Film Streams, the city’s first non-profit indie cinema venue|url=http://omahacityweekly.com/article.php?id=2971|work=Omaha City Weekly|accessdate=14 November 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927231839/http://omahacityweekly.com/article.php?id=2971|archivedate=September 27, 2007}}</ref><ref name="Metro-LABiga-Jacobson">{{cite web|last=Biga|first=Leo Adam|title=Living the Dream: Cinema Maven Rachel Jacobson – the Woman Behind Film Streams|url=http://leoadambiga.wordpress.com/2012/02/01/living-the-dream-cinema-maven-rachel-jacobson-the-woman-behind-film-streams/|work=Metro Magazine|accessdate=14 November 2013|date=February 2012}}</ref><ref name="SiliconPrairie-Jacobson">{{cite news|last=Schreiber|first=Danny|title=Nebraska Film: Rachel Jacobson of Film Streams|url=http://www.siliconprairienews.com/2010/08/nebraska-film-rachel-jacobson-of-film-streams|accessdate=14 November 2013|newspaper=Silicon Prairie News|date=August 9, 2010|format=Part of a series titled Nebraska Film: An Exploration of the Growing Community}}</ref>
==History== Founded by Rachel Jacobson in 2005, Film Streams' mission is to enhance the cultural environment of the Omaha-Council Bluffs area through the presentation and discussion of film as an art form.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://filmstreams.org/mission-history|title=Film Streams — Mission & History|last=Shapes|first=Justin Kemerling and Human|date=2017-11-15|website=Film Streams|language=en-us|access-date=2017-11-15}}</ref>
In July 2007, Film Streams opened the Ruth Sokolof Theater, a new two-screen cinema in [[downtown Omaha]]'s North Downtown ([[NoDo]]) area,<ref name="NYTimes-Omaha-TrainYards">{{cite news|last=Davila|first=Stephanie|title=SURFACING; In Omaha, From Train Yards to Playground|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9502E2DB133EF93AA25755C0A9679D8B63|accessdate=14 November 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=June 19, 2011}}</ref> within a development anchored by internationally acclaimed music label [[Saddle Creek Records]].<ref name="NYT-2008">{{cite news|last=Konigsberg|first=Eric|title=When Omaha Met Cinema|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/03/16/movies/16koen.html|accessdate=14 November 2013|date=March 16, 2008|work=The New York Times}}</ref><ref name="NYT-Omax-Culture-2007">{{cite news|last=Andersen|first=Kurt|title=Omaha’s Culture Club|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/03/25/travel/tmagazine/03talk.omaha.t.html|accessdate=14 November 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=March 25, 2007}}</ref> In February 2016, Film Streams announced that [[Susan Alice Buffett|Susie Buffett]]'s Sherwood Foundation had donated the 92-year-old Dundee Theater to the organization.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.omaha.com/go/arts/sherwood-foundation-will-donate-dundee-theater-to-film-streams-with/article_8d1169bd-5624-5588-983b-8ec7b68fd6a0.html|title=Sherwood Foundation will donate Dundee Theater to Film Streams, with spotlight on 2018 reopening|last=writer|first=Micah Mertes / World-Herald staff|work=Omaha.com|access-date=2017-11-15|language=en}}</ref> The organization launched a public capital campaign in April 2017 with the intention of renovating and reopening the cinema by 2018.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.omaha.com/go/movies/film-streams-nears-million-fundraising-goal-for-dundee-theater-renovations/article_97c86342-aa18-5c17-8ef0-654ae796f148.html|title=Film Streams nears $8.3 million fundraising goal for Dundee Theater renovations|last=writer|first=Micah Mertes / World-Herald staff|work=Omaha.com|access-date=2017-11-15|language=en}}</ref>
The name "Film Streams" is inspired by Omaha (the word means "above all others on a stream") and the [[John Cassavetes]] film, ''[[Love Streams (film)|Love Streams]].''<ref name="FS-FAQ">{{cite web|title=Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ)|url=http://filmstreams.org/filmstreams_about_faq.asp|work=Film Streams|accessdate=14 November 2013}}</ref>
==The Ruth Sokolof Theater== The Ruth Sokolof Theater has two auditoriums with 35-millimeter platter and reel-to-reel projection capabilities.<ref name="NYT-2008" /> The larger theater seats 206 and runs first run feature films. The smaller theater seats 96 and shows a selection of classic films, retrospectives, and other films.<ref name="OmahaCityWeekly-2007" /> Film Streams has [[DVD]], [[Blu-ray]], and digital high-definition projection.
Rachel Jacobson founded Films Streams by joining with [[Saddle Creek Records]], the indie record label based in Omaha, to build a mini-campus in a deserted downtown Omaha area.<ref name=OWH-FS-Money-2013>{{cite news|last=Soderlin|first=Barbara|title=Film Streams vies for starring role in Omaha entertainment scene|url=http://www.omaha.com/article/20130421/MONEY/704219945/1694|accessdate=14 November 2013|newspaper=Omaha World-Herald|date=April 22, 2013|location=Money}}</ref> The block that is home to Film Streams also houses the Saddle Creek headquarters and [[Slowdown (venue)|Slowdown]], a rock club the label operates.<ref name=NYT-2008/><ref name=WNYC-Lehrer>{{cite web|last=Lehrer|first=Brian|title=Knowing When to Quit Is Half of Winning|url=http://www.wnyc.org/story/23458-knowing-when-to-quit-is-half-of-winning/|work=The Brian Lehrer Show|publisher=WNYC|accessdate=14 November 2013|format=Audio story|date=April 13, 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=DiGiacomo|first=Danielle|title=On the Margins of the Multiplex: Young visionaries bring indie cinemas to small cities|url=http://www.aivf.org/independent/current/0605digiacomohalf.html|work=The Independent|publisher=The Association of Independent Video and Filmmakers (AIVF)|accessdate=14 November 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060625034124/http://www.aivf.org/independent/current/0605digiacomohalf.html|archivedate=June 25, 2006|date=May–June 2006}}</ref><ref name=Hemisphere>{{cite web|title=Asserting Their Style |url=http://www.hemispheresmagazine.com/insight/pdfs/omaha/179_187.pdf |work=Hemisphere Magazine |date=May 2006 |accessdate=14 November 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928051342/http://www.hemispheresmagazine.com/insight/pdfs/omaha/179_187.pdf |archivedate=September 28, 2007 }}</ref>
===Ruth Sokolof=== Film Streams' North Downtown Omaha cinema is named after Ruth Sokolof, née Rosinsky (1925-1982), a well-known educator in Omaha who focused her life on helping children with disabilities.<ref name=RuthSokoloff>{{cite web|title=About Film Streams: About Ruth Sokolof (1925-1982)|url=http://www.filmstreams.org/filmstreams_about_cinema_project.asp|work=Film Streams|accessdate=14 November 2013}}</ref> With her husband, Phil,<ref name=NYT-PhilSokolof-obit>{{cite news|last=Saxon|first=Wolfgang|title=Phil Sokolof, 82, a Crusader Against Cholesterol, Is Dead|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/04/17/us/phil-sokolof-82-a-crusader-against-cholesterol-is-dead.html|accessdate=14 November 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=April 17, 2004}}</ref><ref name=JewishFed-PhilGift>{{cite web|last=Sherman|first=Claudia|title=Foundation Receives $3 Million Gift From Sokolof Estate|url=http://omaha.ujcfedweb.org/page.aspx?id=104528|work=The Jewish Federation of Omaha|publisher=The Jewish Federations of North America, Inc.|accessdate=14 November 2013|date=April 29, 2005}}</ref> many education-based scholarships are awarded in their name each year to Omaha-area students and educators.<ref name=JewishFed-SokolofScholarships>{{cite web|last=Henthorn|first=Janet|title=Foundation Announces Sokolof Scholarship Applications Available|url=http://omaha.ujcfedweb.org/page.aspx?id=108878|work=The Jewish Federation of Omaha|publisher=The Jewish Federations of North America, Inc.|accessdate=14 November 2013}}</ref><ref name=JewishFed-SokolofTeachers>{{cite web|last=Sherman|first=Claudia|title=Nominations Sought for Sokolof Teacher’s Award|url=http://omaha.ujcfedweb.org/page.aspx?id=98144|work=The Jewish Federation of Omaha|publisher=The Jewish Federations of North America, Inc.|accessdate=14 November 2013}}</ref>
== The Dundee Theater == Film Streams announced plans to renovate and reopen Omaha's longest-running cinema in February 2016. When opened, it will feature two screens: the historic 300-seat main house and a new 25-seat microcinema.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.omaha.com/go/revamped-dundee-theater-could-open-sooner-than-expected/article_faf29ade-56bb-5920-be33-333f67a91bbc.html|title=Revamped Dundee Theater could open sooner than expected|last=writer|first=Micah Mertes / World-Herald staff|work=Omaha.com|access-date=2017-11-15|language=en}}</ref> The lobby will also house Kitchen Table Central, a second location of a popular [[farm-to-table]] restaurant.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.omaha.com/eedition/sunrise/articles/kitchen-table-is-tapped-for-dundee/article_159dfdd7-a785-57f5-9ec5-fc9bf95c0765.html|title=Kitchen Table is tapped for Dundee|last=WRITER|first=MICAH MERTESWORLD-HERALD STAFF|work=Omaha.com|access-date=2017-11-15|language=en}}</ref>
==Programming== Film Streams offers screenings of first-run films and a selection of retrospectives and classic films; education programs, and community development programs.<ref name=FS-Annual-2012>{{cite web|title=Film Streams Annual Report 2012|url=http://news.filmstreams.org/wp-content/uploads/2013/03/Film-Streams_Annual-Report_2012.pdf|work=Film Streams|accessdate=14 November 2013}}</ref> Programming includes: * [[First run (film)|First run films]]: New American independents, documentaries, and international films making their theatrical premieres in Omaha and the surrounding region. * Repertory Series: Classic films, themed series, director retrospectives, and revivals celebrating the history and cultural spectrum of film as art ** Alexander Payne Presents: Curated repertory series by director [[Alexander Payne]] ** Forever Young Family & Children Series ** The Met: Live in HD: Presented in collaboration with [[Opera Omaha]] * Community Development: Collaborative screenings with other nonprofit organizations, using film as a catalyst for important conversations about our community and the world around us. * Education: Year-round film-education opportunities for all ages. ** Daytime screenings for visiting classes: High School curriculum support ** Student night at the Ruth Sokolof Theater: First Monday of every month free for full-time students * Special Programs: Q&As with visiting filmmakers, live musical performances to silent classics, an annual Local Filmmakers Showcase.
