{{advert|date=February 2017}} {{Infobox model | name = Fitria Yusuf | image = Fitria Yusuf 20100115.jpg | image_size = 250px | alt = | caption = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | birth_name = Fitria Yusuf Hamka | birth_date ={{birth date and age|1982|12|09}} | birth_place = [[Jakarta]], [[Indonesia]] | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | residence = | nationality = Indonesian | other_names = Fifi | ethnicity = | citizenship = | alma_mater =GS Fame Institute of Business (2006)
[[Menlo College]] (2001) | occupation = | years_active = | known_for = | spouse = | partner = | children = | parents = | relatives = | height = {{convert|1.67|m|ft|abbr=on}} | hair_color = Dark brown | eye_color = Dark brown | agency = | module = | website = {{URL|fitriayusuf.com}} }} '''Fitria "Fifi" Yusuf''' (born 9 December 1982{{cite web | url=http://www.indonesiatatler.com/tatler-list/500list/fitria-yusuf | title=Fitria Yusuf - The 500 list | publisher=Indonesia Tatler | accessdate=24 September 2016}}) is an Indonesian socialite and fashion model.{{cite news | url=http://wolipop.detik.com/read/2013/01/15/170614/2142909/1133/fitria-yusuf-penyuka-dunia-fashion-yang-mahir-menulis | title=Fitria Yusuf, Penyuka Dunia Fashion yang Mahir Menulis | work=detik.com | date=15 January 2015 | accessdate=27 September 2016 | language=id}} == Life and career == Yusuf was born in [[Jakarta]], Indonesia on December 9, 1982. In her childhood she moved to [[Australia]] and attended [[St Hilda's Anglican School for Girls]] in [[Perth, Western Australia|Perth]]. She graduated from [[Menlo College]] in 2001 and holds a bachelor's degree in [[Bachelor of Business Administration#BSBA|business administration]] majoring in Marketing from GS Fame Institute of Business in Jakarta. Fitria’s aptitude of fashion began from her childhood, liked flipping through her mother’s magazines, lingering over the fashion pages and all the models posing in colorful clothes. She had worked as an editor for a number of fashion magazines in Jakarta and a columnist of [[Eve (magazine)|''Eve'']] magazine{{cite news | title=Little Pink Book, a guide for the stylish shopaholic| url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2009/09/06/little-pink-book039-a-guide-stylish-shopaholic.html | work=[[The Jakarta Post]] | date=6 September 2009 | accessdate=24 September 2016}} before starting her own business, opening a [[One stop shop|one-stop shopping]] boutique called Ivy boutique in 2006.{{cite web|title=GS Fame Alumni - Fashion Entrepreneur|url=http://www.gsfame.ac.id/alumni/2009/200912235020.asp|publisher=GS Fame Institute of Business|accessdate=24 September 2016}} She also co-founded Twinkle-Twinkle in 2009, a company producing customized crystal casings for smart phones.{{cite news | url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2013/02/24/fitria-yusuf-adventurous-inside.html | title=Fitria Yusuf: Adventurous on the inside | work=[[The Jakarta Post]] | date=24 February 2013 | accessdate=24 September 2016}}{{cite news | url=http://www.fimela.com/lifestyle-relationship/kombinasi-bisnis-dan-fashion-ala-fitria-yusuf-110812o-page1.html | title=Business Combinations and Fashion style of Fitria Yusuf | work=Fimela.com | date=12 August 2011 | accessdate=25 September 2016}} === Writings === In 2009, Fitria Yusuf co-authored ''Little Pink Book: Jakarta Style & Shopping Guide'' with her friend Alexandra Dewi. The book is like a shopping directory for fashion lovers, where she shared her experience combining style and shopping, providing practical information about international and local brand. it contains eight chapters: lingerie, apparel, bags, shoes, jewelry, watches, sunglasses and one-stop shopping.{{cite news | url=http://travel.kompas.com/read/2009/08/20/14015822/little.pink.book.panduan.shopping.dan.direktori.berbusana | title=Little Pink Book: A Guide for "Shopping" and Directory Dressed | work=Kompas TV | date=20 August 2009 | accessdate=27 September 2016}} In 2011, Fitria co-authored another fashion-themed book called ''Hermes Temptation''.{{cite book|last1=Yusuf|first1=Fitria|last2=Dewi|first2=Alexandra|title=Hermes Temptation|publisher=Gramedia Pustaka Utama|isbn=9789792277630|url=https://www.amazon.com/Hermes-Temptation-Ms-Fitria-Yusuf/dp/9792277633/|accessdate=24 September 2016|language=English}}{{cite web | url=http://femaledaily.com/blog/2011/12/07/hermes-temptation-the-story-of-hermes-bags-reseller/ | title=Hermes Temptation, The Story of Hermes Bags Reseller | date=7 December 2012 | accessdate=25 September 2016}} The 400-page book tells the story of a million-dollar resell business of French luxury-bags brand [[Hermès]] which became "a must-have item" among the high society in Jakarta.{{cite news|last1=Grudgings|first1=Stuart|last2=Paramaditha|first2=Andjarsari|title=Analysis: IndoneAnalysis: Indonesia's rich bulge on commodities boom leaves many behindsia's rich bulge on commodities boom leaves many behind|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/us-indonesia-wealthy-idUSBRE82B0MP20120312|date=March 2, 2012|accessdate=September 26, 2016|work=[[Reuters]]}}{{cite web | url=http://jakartaglobe.beritasatu.com/archive/hermes-temptation-takes-hold-in-jakarta/ | title=Hermes Temptation Takes Hold in Jakarta | work=Jakarta Globe | accessdate=25 September 2016}} The book became a national best-seller and had been printed in Indonesia and in the United States.{{cite news | url=https://gaya.tempo.co/read/news/2013/11/08/110528012/skandal-atut-fitria-yusuf-hermes-fenomena-sosial | title=Skandal Atut, Fitria Yusuf: Hermes Fenomena Sosial | work=tempo.co | date=8 November 2013 | accessdate=27 September 2016}} === Corporate career === In 2009, Fitria was appointed as a commissioner of PT Mitra International Resources Tbk, a mining services company and worked there until 2011.{{cite news | url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2010/01/05/fitria-yusuf-indonesia039s-fashionista.html | title=Fitria Yusuf: Indonesia's fashionista | work=[[The Jakarta Post]] | date=5 January 2010 | accessdate=24 September 2016}}{{cite news|title=Analysis: Indonesia's rich bulge on commodities boom leaves many behind|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-indonesia-wealthy-idUSBRE82B0MP20120312|accessdate=24 September 2016|work=[[Reuters]]|date=12 March 2012}} From 2012 to 2013, she served as the Editor In Chief of Aesthetic Beauty Guide Indonesia and Chief Executive Officer of PT Fifefa International Jakarta since 2011.{{cite web | url=http://quotes.wsj.com/ID/CMNP/company-people/executive-profile/43333780 | title=Fitria Yusuf - Citra Marga Nusaphala Persada | work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] | accessdate=27 September 2016}} In 2014, she focused in property and food & beverage business, openng Ozone Hotel & Eatery, in [[Pantai Indah Kapuk]], North Jakarta.{{cite news | url=http://travel.kompas.com/read/2015/04/27/130800727/Pilihan.Menginap.di.Kawasan.Pantai.Indah.Kapuk | title=Pilihan Menginap di Kawasan Pantai Indah Kapuk | work=Kompas TV | date=27 April 2015 | accessdate=27 September 2016 | language=id}} She involved in the family business, becoming Vice President Director of PT Citra Marga Nusaphala Persada Tbk. (CMNP) since October 2015.{{cite news | url=https://cantik.tempo.co/read/news/2016/07/15/335787765/fitria-yusuf-sosialita-fashion-penerus-bisnis-jalan-tol | title=Fitria Yusuf, Sosialita Fashion Penerus Bisnis Jalan Tol | work=Tempo (Indonesian magazine) | date=15 July 2016 | accessdate=27 September 2016}}{{cite news | url=http://swa.co.id/next-gen/fitria-yusuf-sosialita-penerus-cmnp | title=Fitria Yusuf, Sosialita Penerus CMNP | work=SWA Magazine | date=July 11, 2016 | accessdate=27 September 2016}} Previously, she served as independent commissioner at the toll road construction management company.{{cite web | url=http://uk.reuters.com/business/quotes/officerProfile?symbol=CMNP.JK&officerId=1742788 | title=Fitria Yusuf - Citra Marga Nusaphala Persada Tbk PT | work=[[Reuters]] | accessdate=27 September 2016}}{{cite news | url=http://wolipop.detik.com/read/2013/01/14/163951/2141730/1133/fitria-yusuf-sosialita-cantik-dengan-segudang-profesi | title=Fitria Yusuf, Sosialita Cantik dengan Segudang Profesi | work=detik.com | date=14 January 2013 | accessdate=27 September 2016 | language=id}} She is currently involved in a CSR program conducted CMNP and enforcement efforts under the expressway, as well as the provision of green open space.{{cite news | url=http://industri.bisnis.com/read/20160601/45/553682/cmnp-temukan-1.593-kendaraan-overload | title=CMNP Temukan 1.593 Kendaraan Overload | work=[[Bisnis Indonesia]] | date=1 June 2016 | accessdate=27 September 2016}} Yusuf was a speaker at Ideafest at Jakarta Convention Center (2016),{{cite journal|title=Resep Menjadi Content Creator Dari Seorang Fitria Yusuf|date=September 26, 2016|url=http://marketeers.com/resep-menjadi-content-creator-dari-seorang-fitria-yusuf/|accessdate=2 October 2016}}{{cite web|title=[IdeaFest 2016] Wajib Tahu! Tips Pencitraan Sosial Media ala Diana Rikasari dan Fitria Yusuf|url=http://rula.co.id/post/ideafest-2016-wajib-tahu-tips-pencitraan-sosial-media-ala-diana|accessdate=2 October 2016}} and appeared at Jakarta Fashion Week in 2009. == Awards and recognition == Fitria has been recognized by various media and company as a fashion icon including ''[[Tatler]]'' magazine, [[Senayan City]], [[Kuningan City]], Johnny Andrean Salon and [[HighEnd (magazine)|''HighEnd'']] magazine.{{cite news | url=http://archive.tabloidbintang.com/gaya-hidup/cantik-a-sehat/66105-perhelatan-fashion-akbar-tahunan-senayan-city-kembali-digelar.html | title=Perhelatan Fashion Akbar Tahunan Senayan City Kembali Digelar | date=11 April 2013 | accessdate=2 October 2016}}{{cite news | url=http://wolipop.detik.com/read/2012/11/29/125457/2104881/1141/kuningan-city-gelar-grand-opening-12-jam-non-stop | title=Kuningan City Gelar Grand Opening 12 Jam Non-stop | work=[[DetikCom]] | date=29 November 2012 | accessdate=27 September 2016 | language=id}} == References == {{Reflist|2}} == External links == {{DEFAULTSORT:Yusuf, Fitria}} [[Category:1982 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Jakarta]] [[Category:Indonesian female models]] [[Category:Indonesian writers]] [[Category:Indonesian businesspeople]] [[Category:Indonesian women in business]] [[Category:Indonesian Muslims]] [[Category:Indo people]] [[Category:Menlo College alumni]] [[Category:Indonesian expatriates in Australia]]

{{Infobox company |name = Global Arab Network (غلوبال اراب نتورك) |type = [[International organizations]], [[Business organizations]] |foundation = 2006 |location_city = [[London]] |location_country = [[UK]] |founder = |area_served = [[MENA]], Worldwide |key_people = [[Ghassan Ibrahim]](Editor in Chief) |industry = [[Business]] |num_employees = |homepage = [http://www.english.globalarabnetwork.com www.globalarabnetwork.co.uk] }}
'''Global Arab Network''' (GAN) (in [[Arabic]]<ref>http://www.globalarabnetwork.com/ - [[الشبكة العربية العالمية]] [[غلوبال عرب نتوورك]] [[غلوبال عرب نتورك]] [[غلوبل اراب نتوورك]] [[غلوبل عرب نتوورك]] [[جلوبال عرب نتوورك]]</ref> غلوبال اراب نتورك) is a comprehensive news and information service about the Arab world in English and Arabic, registered and based in [[London]], [[Great Britain|UK]].
Founded in 2006, GAN covers news and information from the Middle East and North Africa concerning national and international affairs, relations between the Arab countries and the rest of the world, economy and business, foreign policy, science and technology, culture and society, entertainment and lifestyle. ".<ref>http://arab-niaba.org/english/links/bytopic.asp?tid=6 - United Nations Development Programme [[UNDP]]- POGAR Programme ]</ref>
Global Arab Network is one of the Strategic Partners of The Middle East Association<ref>http://www.the-mea.co.uk - [[The Middle East Association]]</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.english.globalarabnetwork.com/ Global Arab Network (official homepage)]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Global Arab Network}} [[Category:Arab media]] [[Category:Digital newspapers published in Europe]] [[Category:International business]] [[Category:Business organisations based in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:London newspapers]] [[Category:Publications established in 2006]] [[Category:Arabic-language newspapers]]

{{Infobox company | key_people = | industry = construction, engineering, electrical cables, information technology, printing, media |products = | revenue = | operating_income = | assets = | num_employees = | company_logo = | company_type = [[Public company|Public]] | company_slogan = | foundation = | location = [[Dhaka]], [[Bangladesh]] | homepage = [http://www.globe-janakantha.com/ www.globe-janakantha.com] }}
'''Globe Janakantha Shilpa Paribar (GJSP)''' is one of the largest [[Bangladesh]]i [[conglomerate (company)|conglomerates]]. The industries under this conglomerate include construction, engineering, electrical cables, information technology, printing, media etc. It was founded in 1979 by Mohammad Shahidullah Khan eldest brother of current owner and chairman [[Mohammad Atikullah Khan]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://bdnews24.com/bangladesh/2016/03/28/supreme-court-orders-janakantha-editor-atiqullah-khan-masud-to-surrender-in-fraud-case|title=Supreme Court orders Janakantha editor Atiqullah Khan Masud to surrender in fraud case|newspaper=bdnews24.com|access-date=2016-10-29}}</ref>
Small, medium and large family owned businesses dominate over Bangladesh's $100 billion ($288 billion in PPP GDP) economy, which has been growing at over 5 percent a year since 1995.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/newDesign/news-details.php?nid=145603|title=Partex Group splits|date=2010-07-06|newspaper=The Daily Star|access-date=2016-10-29}}</ref>
==List of companies== * Globe Insecticides Ltd. * Globe Metal Complex Ltd. * Globe Cables Limited * [[Janakantha]], a popular daily newspaper in Bangladesh * Globe Khamar Prokalpa Ltd. * Globe Construction Ltd. * Globe Technologies Ltd.
==See also== * [[List of companies of Bangladesh]]
==References== <references/>
==External links== * [http://www.globe-janakantha.com/About.php GJSP corporate information]
[[Category:Media companies of Bangladesh]] [[Category:Manufacturing companies of Bangladesh]]
{{business-stub}}

'''Gross Enrollment Ratio''' ('''GER''') or '''Gross Enrollment Index''' ('''GEI''') is a [[statistics|statistical measure]] used in the [[education]] sector, and formerly by the [[UN]] in its [[Education Index]], to determine the number of students enrolled in school at several different grade levels (like elementary, middle school and high school), and use it to show the ratio of the number of students who live in that country to those who qualify for the particular grade level. The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization(UNESCO), describes ‘Gross Enrolment Ratio’ as the total enrolment within a country ‘in a specific level of education, regardless of age, expressed as a percentage of the population in the official age group corresponding to this level of education.’<ref>Official UN definition for GER</ref>
The GER can be over 100% as it includes students who may be older or younger than the official age group. For instance, the GER includes students who are repeating a grade, those who enrolled late and are older than their classmates, or those who have advanced quickly and are younger than their classmates. This allows the total enrollment to exceed the population that corresponds to that level of education.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://datahelpdesk.worldbank.org/knowledgebase/articles/114955-how-can-gross-school-enrollment-ratios-be-over-100|title=How can gross school enrollment ratios be over 100 percent? – World Bank Data Help Desk|website=datahelpdesk.worldbank.org|language=en|access-date=2018-01-30}}</ref>
== UN Human Development Index use==
A combined gross enrolment ratio (CGER), incorporating all three levels of education, was used to calculate the [[Human Development Index|Human Development Index (HDI)]], an annual [[measuring well-being|gauge of well-being]] for [[United Nations|UN]] [[United Nations member states|member states]], from 1990 to 2009. Amongst other measures used in the calculation, the CGER was given one-third weight in assessing the [[knowledge]] component, represented by gross enrolment, while the adult [[literacy]] rate was given two-thirds weight.<ref>http://hdr.undp.org/hdr2006/pdfs/report/Techinical_notes.pdf page 2</ref>
== References ==
{{Reflist}} http://www.unesco.org/new/en/education/ http://www.worldbank.org/depweb/english/beyond/global/glossary.html
{{Authority control}} [[Category:Educational administration]] [[Category:Human Development Index]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name =Gerald Genta | image = Gerald Genta.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Charles Gérald Genta | birth_date = {{birth date|1931|5|1}} | birth_place = [[Geneva]], [[Restoration (Switzerland)|Switzerland]] | death_date = {{death date and age|2011|8|17|1931|5|1|df=y}} | death_place = | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LONG|display=inline,title}} --> | residence = | nationality = | known_for = | education = | alma_mater = | employer = | occupation = watchmaker, businessman | years_active = }}
'''Charles Gérald Genta''' (1931-2011) was a Swiss jewellery designer, noted for his eponymous line of timepieces as well as his design work with other firms, including [[International Watch Company|IWC]], [[Universal Genève]], [[Patek Philippe]] and [[Audemars Piguet]], among others. [[Christie's]] auction house of New York called Genta's work ''"the [[Fabergé]] of watches"'',<ref>{{cite book | last = Guest | first = Tim | title = My Life in Orange: Growing Up with the Guru (page 258) | publisher = Mariner Books | year = 2005 | isbn = 0-15-603106-X }}</ref> while ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' has called them the "world's most complicated and pricey watches".<ref>{{cite book | last = | first = | work = [[The Wall Street Journal]] (Index, Volume 1; page 429) | publisher = [[Dow Jones & Company]] | year = 1996 | isbn = }}</ref>
==Biography==
Genta was born in Geneva to a Swiss mother and father of [[Piemonte]] (Northern Italian) descent. At age 20, Genta finished jewelry and [[goldsmith]] training in his native Switzerland, earning a Swiss federal diploma.
Subsequently, Genta was recruited by [[Universal Genève]] SA, at the time one of the most recognized manufactures in both the U.S. and Europe for its chronograph models. After Universal Genève settled a patent dispute involving the micro-rotor caliber, Genta designed Universal's [[Universal Genève#1950s-1960s: Microtor automatics|Polerouter Microtors]] in the 1950s, as well as the Golden and White Shadows during the mid-1960s. The Shadows contained a micro-rotor, [[Unisonic Products Corporation|unisonic]] and [[accutron]] movement, the latter two a result of the [[quartz crisis]] starting in the late 1960s.
Genta's work with Universal would be a precursor to future collaborations with other brands in Switzerland and throughout Europe, including Omega's ''Constellation'' (1959); [[Patek Philippe]]'s ''Golden Ellipse'' (1968). [[Audemars Piguet]]'s ''Royal Oak'' (1970), [[International Watch Company|IWC]]'s ''Ingenieur'' (1976); Patek Philippe's ''Nautilus'' (1976); and [[Cartier (jeweler)|Cartier]]'s ''Pasha de Cartier'' (1985)
[[File:Gérald Genta watch.jpg|thumb|150px|left|Gerald Genta ''Gefica Mt. Kilimanjaro'']]
After starting his own brand in 1969, Genta would create the [[sonnerie]]s, among them the Gérald Genta ''Octo Granda Sonnerie Tourbillion'', which contained four [[gong]]s and an emulated [[Westminster Quarters]] bell ring at each quarter and on the hour, "the same melody rung out by London's Big Ben", and priced at $810,200.<ref>Jack Forster, "For whom the bell tolls; For thee if you wear a minute repeater, the most complicated watch there is", p. 101 December 2009 ''Forbes Life''</ref> In 1994, he designed the ''Grande Sonnerie Retro'', the world's most complicated wristwatch, and priced at approximately $2 million.<ref>{{cite book | last = Aylmer, Editor in Chief | first = Sean | title = [[Business Review Weekly]] (Volume 13, Issues 33-42) | publisher = [[Fairfax Media]] | year = 1998 | isbn = }}</ref> For private requests, Genta hand-designed the movements, dials and cases of his timepieces and employed limited or no external assistance, outsourcing or mechanization during the process; it was not unusual for a single watch to take up to 5 years to complete.<ref>{{cite book | last = Chilton & | first = Co | title = Jewelers' circular-keystone (CK., Volume 166, Issues 7-9) | publisher = | year = 1995 | isbn = }}</ref>
During the 1980s, Genta obtained special licensing with [[The Walt Disney Company]] and distributed a limited edition of Disney character watches to the public; previously, they had been an unofficial private request by one of Genta's repeat customers. The dials consisted of illustrations of [[Mickey Mouse]], Minnie Mouse, [[Donald Duck]], Scrooge and Goofy, with cases made of [[18 carat]] gold. Designed in [[Le Brassus]], Switzerland, the watches retailed between $3250–$3650 in 1988.<ref>{{cite book | last = | first = | title = [[Texas Monthly]] (December 1988) | publisher = [[Emmis Communications]] | year = 1988 | isbn = }}</ref>
[[File:Evolution.jpg|thumb|125px|right|Gerald Charles ''A-Evolution'']]
Gerald Genta's clients have included professional athletes, business executives, rock musicians, [[rappers]], movie stars, politicians as well as royalty, including [[Prince Rainier of Monaco]], King [[Hassan II of Morocco]], King [[Juan Carlos]] and Queen [[Sofia of Spain]], King [[Fahd of Saudi Arabia]] and [[Queen Elizabeth The Queen Mother]] of England.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.watchtime.at/archive/wt_2006_06/WT_2006_06_134.pdf|accessdate=3 January 2013|title=The Genta Touch}}</ref>
After his eponymous company was acquired by [[Bulgari]] in 1999, Genta resigned and created a new venture called ''Gerald Charles''. As of 2010, Gerald Genta watches were marketed solely under the Bulgari brand. As Bulgari had been acquired by upscale French conglomerate [[LVMH]] in 2011, all "Gerald Genta" brand watches would in effect be products of the LVMH portfolio.
Genta died in August 2011 at age 80.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.audemarspiguet.com/manufacture/news/tribute-to-gerald-genta-98/|accessdate=28 August 2011|title=Tribute to Gérald Genta|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110910090905/http://www.audemarspiguet.com/manufacture/news/tribute-to-gerald-genta-98/|archivedate=10 September 2011|df=}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20160206023022/http://geraldgenta.ne10.net/ New company website] * [http://omega-constellation-collectors.blogspot.com/2009/07/omega-constellation-gerald-genta.html Gerald Genta's Omega Connection] * [http://blog.dreamchrono.com/2013/12/gerald-genta-watch-designer/ Gerald Genta Profil] by Michael Weare
{{DEFAULTSORT:Genta, Gerald}} [[Category:1931 births]] [[Category:2011 deaths]] [[Category:Swiss people of Italian descent]] [[Category:Swiss businesspeople]] [[Category:People from Geneva]] [[Category:Swiss watchmakers (people)]]

{{Infobox person | name = Hrant Vardanyan | image = Варданян.jpg | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = Hrant Vardanyan | birth_date = {{Birth date|1949|01|23}} | birth_place = [[Yerevan]], Armenia SSR | death_date = {{Death date and age|2014|04|20|1949|01|23}} | death_place = [[Yerevan]], Armenia | death_cause = | resting_place = | residence = Yerevan | nationality = Armenia | other_names = | citizenship = | education = National Polytechnic University of Armenia | alma_mater = | occupation = businessman, philanthropist | years_active = | employer = | organization = | agent = | known_for = | notable_works = | home_town = | salary = | networth = | television = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | movement = | opponents = | boards = | spouse = Zina Muruzyan | partner = | children = Mikael Vardanyan, Karen Vardanyan
| parents = | relatives = | callsign = | awards = [[File:Անանիա Շիրակացի Մեդալ.jpg|20px|link=http://www.president.am/en/medals/17/]][[File:Заслуженный работник экономики Республики Армения.png|30px|link=http://www.president.am/en/honorary-titles/33/]][[File:I41.jpg|30px|link=http://www.president.am/en/orders/41/#!prettyPhoto]] | signature = | signature_alt = | signature_size = | website = | footnotes = | box_width = }}
'''Hrant Vardanyan''' ({{lang-hy|Հրանտ Վարդանյան}}, 23 January 1949 - 20 April 2014)<ref>[http://www.armenianow.com/news/53774/armenia_hrant_vardanyan_grant_candy_tobacco_dead Grant Holding owner Hrant Vardanyan dies at 65: Leading businessman succumbs to heart disease]</ref> was an Armenian businessman and the pioneer of domestic Armenian manufacturing, the founder and the president of the leading national corporation Grand Holding and philanthropist. [http://www.president.am/en/honorary-titles/33/ Honored Worker of Economy of the Republic of Armenia (2009)]
== Biography == Hrant Vardanyan was born on January 23, 1949 in Yerevan, Armenia in a working-class family. From 1956 to 1966 he studied at the Kirov high school No. 12 in Yerevan, Armenia. From 1968 to 1974 he studied at the [[Yerevan Polytechnic Institute]],Faculty of Machine Building and Mechanical, majoring in food-industry engineering. Since 1990 - Candidate of Economics. Non-partisan.
Thanks to Hrant Vardanian, the celebration of the International Labor Day has been resumed in the Republic of Armenia as a state holiday since May 1, 2000. 1998-2003 Vardanyan was the President of the Basketball Federation of Armenia, 1992-2001 Board Member of the National Olympic Committee of Armenia, 2003-2014 Member of the Board of Trustees of Yerevan State Engineering University.
Hrant Vardanyan died on April 20, 2014. He is buried at Yerevan City Pantheon.<ref>{{cite web|author=21.04.14 |url=http://www.slaq.am/arm/news/191106/ |title=Հրանտ Վարդանյանի քաղաքացիական հոգեհանգիստը տեղի կունենա վաղը - Նորություններ |publisher=Slaq.am |date= |accessdate=2014-06-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://armenianow.com/news/53774/armenia_hrant_vardanyan_grant_candy_tobacco_dead |title=Grant Holding owner Hrant Vardanyan dies at 65: Leading businessman succumbs to heart disease - News |publisher=ArmeniaNow.com |date= |accessdate=2014-06-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.reporter.am/go/article/2011-08-29-wikileaks-yerevan-embassy-cables-on-armenian-politics |title=Armenian Reporter: |publisher=Reporter.am |date= |accessdate=2014-06-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130528235514/http://www.reporter.am/go/article/2011-08-29-wikileaks-yerevan-embassy-cables-on-armenian-politics |archivedate=2013-05-28 |df= }}</ref><ref>http://m.slaq.am/arm/news/191398?translit=1</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.banks.am/en/news/business/7853/ |title=Grand Holding substantially increases tobacco production and export |publisher=Banks.am |date=2013-02-07 |accessdate=2014-06-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tert.am/en/news/2014/04/23/vardanian-hrant/ |title=Hundreds pay their last respects to well-known Armenian businessman Hrant Vardanyan - Armenian News |publisher=Tert.am |date=2014-04-23 |accessdate=2014-06-03}}</ref>
==Entrepreneurial activity== Hrant Vardanyan started his professional career at the Yerevan Experimental Tobacco Plant as an engineer technologist, and since 1984 he has been the Deputy Director General Director of the Plant. In 1996, he started his entrepreneurial activity thus stimulating the restoration and development of domestic production. Hrant Vardanian founded Grand Tobacco, Grand Candy, International Masis Tabak and other companies that have leading positions in the domestic Armenian market and proudly represent national production in many countries oll over the world. The group of GRAND HOLDING companies established by him is a leading exporter of finished products in Armenia. In 2016 GRAND HOLDING employed over 7800 workers and [https://news.am/eng/news/374573.html was the largest tax payer in Armenia]. Thanks to cooperation with this enterprise, tens of thousands of jobs have been created in agriculture, particularly, in borderline villages of the Republic of Armenia.
===Business philosophy=== Since 1991, during the first 6 years after independence, when unemployment was rampant, nearly nothing was manufactured in Armenia, and everything was imported, Hrant Vardanyan, as an entrepreneur, set himself the goal of reviving and developing of local manufacture. He was the first to believe that Armenia possesses the required intellectual, human and industrial potential to compete on the domestic and international markets. The philosophy was that the Armenian consumer should buy locally produced goods thus contributing to the development of the domestic production, while the local producer should produce high-quality products, so that the consumer prefers the goods labeled “Made in Armenia”. With this ideology, he became an example for other manufacturers and he proved that, in spite of mass unemployment, emigration and blockade, the Armenian nation is capable not only to work and produce high quality goods and to live with dignity but also to export its products and conquer markets all over the world.
===Charity=== Hrant Vardanyan’s charity activities were multipurpose and comprehensive. He sponsored science, education, culture, healthcare, sports, the [[Yerevan Zoo|National Zoo]], and the children’s gratis TV channel “Hyerenik”, and monthly pensions were paid to the [[Heroes of Socialist Labor]].
Hrant Vardanyan implemented large-scale long-term charity projects in [[Tavush Province]] of Armenia, specially in the borderline villages, thus promoting the development of the local communities.
Hrant Vardanian built the St. Thaddeus Church in the town of [[Masis, Armenia|Masis]] in Armenia.
==Family== Hrant Vardanyan was born into the family of Mikael Vardanyan and Shushanik Sargsyan. He has two sisters Rima and Rosa. His grandmother and grandfather were victims of the 1915 [[Armenian Genocide]] in the village of Hinis, [[Western Armenia]]. At the age of 7 Hrant Vardanyan lost his father. He met his wife Zina Muruzyan while studying at the Polytechnic Institute. They got married in 1972. Hrant Vardanyan has two sons Mikael and Karen, and six grandchildren, Isabella, Zina, Hrant, Daniel, Mark, and Aksel.
==Awards== * In 1999, the Medal of Anania Shirakatsi was awarded to Hrant Vardanian by the [[President of Armenia|President of the Republic of Armenia]] for his contribution to the restoration of national production. * In 2009, for the first time in the history of the independent Armenia, Hrant Vardanyan was awarded the title of Honored Worker of Economy of the RA by the President of the Republic of Armenia.<ref>[http://www.president.am/hy/press-release/item/2009/01/21/news-366/ PRESIDENT SERZH SARGSYAN AWARDED HRANT VARDANIAN WITH THE HONORARY TITLE OF THE DISTINGUISHED ENTREPRENEUR]</ref> * On December 20, 2014, the President of Armenia posthumously awarded Hrant Vardanyan the Order for "Serving the Motherland”, 1st Class for his personal contribution to the development of national economy.
== References == {{Reflist}}
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Vardanyan, Hrant}} [[Category:Articles created via the Article Wizard]] [[Category:1949 births]] [[Category:2014 deaths]] [[Category:People from Yerevan]] [[Category:Armenian businesspeople]]

{{Infobox person | name = James J. Van Alen | image = | caption = | birth_name = James John Van Alen | birth_date = {{Birth date|1848|3|20}} | birth_place = [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]], U.S. | death_date = {{Death date and age|1923|7|13|1848|3|20}} | death_place = [[London]], [[England]], [[U.K.]] | death_cause = | resting_place = | known_for = | alma_mater = [[Oxford University]] | spouse = {{marriage|Emily Astor
|1876|1881|reason=her death}} | children = 3 | parents = [[James Henry Van Alen]]
Mary Young Steward | relatives = ''See [[Astor family]]'' | awards = [[Order of Saint John (chartered 1888)|Knight of Grace of St. John of Jerusalem]] }} '''James John Van Alen''' (March 20, 1848 – July 13, 1923) was a sportsman and politician. He was appointed [[Ambassador Extraordinary and Plenipotentiary]] to Italy on October 20, 1893, but declined the appointment.{{cite web |url=https://history.state.gov/departmenthistory/people/van-alen-james-j |title= James J. Van Alen (1846-1923)|accessdate=2009-08-17 |quote= |publisher=[[United States Department of State]] }} He was well known as a New York Society leader and was referred to as the "American Prince of Wales."{{cite news|last1=Times-|first1=Special Cable To The Xew Tohk|title=JAMES J. VAN ALEN DEAD IN LONDON; {{!}} New York Society Leader Was Sometimes Called "American Prince of Wales." {{!}} A LAVISH NEWPORT HOST {{!}} He Had Lived Abroad Since Prohibition, Which He Disapproved as "Our Lack of Liberty."|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1923/07/14/archives/james-j-van-alen-dead-in-london-new-york-society-leader-was.html|accessdate=26 January 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=14 July 1923}} ==Early life== He was the son of [[James Henry Van Alen]] (1819–1886),{{cite news|title=OVERBOARD IN MIDOCEAN; STRANGE DISAPPEARANCE OF GEN. J.H. VAN ALEN. LOST ON THE VOYAGE FROM LIVERPOOL TO NEW-YORK--HIS DEATH BELIEVED TO BE ACCIDENTAL.|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9F0DEEDA1030E533A25755C2A9619C94679FD7CF&legacy=true|accessdate=26 January 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=26 July 1886}} who served as a brigadier general in the [[Union Army]] during the [[American Civil War|Civil War]], and Mary Young Steward (1818–1852). He attended and graduated from [[Oxford University]]. ==Career== Van Alen donated $50,000 to [[Grover Cleveland]]'s successful campaign for President. He was rewarded with an appointment as [[Ambassador Extraordinary and Plenipotentiary]] to Italy on October 20, 1893,{{cite news|title=A NEW SUPREME COURT JUDGE; WILLIAM B. HORNBLOWER, PROMOTED TO THE BENCH. The Successor to the Late Justice Blatchford Appointed -- No Surprise Created as The New York Times Had Foreshadowed the Nomination -- Senator David B. Hill the Only One Who Has Thus Far Criticised the Appointment -- Other Nominations.|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9D06E1D9103BEF33A25753C2A96F9C94629ED7CF&legacy=true|accessdate=26 January 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=20 September 1893}} but declined the appointment, owing to public disapproval.{{cite news|title=JAMES J. VAN ALEN.|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1893/12/12/109714852.html?pageNumber=5|accessdate=26 January 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=December 12, 1893|language=en}} He was also rumored to have been appointed the [[United States Ambassador to the United Kingdom|United States Ambassador to Great Britain]] under President Cleveland. His father became wealthy from real estate, which he inherited upon his death in 1886.{{cite news|title=LATEST DEALINGS IN THE REALTY FIELD; James J. Van Alen Sells Eight Old Harlem Houses in 130th Street. WAVERLEY PLACE PURCHASE Dwelling Sale Near Sutton Place-- Deals in Chelsea and on Canal Street.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1921/02/15/archives/latest-dealings-in-the-realty-field-james-j-van-alen-sells-eight.html|accessdate=26 January 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=15 February 1921}}{{cite news|title=GEN. VAN ALEN'S WILL.|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9F01E4DB1130E533A25757C2A96E9C94679FD7CF&legacy=true|accessdate=26 January 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=24 August 1886}} In 1919, he sold his house at 15 [[65th Street (Manhattan)|East 65th Street]] in Manhattan, to [[Rufus Lenoir Patterson|Rufus L. Patterson]], due to his opposition to [[Prohibition]].{{cite news|title=VAN ALEN SELLS HOME HERE; Advent of Prohibition Responsible It Is Said, for Giving Up Residence.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1919/12/13/archives/van-alen-sells-home-here-advent-of-prohibition-responsible-it-is.html|accessdate=26 January 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=13 December 1919}} He then lived abroad, spending most of his time at a villa in [[Cannes, France]],{{cite news|last1=Times|first1=Wireless To The New Yobk|title=VAN ALEN BURIAL HERE.; Memorial Service to Bi, Held In Savoy Chapel, London, Tomorrow.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1923/07/15/archives/van-alen-burial-here-memorial-service-to-bi-held-in-savoy-chapel.html|accessdate=26 January 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=15 July 1923}} from February 1920 until his death. In 1919, Van Alen stated:
I know of lots of people that will leave the United States and make their home in countries where the laws are not so strict."
In 1921, Van Alen sold eight three-story Harlem Houses in the [[Astor Row|130th Street]] block, 28 to 42 West 130th Street, each on a lot 25 by 100 feet, between [[Fifth Avenue|Fifth]] and [[Lenox Avenue]]s to James H. Cruikshank.{{cite news |title=Harlem's Astor Row for Colored Tenants; Radical Changes in 130th Street, for Years the Block Beautiful in That Section |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1920/11/21/archives/harlems-astor-row-for-colored-tenants-radical-changes-in-130th.html |newspaper=[[New York Times]] |page=106 |date=November 21, 1920 |accessdate=2009-08-22}}{{cite news |last=Hartocollis |first=Anemona |title=The Long Journey of the Lord of the House |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/01/05/nyregion/coping-the-long-journey-of-the-lord-of-the-house.html |newspaper=[[New York Times]] |date=January 5, 2003 |accessdate=2009-08-22}} ==Personal life== [[File:Emily Astor by Hiram Powers.jpg|thumb|Emily Astor by Hiram Powers]] In 1876, he married Emily Astor (1854–1881), the eldest daughter of [[William Backhouse Astor, Jr.]] (1829–1892) and [[Caroline Webster Schermerhorn Astor|Caroline Webster Schermerhorn]] (1830–1908). Together, James and Emily had three children:{{cite web |url=http://xroads.virginia.edu/~MA01/davis/newport/biographies/vanalen.html |title=James J. Van Alen |accessdate=2009-08-04 |quote=James J. Van Alen (1846-1923) was a sportsman, politician, and member of an old-monied New York railroad family. Van Alen solidified his status as a member of upper-class society by marrying Emily Astor, daughter of society matron Caroline Schermerhorn Astor and William Backhouse Astor Jr. |publisher=[[University of Virginia]] }} *Mary Van Alen (1876–1959),{{cite news|last1=Times|first1=Special To The New York|title=MRS. G.A. THOMPSON DIES; Granddaughter of William Astors Was Broker's Widow|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1959/05/10/archives/mrs-ga-thompson-dies-granddaughter-of-william-astors-was-brokers.html?_r=0|accessdate=26 January 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=10 May 1959}} who married Griswold A. Thompson (1875–1945) in 1913.{{cite book|last1=Appeals|first1=United States Court of Customs|title=Court of Customs Appeals Reports: Cases Adjudged in the United States Court of Customs Appeals|date=1915|publisher=The Court|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=85QKAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA343&lpg=PA343&dq=Mary+Van+Alen+thompson&source=bl&ots=YXQ7Eg-2hO&sig=oy-R84JX7vj23p4rs-gk_vpx2WA&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwig5rDo7eDRAhUG64MKHcgCBXAQ6AEIMDAE#v=onepage&q=Mary%20Van%20Alen%20thompson&f=false|accessdate=26 January 2017|language=en}} *James Laurens Van Alen (1878–1927),{{cite news|last1=Times|first1=Special To The New York|title=James L. Van Alen Buried.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1927/06/19/archives/james-l-van-alen-buried.html|accessdate=26 January 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=19 June 1927}} who married [[Margaret Van Alen Bruguiére|Margaret "Daisy" Louise Post]] (1876–1969) in 1900{{cite news|title=A VANDERBILT-ASTOR ALLIANCE; Wedding of J. Lawrence Van Alen and Miss Daisy Post. A Quiet Ceremony, Only Sixty-two Guests Being Present -- Some of if the Guests and Gowns.|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9D07EFDC1E3BEE33A25752C1A9649D946197D6CF&legacy=true|accessdate=26 January 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=11 December 1900}}{{cite news|title=WHAT IS DOING IN SOCIETY.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1900/12/08/archives/what-is-doing-in-society.html|accessdate=26 January 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=8 December 1900}}{{cite web |url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2209&dat=19690122&id=syRfAAAAIBAJ&sjid=8U4NAAAAIBAJ&pg=3495,2164927|title=Wealthy Newport Dowager, Mrs Brugiere, Dies at 92 |publisher=[[The Telegraph (Nashua)|Nashua Telegraph]]|date=22 January 1969|accessdate=4 March 2014}} *Sarah Steward Van Alen (1881–1963),{{cite news|last1=Times|first1=Special To The New York|title=J.J. VAN ALEN'S DINNER DANCE.; Wakehurst Beautifully Decorated -- Miss Sarah Van Alen Introduced to Newport Society.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1900/09/06/archives/jj-van-alens-dinner-dance-wake-hurst-beautifully-decorated-miss.html|accessdate=26 January 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=6 September 1900}} who married [[Robert J. Collier|Robert Joseph Collier]] (1876–1918) in 1902.{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=R. J. Collier Dies At Dinner Table. Editor, Just Returned from the Front, Is a Victim of Heart Attack. Recall Had Been Reported. Washington Admits His Credentials Had Been Canceled, but Denies Knowledge of the Reason. Stricken at Dinner Table. Had Many Libel Suits. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1918/11/09/97042006.pdf |quote=Robert J. Collier, editor of Collier's Weekly and President of the publishing house of P.F. Collier Son, died of heart attack at his home at 1,067 Fifth Avenue at 7:45 last night, a few hours after he had landed from an army transport upon which he had returned ...|work=[[New York Times]] |date=November 9, 1918 |accessdate=2009-08-04 | format=PDF}} His wife died in 1881, only 5 years after they were wed.{{cite news|title=Obituary 2 -- DIED|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1881/11/23/archives/obituary-2-no-title.html|accessdate=26 January 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=23 November 1881}} Van Alen died in 1923 while in London.{{cite news|last1=Times|first1=Special To The New York|title=CONTEST EXPECTED ON VAN ALEN'S WILL {{!}} One Executor Refuses to Serve, and His Son Has Not Accepted. {{!}} ESTATE GOES TO FAMILY {{!}} Codicil Increases Trusts for Daughters from $250,000 Each to $500,000.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1923/10/09/archives/contest-expected-onvanalenswill-i-_____-one-executor-refuses-to.html|accessdate=26 January 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=9 October 1923}} His entire estate was estimated at $20,000,000 ({{Inflation|US|20000000|1923|r=-3|fmt=eq}}).{{cite news|title=VAN ALEN LEFT $20,000,000.; Will to Be Offered In Newport on Monday.|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9E06E7D91030E233A25753C1A96E9C946295D6CF&legacy=true|accessdate=26 January 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=10 August 1923}} After his property and stock was given to his son, and taxes were paid,{{cite news|last1=Times|first1=Special To The New York|title=THREE LANDS CLAIM VAN ALEN RESIDENCE; {{!}} America, England and France Reported to Be Eying Expatriate's $25,000,000 Estate for Taxes.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1923/08/02/archives/three-lands-claim-van-alen-residence-america-england-and-france.html|accessdate=26 January 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=2 August 1923}} the residual estate was valued at $2,061,617 ({{Inflation|US|2061617|1923|r=-3|fmt=eq}}).{{cite news|title=VAN ALEN LEFT $2,061,617. {{!}} Estate of the Late William Astor's Son-in-Law is Appraised.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1925/01/28/archives/ce-conant-dies-in-fall-authority-on-romance-languages-steps-from-a.html|accessdate=26 January 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=28 January 1925}} His will provided trust funds of $500,000 ({{Inflation|US|500000|1923|r=-3|fmt=eq}}) each for his daughters, Mary and Sarah, the principal to go to their descendants. His son, James, received all real estate, property, and life estate in the residue and his grandson, [[Jimmy Van Alen|James H. Van Alen]], a surviving life estate. An additional trust of $12,000 ({{Inflation|US|12000|1923|r=-3|fmt=eq}}) was set aside for a friend, Mary M. Griffith. Upon her death, the residual went to his grandchildren. [[File:Rushton Hall 01.jpg|thumb|right|[[Rushton Hall]] in [[Northamptonshire, England]]]][[File:Wakehurst1.jpg|thumb|right|Van Alen's Newport residence]] ===Residences=== Van Alen was one of several very rich men who leased, but did not buy, [[Rushton Hall]] in [[Northamptonshire, England]], from the Clarke-Thornhill family.{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=James J. Van Alen Selling Flowers. His Gardens at Rushton Hall Producing Blooms for the London Market. Making Money On Estate. Likely to Get Back Part of the Big Sum He Was Compelled by Tradesmen to Expend. |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1908/03/29/104800034.pdf |quote=James J. Van Alen is getting back some of the money he has spent in England. It will be remembered that several years ago he purchased Rushton Hall, a handsome country seat, on which he expended great sums, paying, if report be correct, extraordinary and unnecessarily high prices for certain pieces of furniture and bits of decoration which he required to complete the artistic ensemble he had planned out. |work=[[New York Times]] |date=March 29, 1909 |accessdate=2009-08-17 | format=PDF}} Rushton was the ancestral home of the [[Tresham baronets|Tresham family]]. The estate is about {{convert|227|acre}} of which {{convert|30|acre}} are formal gardens. The [[River Ise]] flows from west to east south of the Hall.[http://www.parksandgardens.ac.uk/component/option,com_parksandgardens/task,site/id,4872/Itemid,292/ Parks and Gardens UK website], accessed 25 March 2012 Van Alen's father had a home in [[Newport, Rhode Island]] called " The Grange " and lived there year-round.{{cite news|title=REAL ESTATE IN NEWPORT.; A FARM BOUGHT FOR $12,000 NOW WORTH A MILLION AND A HALF.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1881/12/28/archives/real-estate-in-newport-a-farm-bought-for-12000-now-worth-a-million.html|accessdate=26 January 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=28 December 1881}} In 1887, seven years after his wife's death in 1881, Van Alen's father gave him the land and he commissioned American architect [[Dudley Newton]] to build a replica of [[Wakehurst Place]] in Newport from plans designed by [[Charles Eamer Kempe]].{{cite web|last1=Hughes|first1=Tyler|title=The Gilded Age Era: "Wakehurst" The Van Alen Mansion, Newport|url=http://thegildedageera.blogspot.com/2012/07/wakehurst.html|website=The Gilded Age Era|accessdate=26 January 2017|date=4 July 2012}} When completed the home had cost Van Alen some $750,000 ({{Inflation|US|750000|1887|r=-3|fmt=eq}}). [[Salve Regina University]] purchased the mansion from the Van Alen family in 1972.{{cite web|last1=Salve Regina University|title=Campus Buildings: Wakehurst|url=http://www.salve.edu/campus-buildings/wakehurst|accessdate=6 July 2016}} ===Descendants=== His two daughters did not have children, however his son, James Laurens Van Alen, had three children. James' eldest child was [[Jimmy Van Alen|James Henry "Jimmy" Van Alen II]] (1902–1991), the founder of the [[International Tennis Hall of Fame]], who married Eleanor Langley.{{cite news|title=MISS LANGLEY TO WED JAMES H. VAN ALEN; Engagement to Great-Grandson of Late Mrs. William Astor Is Announced.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1929/07/17/archives/miss-langley-to-wed-james-h-van-alen-engagement-to-greatgrandson-of.html|accessdate=26 January 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=17 July 1929}} His second born was William Laurens Van Alen (1907–2003), founding president of the [[United States Court Tennis Association]], who married Elizabeth Brinton Kent, daughter of [[A. Atwater Kent|Arthur Atwater Kent]], in 1931.{{cite news|last1=Times|first1=Special To The New York|title=MISS ELIZABETH KENT WED TO W.L. VAN ALEN; Married to Great-Grandson of William Astor at St. Saviour's Church, Bar Harbor, Me.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1931/08/09/archives/miss-elizabeth-kent-wed-to-wl-van-alen-married-to-greatgrandson-of.html|accessdate=26 January 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=9 August 1931}} His youngest, and only daughter was Louise Astor Van Alen (1910–1998).{{cite news|title=Paid Notice: Deaths SAUNDERSON, LOUISE ASTOR VAN ALEN|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/04/classified/paid-notice-deaths-saunderson-louise-astor-van-alen.html|accessdate=26 January 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=4 January 1998}} Louise was married three times, first in 1931 to Prince [[Mdivani|Alexei Mdivani]] (1905–1936). They divorced in 1932 when Mdivani left her to marry [[F. W. Woolworth Company|Woolworth]] heiress [[Barbara Hutton]]. In 1936, after Alexei's death, she married Prince [[Mdivani|Sergei Mdivani]] (1903–1936), her first husband's older brother.{{cite news|title=MISS VAN ALEN TO REWED.; She Will Marry Serge Mdivani, Whose Brother She Divorced.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1935/12/04/archives/miss-van-alen-to-rewed-she-will-marry-serge-mdivani-whose-brother.html|accessdate=26 January 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=4 December 1935}} Sergei tragically died later that year in a polo accident.''Serge Mdivani is Killed Playing Polo in Florida'', ''[[The New York Times]]'', March 16, 1936 In 1947, she married for the third and final time, to Alexander Saunderson (1917–2004),{{cite news|title=Paid Notice: Deaths SAUNDERSON, ALEXANDER|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9B02E1DD1330F931A2575AC0A9629C8B63|accessdate=26 January 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=12 September 2004}} grandson of [[Edward James Saunderson|Edward J. Saunderson]] (1837–1906), an [[Member of Parliament|MP]] and [[Lord Lieutenant of Cavan]].Moore, Steven. ''Archives: Ulsterman to marry Georgian Princess'' [[The Belfast News Letter]], 25 August 1999 ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Van Alen, James John}} [[Category:1848 births]] [[Category:1923 deaths]] [[Category:American people of Dutch descent]] [[Category:Astor family]] [[Category:Livingston family]] [[Category:Van Alen family]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.1)
revision.text:
'''James Kenneth Gray''' O.C., A.O.E.<ref name="CBHF">{{cite web|url=http://www.cbhof.ca/james-k-gray-oc-aoe-cbhf-class-2005|title=James K. Gray O.C., A.O.E., C.B.H.F. - Class of 2005|accessdate=March 3, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130115092628/http://www.cbhof.ca/james-k-gray-oc-aoe-cbhf-class-2005|archivedate=January 15, 2013|df=}}</ref> was born in [[Kirkland Lake]], [[Ontario]] in 1933. He was educated at [[Ridley College]] in [[St. Catharines]], Canada. He came to [[Calgary]] in 1956 to pursue a career in [[Alberta]]'s energy sector. In 1973, he co-founded Canadian Hunter Exploration, an organization that became one of Canada's largest and most successful natural gas companies."<ref name="aoe bio">{{cite web|url=http://www.lieutenantgovernor.ab.ca/AOE_Legacy/Member/57/Full|title=James Kenneth Gray's Alberta Order of Excellence biography |accessdate=March 3, 2012}}</ref>
Gray has served as an independent director of [[Brookfield Asset Management]] (an [[NYSE]] listed company) since April 1997.<ref name="Brookfield">{{cite web|url=http://www.brookfield.com/content/corporate_governance/board_of_directors-1057.html |title=Brookfield Board of Directors page for James Kenneth Gray |accessdate=March 3, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120302001117/http://www.brookfield.com/content/corporate_governance/board_of_directors-1057.html |archivedate=March 2, 2012 |df= }}</ref> He is also a director emeritus of [[Canadian National Railway]],<ref name="CN annual report">{{cite web|url=http://www.cn.ca/documents/Investor-Annual-Report/2010-annual-report-en.pdf|title=CN Rail 2010 Annual report dated Feb 15, 2011 |accessdate=March 3, 2012}}</ref> director of Phoenix Technology Services,<ref name="Phoenix">{{cite web|url=http://www.phxtech.com/index.php/investor/people.html|title=Phoenix Technology Services Directors and Officers |accessdate=March 3, 2012}}</ref> and Honorary Chair of the [[Canada West Foundation]].<ref name="CWF">{{cite web|url=http://cwf.ca/about-us/board-of-directors|title=CWF board of directors |accessdate=March 3, 2012}}</ref>
Gray was recognized in 2002 with the [[Alberta Order of Excellence]].<ref name="aoe scroll">{{cite web|url=http://www.lieutenantgovernor.ab.ca/AOE_Legacy/Member/57/Scroll|title=James Kenneth Gray's Alberta Order of Excellence Scroll |accessdate=March 3, 2012}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
== External links == * http://www.lieutenantgovernor.ab.ca/AOE_Legacy/Member/57
{{DEFAULTSORT:Gray, James K.}} [[Category:Canadian businesspeople]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Calgary]] [[Category:1933 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Kirkland Lake]] [[Category:Members of the Alberta Order of Excellence]]
{{Canada-business-bio-stub}}

{{infobox person |image= |name=Jay Boy Adams |birth_name= James Wallace Adams |birth_date={{birth date and age|1949|12|8}} |birth_place=[[Fort Worth, Texas|Fort Worth]], [[Tarrant County, Texas|Tarrant County]], [[Texas]], [[United States]] |residence=[[Lubbock, Texas|Lubbock]], [[Comfort, Texas|Comfort]], [[Kendall County, Texas|Kendall County]], Texas |death_date= |death_place= |occupation=Musician; vocalist, businessman |spouse=Mary F. Adams |children= |religion= |alma_mater=Colorado City High School, [[University of North Texas]], [[Texas Tech University]] |website=http://www.jayboyadams.com/ |footnotes= }} '''James Wallace "Jay Boy" Adams''' (born December 8, 1949) is an American singer, songwriter, and guitarist from [[Lubbock, Texas|Lubbock]] and [[San Antonio, Texas|San Antonio]], [[Texas]], known particularly for storytelling in his songs.
==Early years== Adams was born in [[Fort Worth, Texas|Fort Worth]] but reared in [[Colorado City, Texas|Colorado City]], the seat of [[Mitchell County, Texas|Mitchell County]] south of [[Snyder, Texas|Snyder]] in [[West Texas]], where his father was the local [[Chevrolet]] dealer and a rancher.<ref name=bio>{{cite web|url=http://www.jayboyadams.com/page2.htm|title=Jay Boy Adams biography|publisher=jayboyadams.com|accessdate=September 3, 2011}}</ref> Upon graduation in 1967 from [[Colorado Independent School District|Colorado City High School]], he entered the [[University of North Texas]] at [[Denton, Texas|Denton]], then North Texas State University, which is known for its arts and music curricula. There one of his English classmates was [[Don Henley]], later with the [[Eagles (band)|Eagles]]. Adams also met [[Gary Nicholson (singer)|Gary Nicholson]] while at NTSU. Adams went to [[Dallas, Texas|Dallas]], to hear the guitarist [[Bugs Henderson]], who played an impact on Adams's musical development. He fondly credits the late nights spent listening to Henderson for the neglect of his college studies.<ref name=jba>{{cite web|url=http://www.sweetwaterreporter.com/content/jay-boy-adams-perform-texas-theatre|title=Jay Boy Adams to perform at Texas Theater|publisher=''Sweetwater Reporter'', March 5, 2011|accessdate=September 3, 2011}}</ref>
With hopes of a musical career of his own, Adams left UNT after two years and moved to Houston. There he met John Carrick whose mother was the owner of Sand Mountain Coffee House. His first solo performing was at Sand Mountain along with Carrick, Bobbie Jo Gentry, Jerry Jeff Walker and others. Adams and Carrick formed "Hayseed" a short lived band experimenting with original songs and then performing in and around [[Houston, Texas|Houston]] and at Alan's Landing. Once there, Adams met the guitarist [[Billy Gibbons]] of The Moving Sidewalks, and played at The Cellar.<ref name=jba/> In late 1969 he moved to [[Midland, Texas|Midland]] where he joined the house band at The Chateau Club led by [[Johnny Heartsman]]. Adams credited Heartsman as a major influence. He attended [[Howard College]], a [[community college]] in [[Big Spring, Texas|Big Spring]], Texas, with the goal of improving his grade-point average so that he could re-enter a university. Meanwhile, he lost his draft deferment during the [[Vietnam War]].<ref name=intv>{{cite web|url=http://www.virtualubbock.com/intJayBoyAdams.html|title=Interview: Jay Boy Adams|publisher=virtuallubbock.com|accessdate=September 3, 2011}}</ref>
In March 1972, [[Steve Moss]], a friend secured Adams a spot with the [[ZZ Top]] band in Lubbock. That summer he gained entry to [[Texas Tech University]] in Lubbock to study music and English. ZZ Top's manager, [[Bill Ham]], soon invited Adams to play for the band at the Municipal Auditorium in Dallas. By 1976, Adams had signed with [[Atlantic Records]], which in 1977 released his first music. After two albums Atlantic did not renew his contract. Late 1980 manager [[Bill Ham]] sent Adams to Capricorn Records in Macon, GA to record. His last recordings were done there with Paul Hornsby producing. Early 1981 before the album was completed Capricorn Records filed bandruptsy. Probably his best unfinished work to date was locked away in the legal vault. He and his band continued to perform and tour but by 1982 Adams had had enough and withdrew from the music scene. Adams is known for his ability for storytelling in song, a mixture of blues, [[rock and roll]], [[Country music|country]], and folk music. In those years, Adams often spent more than half of the year in concert tours.<ref name=jba/> He performed not only with ZZ Top, but the [[Allman Brothers Band]], [[Marshall Tucker Band]], [[Joe Cocker]], and many others. In the Cocker band for a time was a saxophone player, [[Bobby Keys]], originally from [[Slaton, Texas|Slaton]] in [[Lubbock County, Texas|Lubbock County]], who began touring with many bands as a young teenager. Keys and Adams had not previously met but toured together for a time with Cocker.<ref name=intv/> It had been years since Bobby Keys had seen Lubbock. Adams invited Keys to return and play with his band at the first Joe Ely Tornado Jam.
==Later career== By 1982, faced with mounting family obligations, Adams left the music business and avoided music clubs and concerts for most of the following fifteen years. Instead, he operated and still maintains the company, Roadhouse Transportation, which leases touring coaches to such celebrity singers as [[Celine Dion]], [[ZZ Top]], and [[Bruce Springsteen]] and even the [[Dallas Cowboys]]. He did for a time make a few annual musical appearances in Lubbock and in 1986 played there at the Cattle Baron’s Ball with [[Reba McEntire]]. He moved his family to a ranch in the [[Texas Hill Country]] and his business to the town of [[Comfort, Texas|Comfort]] in [[Kendall County, Texas|Kendall County]], part of the [[San Antonio, Texas|San Antonio]] [[Metropolitan Statistical Area]]. One evening Adams and his wife, Mary F. Adams, attended a show in San Antonio to hear the musician [[Lee Roy Parnell]], who invited Adams to join him on stage. Thereafter, Adams's desire to perform in public was rekindled and became irresistible.<ref name=jba/>
In 1999, Adams joined George Strait's national tour. He toured Europe with the [[Tejano]] group, the [[Texas Tornados]]. He became the co-manager of the popular singer [[Pat Green]], whom Adams met when Green came looking for touring accommodations. By 2007, Adams released the album "The Shoe Box", which reached No. 5 on the Americana chart. The album offers ten new Adams selections and three from the late 1970s. "The Shoe Box" produced three top 10 single songs the Texas Music Chart, where it was posted for some two years. Singer [[Stephen Stills]], an avid listener of "The Shoe Box," declared Adams "a great musician and a storyteller in the true Texas tradition" and invited him to join Stills' national tour.<ref name=jba/>
In 2005, Adams was featured on [[Bob Phillips]]'s ''[[Texas Country Reporter]]'' [[Television syndication|syndicated]] television [[anthology]] [[television series|series]], with an explanation for his return to professional music.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.texascountryreporter.com/show05.htm |title=Jay Boy Adams |publisher=texascountryreporter.com, May 28, 2005 |accessdate=September 3, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120323074921/http://www.texascountryreporter.com/show05.htm |archivedate=March 23, 2012 |df= }}</ref>
On March 12, 2011, Adams performed in concert at the landmark Texas Theater in [[Sweetwater, Texas|Sweetwater]] in [[Nolan County, Texas|Nolan County]], near his hometown of Colorado City. It was the first concert in some seventy years at that facility, which had originally been designed for musical programs but converted to films after its opening.<ref name=jba/>
The current lineup of Adams' band, The Roadhouse Scholars, include Sam Hendricks on Hammond B3 and piano, Mark Butzirus on drums, and Ronnie Leatherman on bass guitar. It is commonplace to see other musicians join Adams on stage. Currently Adams splits his time between Texas and Santa Fe, New Mexico, and plays regularly when in Santa Fe with a host of local and transplanted musicians from various parts of the USA. He is frequently seen performing in most of the popular night spots in Santa Fe that include El Farol, Evangelo's, and The Cowgirl.
[[Image:Colorado City, TX, Opera House IMG_4536.JPG|250px|right|thumb|The Opera House in [[Colorado City, Texas|Colorado City]], [[Texas]], where Adams has occasionally performed in the community where he was reared]]
Adams is an artist through [[Wounded Bird Records]]. He has recently joined forces with other musical veterans in the rock group, Brothers of the Southland which include key members from southern rock pioneers The Outlaws, The Allman Brothers Band, The Marshall Tucker Band, Wet Willie, The Black Crowes, and new comer Bo Bice.<ref name=bio/> Though his touring coach business is based in Kendall County (San Antonio), Adams kept Lubbock as his musical home. "Lubbock is the capital of West Texas. There has been so much talent come out of there, and really . . . none of it has been very commercial. [[Buddy Holly]] wasn't commercial when he [first] came out of there."<ref name=intv/> Among those to whom Adams was referring was [[Don Allison]], an area musician associated with various genres of music and a long-time producer at the [[Cactus Theater]] in Lubbock, where Adams has also frequently performed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://lubbockonline.com/entertainment/2011-05-25/lubbock-musician-don-allison-loses-battle-cancer-age-49?v=1306287180|title=William Kerns, Lubbock musician Don Allison loses battle with cancer at age 49: Musician Don Allison lost four-year battle with cancer and died Tuesday", May 25, 2011|publisher=''[[Lubbock Avalanche-Journal]]''|accessdate=September 3, 2011}}</ref>
==Discography== * ''Jay Boy Adams'' (1977) [[Billboard 200|US]] No. 210 * ''Fork In The Road'' (1978) * ''The Shoe Box'' (2007) * ''Let It Go'' (2014)
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Adams, Jay Boy}} [[Category:1949 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Fort Worth, Texas]] [[Category:American rock singers]] [[Category:American pop singers]] [[Category:American country singers]] [[Category:American country singer-songwriters]] [[Category:American businesspeople]] [[Category:Country musicians from Texas]] [[Category:People from Colorado City, Texas]] [[Category:Musicians from San Antonio]] [[Category:People from Lubbock, Texas]] [[Category:Texas Tech University alumni]] [[Category:University of North Texas alumni]] [[Category:Songwriters from Texas]] [[Category:Guitarists from Texas]] [[Category:American male guitarists]] [[Category:20th-century American guitarists]]

revision.text:
{{For|the distantly related SA lawyer, MLC and MLA for [[Electoral district of Light|Light]] |John Tuthill Bagot}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2016}} {{Use Australian English|date=November 2016}}
'''John Bagot''' J.P. (10 January 1849 – 29 August 1910) was a businessman and politician in the colony of South Australia.
John Bagot was born the second son of Christopher Michael Bagot (1817 – 8 November 1853) and Margaret Elizabeth Bagot, née Watts (ca.1823 – 6 November 1910) at his father's property "Koonunga", near [[Kapunda, South Australia]]. His mother was a daughter of Capt. John Watts (of the 73rd Regiment), who was at one time Adelaide's Postmaster-General. His grandfather, who selected the property, was Capt. [[Charles Hervey Bagot]], of the 59th Regiment, who arrived in South Australia on the ''Birman'' in December 1840. It was on this same property that copper was discovered by Captain Bagot's youngest son Charles Samuel Bagot, which incorporated with the [[F. S. Dutton]]'s adjoining property "Anlaby", became Australia's first copper mine.
John Bagot was educated at [[St Peter's College, Adelaide|St. Peter's College]], then for several years worked for the National Bank of Australasia. In the 1870s he and his brother C. M. Bagot (1852–1899) took up the Peake Cattle Run, between Warrina and Lake Eyre, which they continued to run until around 1900. He also owned the "Springbank" property near Burra for a few years. For a long period he was a director of Bagot, Shakes, & Lewis, Limited, Broken Hill Pty., the National Bank, the South Australian Brewing Company, the Alliance Assurance Company, and the [[South Australian Mining Association]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article164706051 |title=Obituary |newspaper=[[The Observer (Adelaide)|The Observer]] |location=Adelaide |date=3 September 1910 |accessdate=28 August 2015 |page=39 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
He was represented the seat of [[Electoral district of Victoria|Victoria]] in the [[South Australian House of Assembly]] from April 1884 to April 1887.
He married Lucy Josephine Ayers (ca.1857 – 11 May 1945), a daughter of [[Henry Ayers|Sir Henry Ayers]], on 24 September 1878. [[Walter Bagot (architect)|Walter Hervey Bagot]] (17 March 1880 – 27 February 1889), a noted architect, and founding partner in [[Woods Bagot|Woods and Bagot]] was the only child to survive to adulthood. They lived at Buxton Street, North Adelaide, later Park Terrace, Fitzroy until 1901, then "Forest Lodge", 19 Pine Street, [[Stirling, South Australia|Stirling]], where John established a fine garden. His library included a valuable collection of Australiana. For several years prior to his death Mr. Bagot was an invalid, and was obliged to retire altogether from public life, living on Pennington Terrace, North Adelaide, where he died.
==Recognition== His widow endowed a prize for botany at the [[University of Adelaide]] in his name from 1912.<ref>http://trove.nla.gov.au/work/162342676?sortby=dateDesc&q=%22of+John+Bagot%22&c=picture</ref>
==Family== [[Charles Hervey Bagot]] "Captain Bagot" (c. 17 April 1788 – 29 July 1880) married Mary MacCarthy ( – 17 January 1860) around 1815. They emigrated on the ''Birman'', arriving in South Australia in December 1840. He was a member of the [[South Australian Legislative Council|Legislative Council]] for a number of terms between 1844 and 1869. Among their descendants were: *Christopher Michael Bagot (1817 – 8 November 1853) married Margaret Elizabeth Watts (ca.1823 – 6 November 1910) on 6 August 1846. Margaret was the eldest daughter of [[John Cliffe Watts]]. :*Charles Hervey Bagot [[Order of the Bath|C.B.]] (18 May 1847 – 8 November 1911) married Laura Mildred Daniel ( – 15 August 1879) on 22 July 1874 :*'''John Bagot''' J.P. (10 January 1849 – 29 August 1910) married Lucy Josephine Ayers (ca.1857 – 11 May 1945), daughter of [[Henry Ayers|Sir Henry]] on 24 September 1878. ::*[[Walter Bagot (architect)|Walter Hervey Bagot]] (17 March 1880 – 27 February 1889), noted architect, founding partner in [[Woods Bagot|Woods and Bagot]] ::*Henry Charles Hervey Bagot (25 January 1886 – 27 February 1889) <!--::*son 19 October 1891--> :*Mary Jane Bagot (23 July 1850 – 2 November 1901) married George Mathieson Turnbull (ca. 1840 – 29 November 1885) on 12 December 1868. Died at "Leith House" Barton Terrace. ::*George Bagot Turnbull (7 May 1876 – 1 December 1911) married Elsie Stewart Patterson. :::*[[Don Turnbull (tennis)|Don Turnbull]] (28 May 1909 – 30 January 1994) was a prominent tennis player and squash champion. :*Christopher Michael Bagot Jr. (15 June 1852 – 8 October 1899) married Eleanor Mary Hawker (1855 – 11 January 1939) on 1 February 1878. :*Margaret Elizabeth Bagot Jr. (3 May 1854 – 10 August 1929). *Mary Elizabeth Bagot (ca.1822 – 20 January 1892) married William Jacob (ca.1815 – 14 July 1902) on 31 August 1842. William was a draftsman with [[Col. William Light]]<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article4860713 |title=Personal |newspaper=[[The Advertiser (Adelaide)|The Advertiser]] |location=Adelaide |date=16 July 1902 |accessdate=23 March 2012 |page=4 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> [[Jacobs Creek (Australia)|Jacobs Creek]] is named for their family.<ref>Tolley, Julie Holbrook [http://www.history.sa.gov.au/chu/programs/history_conference/History%20Conf%2007/Stewed%20cockatoo%20and%20a%20glass%20of%20Grenache%20-%20Julie%20Holbrook%20Tol.pdf ''Stewed Cockatoo and a Glass of Grenache''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110328195031/http://www.history.sa.gov.au/chu/programs/history_conference/History%20Conf%2007/Stewed%20cockatoo%20and%20a%20glass%20of%20Grenache%20-%20Julie%20Holbrook%20Tol.pdf |date=28 March 2011 }}</ref> *[[Edward Meade Bagot|Edward Meade "Ned" Bagot]] (13 December 1822 – 24 July 1886) married Mary Pettman (1830 – 5 March 1855) on 1 August 1853. He married again, to Anne Smith, née Walworth ( – 16 February 1892), on 30 July 1857. :*Allan Walter Bagot (24 March 1874 – ) *Charlotte Owen Bagot (1824 – 22 October 1893) married Captain [[William H. Maturin]] C.B. (1814–1889) on 2 October 1845 *Sir Charles Samuel Bagot (1828 – 21 July 1906) married Lucy Francisca Hornby on 29 July 1851 in [[Lancaster, England]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Bagot, John}} [[Category:Members of the South Australian House of Assembly]] [[Category:Australian businesspeople]] [[Category:1849 births]] [[Category:1910 deaths]] [[Category:People from Kapunda, South Australia]]
