{{Orphan|date=March 2014}}
{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2012}} {{Infobox person | name = John Treasure | image = JAPT_Karsch.jpg | alt = John Treasure portrait by Yousuf Karsh | caption = John Treasure by [[Yousuf Karsh]]. | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1924|06|20}} | birth_place = [[Usk]], Monmouthshire | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|2004|02|09|1924|06|20}} | death_place = [[Kingston upon Thames]] | nationality = British | other_names = | known_for = Chairman [[J. Walter Thompson|J Walter Thompson]], vice chairman [[Saatchi & Saatchi]] | occupation = Advertising executive }}
'''John Treasure''' (20 June 1924 – 9 February 2004) was a leading figure in the British advertising industry in the 1960s, 70s and 80s. He was chairman of [[J. Walter Thompson|J Walter Thompson]] in the UK while it was the country's number one agency, and then vice chairman of [[Saatchi & Saatchi]] when it in turn held the number one position; he was also Dean of [[Cass Business School|City University Business School]] and Master of the [[Worshipful Company of Marketors]]. He was a potent proponent of the economic and social value of his industry, and became known as "Mr Advertising."
== Early life and rise in BMRB and JWT == John Albert Penberthy Treasure was born at [[Usk]], in [[Monmouthshire]], on 20 June 1924. The son of a bank clerk, he was brought up in [[Cardiff]], where he was educated at the High School, and went on to take first-class honours in economics at University College, then part of the [[University of Wales]].<ref name="The Guardian" /> In 1947 he won a Kemsley Fellowship to spend two years in America. He returned to teach and read for a doctorate at [[Magdalene College, Cambridge]]; his thesis, ''On problems of the British export trade'', later had some influence on the reporting of balance of payments figures. Meanwhile, he made ends meet by offering guided tours of Cambridge's colleges which earned him £5 a day.<ref name="Telegraph" /> He met and married Valerie Bell during this period, and to finance his PhD studies, in 1952 he joined the British Market Research Bureau (BMRB). By 1957, he was BMRB's managing director; by 1960, director of the marketing and research department at its parent company, [[J. Walter Thompson|J Walter Thompson]]. While running this 60-strong department, he set up a research and development committee to plan and manage JWT's substantial research budget. Innovations during this period included the TV Attention Survey (a prototype of modern TV audience research which gave useful insights, enabled JWT to buy airtime better and became a remarkable new business tool) and the creative workshop, which tested new and experimental ideas with qualitative research. JWT became the standard bearer of modern market research and the theory of how advertising works, what it does and how to measure it.<ref name="The Times">[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/comment/obituaries/article1028027.ece The Times], 24 Feb 2004.</ref>
== 'Mr Advertising' == In 1967, at the age of 43, Treasure became JWT chairman. Between then and 1976, when he resigned, he presided over one of the most successful periods in the long life of that agency: under his chairmanship, JWT in the UK grew fourfold in recorded billings from £20 million to £80 million.<ref name="The Guardian">[https://www.theguardian.com/news/2004/feb/18/guardianobituaries.advertising The Guardian], obituary by Jeremy Bullmore, 18 Feb 2004.</ref> Treasure became a director of the J Walter Thompson company worldwide, becoming vice chairman in 1974, and was president of both the [[Institute of Practitioners in Advertising]] and the Market Research Society. He was also president of the National Advertising Benevolent Society and later of the [[History of Advertising Trust]], where he remained a governor until 2002; he also headed a [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]] committee on communications.<ref name="Telegraph" /> Not only to the advertising village, but also to a much wider world outside, he became known as ‘Mr Advertising’.<ref name="The Times" /> When he was the subject of [[Bernard Levin]]'s chat show The Levin Interview in 1966,<ref name="Levin">[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1743583/ The Levin Interview], aired 5 April 1966.</ref> the television critic of [[The Sunday Times]] wrote: “On the level of civil, intelligent Q&A it was very good. A good deal of rubbish that is talked about advertising, from both sides, was sensibly disposed of.”<ref name="The Times" />
== Academia and the Saatchis == He left the agency world in 1977 at the age of 52 to become Dean and Professor of Marketing at the [[Cass Business School|City University Business School]], where in four years he raised the school's profile, expanded its range and secured new professorial posts and premises.<ref name="Telegraph" /> He returned to the commercial advertising world in 1980, running his own agency John Treasure and Partners, which then merged with Freeman Mathews Milne to become Freeman Mathews Treasure, before the Saatchi brothers, possibly in recognition of the role he had played in suggesting them to [[Margaret Thatcher]] for the Conservative Party account, invited him to become vice-chairman of their rapidly growing agency. He joined [[Saatchi & Saatchi]] in 1983, and added weight and gravitas to the predominantly young and aggressive management team there for several years.
== Taylor Nelson and the Marketors == In 1989 he moved back to his first love, market research, to become chairman of [[Taylor Nelson Sofres|Taylor Nelson AGB plc]], and presided over its acquisition of Sofres to become the world’s number two market research group. In the Millennium year he was a well-connected, highly regarded Master of the [[Worshipful Company of Marketors]].<ref name="The Times" /> He retired the following year, and though he was active in [[Richmond, London|Richmond, Surrey]] (he chaired the Friends of Old Deer Park and raised money for [[Richmond Theatre]] and the Museum of Richmond)<ref name="The Times" /> his health declined from then on.
== Character and influence == Colleague and industry commentator Jeremy Bullmore wrote: "Although he retained a certain reserve all his life, Treasure was always possessed of presence; he commanded attention. He chaired meetings and spoke in public with natural confidence and evident enjoyment.... The source of this authority was a clear and analytical mind, combined with an enviable ability to express complicated thoughts in jargon-free language.... Treasure's intellectual curiosity, his withering contempt for flabby thinking and his fascination with theory had a liberating effect on others. His presence seemed to grant implicit permission to experiment, to speculate and to innovate."<ref name="The Guardian" />
Possibly the best evidence of Treasure’s intense focus and competitive nature came from golf. He took up the game at the age of 50, becoming an active member of Royal Mid-Surrey Golf Club – and within five years, with RMS professional David Talbot, he had become good enough to compete in the [http://www.pga.info/PGANationalProAmChampionship/40868009.htm State Express 555 National Pro-Am Championship] at Penina in Portugal. He holed a 40-footer on the 18th green to draw level with the leaders, and the pair went on to win the play-off;<ref name="PGA">[http://www.pga.info/PGANationalProAmChampionship/40868009.htm PGA] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101129031356/http://www.pga.info/PGANationalProAmChampionship/40868009.htm |date=29 November 2010 }}, National Pro-Am website.</ref> at the winners' press conference, Treasure revealed that he had dreamed the night before that he would win with just such a putt, provoking the [[Daily Mail]] headline "Prophetic Prof Sinks Dream Putt".<ref name="Telegraph">[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/1454437/Professor-John-Treasure.html The Daily Telegraph], 16 Feb 2004.</ref> Good publicity was in his nature.
John Treasure's influence on the advertising profession and its image in the UK was significant and lasting: [[Maurice Saatchi, Baron Saatchi|Maurice (later Baron) Saatchi]] called him “one of the great figures of advertising”.<ref name="Telegraph" /> Hamish Pringle, the IPA director-general, said: "With John's passing we have lost another giant of UK advertising. His contribution to the industry was enormous."<ref name="Campaign">[http://www.campaignlive.co.uk/news/203128/Former-JWT-chief-John-Treasure-dies-aged-79/?DCMP=ILC-SEARCH Campaign Magazine], 20 Feb 2004.</ref>
John Treasure died in Kingston Hospital on 9 February 2004. His papers from his time at JWT are stored as the John Treasure Collection at the [[History of Advertising Trust]].<ref name="HAT">[http://www.hatads.org.uk/hat/newsitem.php?A=127&C=22 The History of Advertising Trust] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110720001506/http://www.hatads.org.uk/hat/newsitem.php?A=127&C=22 |date=20 July 2011 }}, website.</ref>
== References == <references/>
== Additional sources == * Financial Times, London: 19.02.04 * Sunday Times, London: profile 09.10.77 * New Society Magazine, London: 17.1.74 * South Wales Echo, Cardiff: 3 Feb 1966
{{DEFAULTSORT:Treasure, John}} [[Category:2004 deaths]] [[Category:1924 births]] [[Category:Advertising people]] [[Category:Academics of City, University of London]] [[Category:People from Cardiff]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.3beta8)
revision.text:
'''[[Ratu]] Josateki Tuivanuavou Nacagilevu Nawalowalo''' (1950 – 27 August 2010), commonly known as '''Ratu Jo Nawalowalo''', was a [[Fiji]]an [[Ratu|chief]], businessman, and the chairman of the [[Kadavu Provincial Council]]. He also chaired the [[Fiji Kava Council]], which promotes the sale of [[Kava|yaqona]] locally and internationally.
As chairman of the Provincial Council, Nawalowalo promoted aggressive infrastructural development programs. He also strongly supported the central government of [[Prime Minister of Fiji|Prime Minister]] [[Laisenia Qarase]], and refused to let [[Republic of Fiji Military Forces|Military]] teams tour Kadavu to campaign against the government's controversial [[Reconciliation, Tolerance, and Unity Bill]], which Nawalowalo strongly supported.
On 29 March 2006, Nawalowalo expressed interest in contesting the [[Kadavu (Fijian Communal Constituency, Fiji)|Kadavu]] [[Fijians|Fijian]] [[Communal constituencies|Communal Constituency]] for the ruling [[Soqosoqo Duavata ni Lewenivanua]] Party (SDL), but ended up withdrawing in favour of the incumbent, [[Konisi Yabaki]].
In the aftermath of the [[2006 Fijian coup d'état|military takeover]] of 5 December 2006, Nawalowalo changed his views, and threw his support behind the new regime.<ref>{{cite news|title=It's time for a cleansing exercise|url=http://www.fijitimes.com/story.aspx?id=52986|publisher=[[Fiji Times]]|date=December 6, 2006}}</ref> This provoked an angry reaction from some of his fellow chiefs, who were reported by [[Fiji Television]] on 9 December as instructing him to refrain from making any further public statements without their approval.<ref>{{cite news |title=Chiefs instruct Provincial Council Chairman not to issue public statements on crisis, without approval |url=http://www.fijitv.com.fj/index.cfm?go=tv.resources&cmd=forumview&cbegin=0&uid=fijionenews&cid=10745 |publisher=[[Fiji Television]] |date=December 9, 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928004219/http://www.fijitv.com.fj/index.cfm?go=tv.resources&cmd=forumview&cbegin=0&uid=fijionenews&cid=10745 |archivedate=2007-09-28 |df= }}</ref> In May 2008, he was not returned as chairman of the Kadavu Provincial Council.<ref>{{cite web|title=Kadavu Council defeat has no bearing on Nawalowalo's Fiji GCC task work|url=http://www.radionz.co.nz/international/pacific-news/177269/kadavu-council-defeat-has-no-bearing-on-nawalowalo's-fiji-gcc-task-work|website=Radio New Zealand International|publisher=Radio New Zealand International|accessdate=16 June 2015}}</ref>
Nawalowalo co-chaired the task force focusing on economic growth within the [[National Council for Building a Better Fiji]].<ref>[http://www.flp.org.fj/n080723.htm "Flawed democracy"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081120194844/http://www.flp.org.fj/n080723.htm |date=2008-11-20 }}, Fiji Labour Party website, July 23, 2008</ref>
Nawalowalo died 27 August 2010, aged 60.<ref>[https://archive.is/20110717092010/http://www.radiofiji.com.fj/fullstory.php?id=30500 ]</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Nawalowalo, Josateki}} [[Category:1950 births]] [[Category:Fijian chiefs]] [[Category:People from Kadavu Province]] [[Category:2010 deaths]] [[Category:Fijian businesspeople]]
{{Fiji-bio-stub}}

{{Infobox building |name = Justice Complex Center |image = Justice Center complex, Cleveland.jpg |alt = Street level view of group of buildings with tower, jail, parking garage |caption = Courts Tower (rear) and Jail II (left foreground) |location = 1200 Ontario Street, [[Cleveland]], [[Ohio]], U.S. |building_type = Government office building |architectural_style = [[Brutalist architecture|Brutalist]] |address = 1200 Ontario Street (Courts Tower);
1300 Ontario Street (Police);
1215 West 3rd Street (Corrections Center) |coordinates = {{coord|41.501664|N|81.696828|W|display=inline,title}} |floor_count = 25 (Courts Tower);
11 (Jail II);
10 (Corrections Center);
9 (Police Headquarters) |start_date = 1972 |completion_date = 1976 (Courts Tower, Corrections Center, Police Headquarters);
1995 (Jail II) |roof = {{convert|128.1|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} (Court Towers) |architect = [[Prindle, Patrick and Associates]] (Court Towers and Correction Center [Jail I]);
[[Richard L. Bowen and Associates]] (Cleveland Police Headquarters);
[[Robert P. Madison International]] (Jail II) }} The '''Justice Center Complex''' is a building complex located in the [[Civic Center (Cleveland)|Civic Center]] District in [[Cleveland]], [[Ohio]], in the United States. The complex consists of the '''Cleveland Police Headquarters Building''', the '''Cuyahoga County and Cleveland Municipal Courts Tower''', and the '''Correction Center''' (Jail I), and '''Jail II'''. It occupies a city block bounded by Lakeside Avenue, Ontario Street, West 3rd Street, and St. Clair Avenue. The Lakeside Avenue entrance faces the [[Cuyahoga County Court House]], erected in 1912. ==About the Justice Center== When the Justice Center was proposed in 1969, then-Mayor [[Carl B. Stokes]] did not want to be part of the Justice Center project. At the time, the Cleveland Police were at an older headquarters on East 22nd Street. In 1971, voters elected Mayor [[Ralph Perk]], who accepted the police department recommendation to move to the proposed Justice Center. The original cost for the Justice Center was set at $60 million, but infighting between Cuyahoga County and City of Cleveland officials escalated the cost to $128 million. On October 20, 1972, ground was broken for the Justice Center. Construction was complete in 1976. The Courts Tower component, 26 stories high, was designed by [[Prindle, Patrick and Associates]].{{cite news |first=Michael |last=Norman |title=Cleveland: A Brutalist Tour |url=http://blog.cleveland.com/pdextra/2007/06/cleveland_a_brutalist_tour.html |work=The Plain Dealer|date=June 21, 2007 |accessdate=July 7, 2010}} Jail I was built in 1976, when the rest of the construction of the complex was completed. It had 956 beds, arranged in pods of 23, and each pod was designed to take extensive advantage of natural light. The Courts Tower has been criticized by Steven Litt in ''[[The Plain Dealer]]'' as menacing, cold, and distracting. In 1995, the Robert P. Madison International-designed, $68 million Jail II was erected on the southern corner of the block.{{cite news|last=Litt|first=Steven|title=Jail II At Justice Center Could Scare Crooks Straight|work=The Plain Dealer|date=May 28, 1995|page=K3}} A suburban location was considered for the facility, but county officials found it was cheaper to demolish two older structures next to the Justice Center. Jail II added 480 beds. Determined to avoid cost overruns on the structure, Jail II was left without stone cladding—which made it clash with the three buildings beside it. Jail II was harshly criticized by Steven Litt in ''[[The Plain Dealer]]'' as "straight out of ''[[Nineteen Eighty-Four|1984]]''" and for clashing with historic structures in the nearby [[Warehouse District, Cleveland|Warehouse District]]. A four-story atrium exists in the center of the block, and serves as the secure public entry to the complex.{{cite news|last=Farkas|first=Karen|title=Cuyahoga County needs new downtown courthouse and jail, officials say|work=The Plain Dealer|date=September 30, 2015|accessdate=March 21, 2016|url=http://www.cleveland.com/cuyahoga-county/index.ssf/2015/09/cuyahoga_county_needs_new_downtown_courthouse_and_jail_officials_say.html}} The atrium helps resolve ground-level changes at the site, and connects the Courts Tower, Police Headquarters, and Correction Center (Jail I) structures internally. The north, south, and east walls of the atrium are glass curtain walls. An enclosed, elevated walkway connects Jail I and Jail II, while an enclosed walkway connects Cleveland Police Headquarters with Jail II. The entire complex contains about {{convert|2300000|sqft|m2}} of interior space. The bases of both the Cleveland Police Headquarters and the Correction Center are deeply recessed with a regular spacing of bays and perimeter columns. Bronze tinted glass enhances the play of shadow upon the surface of the structures. Cleveland Police Headquarters and the atrium are set much further back from Ontario Street than the Courts Tower. An open paved plaza occupies this space. Located at the northwestern end of this plaza is the [[Isamu Noguchi]] sculpture, ''Portal'', donated by the Gund Foundation in 1977. The $100,000, {{convert|36|ft|m|adj=on}} high sculpture was cast by the Patterson-Leitch Company of Cleveland. It is one of [[Isamu Noguchi]]'s famous sculptures, and the most recognizable symbol of the Justice Center. One Cleveland art critic said ''Portal'' looked like "justice going down the drain".{{cite book|last=Campen|first=Richard N.|title=Outdoor Sculpture in Ohio|location=Chagrin Falls, Ohio|publisher=West Summit Press|date=1980|isbn=9780960135622|page=145}} But artist [[John Clague]] highly praised it, and sculptor [[Clement Meadmore]] says it is Noguchi's best work. ===Renovations=== The granite veneer of the Courts Tower, Police Headquarters, and Corrections Center underwent a $3.2 million refurbishment in 1995. A $13 million renovation of the Corrections Center and Jail II was completed in 1999.{{cite news|last=Rollenhagen|first=Mark|title=Whole Cuyahoga Jail Floor Stood Empty|work=The Plain Dealer|date=May 21, 1999|page=B1|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|last=Sweeney|first=James F.|title=County Seeking Millions for Jails Bond Issue|work=The Plain Dealer|date=October 22, 1998|page=B2}} The renovations increased the capacity of Jail I to 1,749 beds.{{cite news|last=Dissell|first=Rachel|title=County Jail operating beyond capacity|work=The Plain Dealer|date=November 14, 2014|page=A6}} ==Future of the Justice Complex== In 2013, [[Cuyahoga County, Ohio|Cuyahoga County]] officials commissioned a study from Osborne Engineering to assess the condition of the Justice Center Complex. The report, issued in spring 2014, found that the Justice Center Complex was in significant disrepair. The study cited significant architectural and construction issues which have affected the longevity of the three original structures, and Cuyahoga County Public Works Director Michael Dever said the electrical system, plumbing, elevators, and [[HVAC]] system all need replacing. The structures also have little capacity for modern communications and computer systems (such as [[broadband]] telecommunications), and currently systems are installed in insecure or temporary fashions. The buildings were not constructed to accommodate [[Wi-Fi]] or [[mobile phone]]s, neither of which can be accommodated in many parts of the complex. The cost of renovation was pegged at a minimum of $300 million. The Osborne Engineering report estimated the cost of new construction at $429 million, which involved demolishing the Cleveland police headquarters and the Courts Tower and constructing a one or two new buildings in their place. County officials came to the preliminary conclusion that the Justice Complex should be demolished, and a new "justice center" erected elsewhere in downtown Cleveland. Cuyahoga County Council member Michael Gallagher told ''[[The Plain Dealer]]'' newspaper that advances in corrections design made the existing Corrections Center/Jail I significantly outdated. He also claimed that renovations could not correct the design and other deficiencies of the buildings. But county officials emphasized that no alternative site had been identified, and no budget proposals or even preliminary architectural discussions had occurred. ==In Popular Culture== The Justice Center Complex plays an important role in the third season of the [[Serial (podcast)|Serial Podcast]]. The season opens with a general description of day-to-day lives inside the complex and then focusses on specific cases being handled and (sometimes) trialled in the building. Several of the audio recordings take place inside the complex and feature the host, [[Sarah Koenig]], discussing and interviewing those involved in the cases.https://www.theverge.com/2018/9/23/17887612/serial-season-3-review-sarah-koenig-cleveland-criminal-justice-system {{clear}} ==See also== *[[List of tallest buildings in Cleveland]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== *Toman, James. ''Cleveland's Changing Skyline'', 1984. Cleveland Landmarks Press. {{ISBN|0-936760-03-6}}. ==External links== * [https://clevelandmunicipalcourt.org/home Cleveland Municipal Court] * [http://sheriff.cuyahogacounty.us/en-US/Cuyahoga-County-Corrections-Center.aspx Cuyahoga County Corrections Center] * [http://cp.cuyahogacounty.us/internet/index.aspx Cuyahoga County Court of Common Pleas] {{Ohio County Courthouses}} [[Category:Government buildings completed in 1976]] [[Category:Government buildings completed in 1995]] [[Category:Brutalist architecture in Ohio]] [[Category:Cleveland Division of Police]] [[Category:Police headquarters]] [[Category:County courthouses in Ohio]] [[Category:Jails in Ohio]] [[Category:Skyscraper office buildings in Cleveland]] [[Category:Downtown Cleveland]]

{{Infobox person |name = Khaled Juffali |image = |image_size = |caption = |birth_name = Khaled bin Ahmed Al Juffali |birth_date = |birth_place = |death_date = |death_place = |residence = |nationality = Saudi |ethnicity = |citizenship = |other_names = |known_for = Vice chairman of [[E. A. Juffali and Brothers]] |education = [[Brummana High School]]
[[Institut Le Rosey]] |alma_mater = [[University of San Diego]] |occupation = |years_active = |home_town = |salary = |networth = |title = |term = |predecessor = |successor = |boards = |religion = |spouse = Olfat Al-Mutlaq Juffali |partner = |children = 4 |parents = [[Ahmed Juffali|Ahmed Abdullah Juffali]] |relations = [[Walid Juffali]] (brother) |website = }} '''Khaled Juffali''' is a [[Saudi]] businessman. ==Early life== Juffali is the son of [[Ahmed Juffali|Ahmed Abdullah Juffali]] (1924-1994),{{cite web|title=The Al Juffali family|url=http://www.arabianbusiness.com/arabian-business-rich-list-2010-367763.html?view=profile&itemid=367819|website=arabianbusiness|accessdate=11 November 2015}} the founder of [[E. A. Juffali and Brothers]], one of Saudi Arabia's largest companies.{{cite book|author=Stig Stenslie|title=Regime Stability in Saudi Arabia: The Challenge of Succession|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-g81rF4Zga4C&pg=PA60|accessdate=18 November 2015|date=21 August 2012|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-136-51157-8|page=60}} His younger brother is the billionaire [[Walid Juffali]], and his sister is Maha Juffali.{{cite news|title=Strength in numbers|url=http://www.philanthropyage.org/2013/04/23/strength-in-numbers/|accessdate=11 November 2015|work=philanthropyage|date=23 April 2013}} His brother Tarek Juffali died in 2006 from a drug overdose, and had been "a heavy heroin and cocaine user and also took Rohypnol and smoked 30 cannabis joints a day".{{cite news|title=Saudi billionaire's son living in Britain died from drug overdose weeks before his wife had twins|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1035702/Saudi-billionaires-son-living-Britain-died-drug-overdose-weeks-wife-twins.html|accessdate=11 November 2015|work=The Daily Mail|date=17 July 2008}} He was educated at [[Brummana High School]] in Lebanon and [[Institut Le Rosey]] in Switzerland, and received a bachelor's degree in Business Administration from the [[University of San Diego]], California, US, in 1979. ==Career== Juffali is a managing partner and vice chairman at [[E. A. Juffali and Brothers]].{{cite web|title=Executive Profile Khaled Juffali|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=29602156&privcapId=116949690|website=Bloomberg L.P.|accessdate=18 November 2015}} Juffali is chairman of ReAya Holding, Saudi Tractors Manufacturing, National Automobile Industry, Saudi Ericsson Communications, Fluor Daniel Arabia, and Raychem Saudi Arabia. ==Personal life== He is married to fellow Saudi, Olfat Al-Mutlaq Juffali, and they have four children together.{{cite web|title=Olfat Al-Mutlaq Juffali|url=http://www.arabculturefund.org/about/board.php?id=14|website=arabculturefund|accessdate=18 November 2015}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Juffali, Khaled }} [[Category:1950s births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Alumni of Institut Le Rosey]] [[Category:Juffali family|Khaled]] [[Category:People from Jeddah]] [[Category:Saudi Arabian businesspeople]] [[Category:University of San Diego alumni]]

revision.text:
The '''lead chamber process''' was an industrial method used to produce [[sulfuric acid]] in large quantities. It has been largely supplanted by the [[contact process]].
In 1746 in [[Birmingham]], England, [[John Roebuck]] began producing [[sulfuric acid]] in [[lead]]-lined chambers, which were stronger and less expensive, and could be made much larger, than the [[glass]] containers which had been used previously. This allowed the effective industrialization of sulfuric acid production and, with several refinements, this process remained the standard method of production for almost two centuries. So robust was the process that as late as 1946, the chamber process still accounted for 25% of sulfuric acid manufactured.<ref>Edward M. Jones, "Chamber Process Manufacture of Sulfuric Acid", ''Industrial and Engineering Chemistry'', Nov 1950, Vol 42, No. 11, pp 2208–10.</ref>
== Process == [[Sulfur dioxide]] is introduced with steam and [[nitrogen dioxide]] into large chambers lined with sheet [[lead]] where the gases are sprayed down with water and [[chamber acid]] (62–70% Sulfuric acid). The sulfur dioxide and nitrogen dioxide dissolve and over a period of approximately 30 minutes the sulfur dioxide is oxidized to sulfuric acid. The presence of nitrogen dioxide is necessary for the reaction to proceed at a reasonable rate. The process is highly [[exothermic]], and a major consideration of the design of the chambers was to provide a way to dissipate the heat formed in the reactions.
Early plants used very large lead-lined wooden rectangular chambers (Faulding box chambers) that were cooled by ambient air. The internal lead sheathing served to contain the corrosive sulfuric acid and to render the wooden chambers waterproof. Around the turn of the nineteenth century, such plants required about half a cubic meter of volume to process the sulfur dioxide equivalent of a kilogram of burned sulfur.{{citation needed|reason=Great fact worthy of inclusion here, but I can't find supporting data.|date=March 2014}} In the mid-19th century, French chemist [[Joseph Louis Gay-Lussac|Gay-Lussac]] redesigned the chambers as stoneware packed masonry cylinders. In the 20th century, plants using Mills-Packard chambers supplanted the earlier designs. These chambers were tall tapered cylinders that were externally cooled by water flowing down the outside surface of the chamber.
Sulfur dioxide for the process was provided by burning [[sulfur|elemental sulfur]] or by the [[Roasting (metallurgy)|roasting]] of [[Sulfide mineral|sulfur-containing metal ores]] in a stream of air in a furnace. During the early period of manufacture, nitrogen oxides were produced by the decomposition of [[nitre|niter]] at high temperature in the presence of acid, but this process was gradually supplanted by the air oxidation of [[ammonia]] to [[nitric oxide]] in the presence of a catalyst. The recovery and reuse of oxides of nitrogen was an important economic consideration in the operation of a chamber process plant.
In the reaction chambers, nitric oxide reacts with oxygen to produce [[nitrogen dioxide]]. Liquid from the bottom of the chambers is diluted and pumped to the top of the chamber and sprayed downwards in a fine mist. Sulfur dioxide and nitrogen dioxide are absorbed in the liquid and react to form sulfuric acid and nitric oxide. The liberated nitric oxide is sparingly soluble in water and returns to the gas in the chamber where it reacts with oxygen in the air to reform nitrogen dioxide. Some percentage of the nitrogen oxides are sequestered in the reaction liquor as [[nitrosylsulfuric acid]] and as nitric acid, so fresh nitric oxide must be added as the process proceeds. Later versions of chamber plants included a high-temperature Glover tower to recover the nitrogen oxides from the chamber liquor, while concentrating the chamber acid to as much as 78% H<sub>2</sub>SO<sub>4</sub>. Exhaust gases from the chambers are scrubbed by passing into a tower through which some of the Glover acid flows over broken tile. Nitrogen oxides are absorbed to form nitrosylsulfuric acid, which is then returned to the Glover tower to reclaim the oxides of nitrogen.
Sulfuric acid produced in the reaction chambers is limited to about 35% concentration. At higher concentrations, nitrosylsulfuric acid precipitates on the lead walls as [[nitrosylsulfuric acid|chamber crystals]] and is no longer able to [[Catalysis|catalyze]] the oxidation reactions.<ref>F. A. Gooch and C. F. Walker, ''Outlines of Inorganic Chemistry'', MacMillan, London, 1905, pp 274.</ref>
== Chemistry == Sulfur dioxide is generated by burning elemental [[sulfur]] or by roasting [[pyrite|pyritic ore]] in a current of air:
:S<sub>8</sub> + 8 O<sub>2</sub> → 8 SO<sub>2</sub> :4 FeS<sub>2</sub> + 11 O<sub>2</sub> → 2 Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> + 8 SO<sub>2</sub>
Nitrogen oxides are produced by decomposition of [[nitre|niter]] in the presence of sulfuric acid or hydrolysis of [[nitrosylsulfuric acid]]:
:2 NaNO<sub>3</sub> + H<sub>2</sub>SO<sub>4</sub> → Na<sub>2</sub>SO<sub>4</sub> + H<sub>2</sub>O + NO + NO<sub>2</sub> + O<sub>2</sub> :2 NOHSO<sub>4</sub> + H<sub>2</sub>O → 2 H<sub>2</sub>SO<sub>4</sub> + NO + NO<sub>2</sub>
In the reaction chambers, sulfur dioxide and nitrogen dioxide dissolve in the reaction liquor. Nitrogen dioxide is hydrated to produce [[nitrous acid]] which then oxidizes the sulfur dioxide to sulfuric acid and nitric oxide. The reactions are not well characterized but it is known that nitrosylsulfuric acid is an intermediate in at least one pathway. The major overall reactions are:
:2 NO<sub>2</sub> + H<sub>2</sub>O → HNO<sub>2</sub> + HNO<sub>3</sub> :SO<sub>2</sub> (aq) + HNO<sub>3</sub> → NOHSO<sub>4</sub> :NOHSO<sub>4</sub> + HNO<sub>2</sub> → H<sub>2</sub>SO<sub>4</sub> + NO<sub>2</sub> + NO :SO<sub>2</sub> (aq) + 2 HNO<sub>2</sub> → H<sub>2</sub>SO<sub>4</sub> + 2 NO
Nitric oxide escapes from the reaction liquor and is subsequently reoxidized by molecular oxygen to nitrogen dioxide. This is the overall rate determining step in the process:<ref>Jones, pp 2209.</ref>
:2 NO + O<sub>2</sub> → 2 NO<sub>2</sub>
Nitrogen oxides are absorbed and regenerated in the process, and thus serve as a [[catalysis|catalyst]] for the overall reaction:
:2 SO<sub>2</sub> + 2 H<sub>2</sub>O + O<sub>2</sub> → 2 H<sub>2</sub>SO<sub>4</sub>
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
== Further reading == * {{cite book | author = Derry, Thomas Kingston |author2=Williams, Trevor I. | year = 1993 | title = A Short History of Technology: From the Earliest Times to A.D. 1900 | location = New York | publisher = Dover }} * {{cite web | title = Sulfuric Acid: Pumping Up the Volume | author = Kiefer, David M. | year = 2001 | publisher = American Chemical Society | url = http://pubs.acs.org/subscribe/journals/tcaw/10/i09/html/09chemch.html | accessdate = 2008-04-21}}
==External links== * [http://www.inclusive-science-engineering.com/manufacture-of-h2so4-by-chamber-process/manufacture-of-h2so4-by-chamber-process-2/ Process flow sheet of sulphuric acid manufacturing by lead chamber process]
<!-- Categories --> [[Category:Industrial processes]] [[Category:Lead]] [[Category:Sulfur]] [[Category:Catalysis]]

{{Chinese |pic=06.19 總統接見「貝里斯眾議院塔蘿拉暨參議院議長鄭經緯一行」 (Flickr id 41080872310).jpg |t = 鄭經緯 |s = 郑经纬 |p = Zhèng Jīngwěi }}
'''Lee Mark Chang''' is a [[Belize]]an politician and restaurateur. A member of the [[United Democratic Party (Belize)|United Democratic Party]], he was the first [[Ethnic Chinese in Belize|ethnic Chinese]] person to hold the post of [[President of the Senate of Belize|President]] (''[[pro tempore]]'') of the [[Senate of Belize]].<ref name="Reporter20100820">{{cite news|url=http://www.reporter.bz/index.php?mod=archive&act=view&article=4557|title=Belize's first Chinese President of the Senate|work=The Belize Reporter|date=2010-08-20|accessdate=2012-04-24}}</ref>
==Career==
===Early career=== Lee got his start in life working at the Chon Saan Palace restaurant which his father Armando Chang opened in 1974. From a small family restaurant, under his management he grew it to a chain with three locations and fifty staff, making it "one of the biggest names in restaurants".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.7newsbelize.com/sstory.php?nid=12628|title=7 On the Inside of Chon Saan Palace's Kitchen|work=7 News Belize|date=2008-11-12|accessdate=2012-04-22}}</ref> He also became the president of the Chinese Association of Belize.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://edition.channel5belize.com/archives/13922|title=Chinese-Belizeans celebrate New Year|work= News 5 Belize|date=2004-01-22|accessdate=2012-04-24}}</ref> Under his tenure as president, the CAB worked closely with the [[Belize Police Department]] on issues of crime prevention, and also donated several motorcycles.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://7newsbelize.com/sstory.php?nid=16923|title=The Chinese Community’s Contribution|work=7 News Belize|date=2010-05-18|accessdate=2012-04-24}}</ref> He also served in a variety of public positions, for example sitting on the Belize District Liquor Licensing board and working as an occasional court translator.<ref name="Amandala20090220">{{cite news|url=http://www.amandala.com.bz/index.php?id=8190|first=Aaron|last=Humes|title=Archie Lee and Wilmot square off!|work=[[Amandala]]|date=2009-02-20|accessdate=2012-04-22}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://belize.me.uk/2010/05/14/chinese-national-pays-fine/|title=Chinese National pays $1000 fine for frying chicken|work=Belize Local News|date=2010-05-14|accessdate=2012-04-24}}</ref>
===In politics=== Chang first announced his intention to join electoral politics in August 2009.<ref name="News520090806">{{cite news|url=http://edition.channel5belize.com/archives/904|title=Lee Mark Chang: 1 citizenship and 100% Belizean|work=News 5 Belize|date=2009-08-06|accessdate=2012-04-24}}</ref> In August 2010, [[Prime Minister of Belize|PM]] [[Dean Barrow]] appointed Chang to the Senate and made him acting President, to fill in for [[Andrea Gill]] who was on [[maternity leave]]. Politicians from both sides of the aisle such as the PUP's [[Lisa Shoman]] offered congratulations to him on what they described as "the epitome of Belize's cultural diversity" and an "important milestone" for Belize's Chinese community.<ref name="Reporter20100820"/>
Lee entered the [[Belizean general and local elections, 2012|2012 "double election"]] as the UDP's [[National Assembly of Belize|National Assembly]] candidate for the Freetown constituency. In the run-up to the election, an unknown person released a forged letter claiming to be from Chang, promising to distribute land in Belama to the Belize Chinese Association in exchange for campaign contributions.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://7newsbelize.com/sstory.php?nid=21897|title=Lee Mark Cries Foul in Freetown|work=7 News Belize|date=2012-02-29|accessdate=2012-04-22}}</ref> The ''[[Belize Times]]'' also published a number of racist comments about him.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.bz/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=4450:pup-trying-to-inject-racism-in-freetown&catid=53:headlines|first=Shane|last=Williams|title=PUP Trying to Inject Racism in Freetown|work=Belize Guardian|date=2012-03-01|accessdate=2012-04-22}}</ref> Lee lost the election to PUP party leader [[Francis Fonseca]] by 1,558 to 1,408 votes.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.lovetv.com.bz/2012/04/04/cj-approves-application-for-election-petition-against-francis-fonseca/|title=CJ approves application for election petition against Francis Fonseca|work=Love TV Belize|date=2012-04-04|accessdate=2012-04-24}}</ref> In early April Chang filed a motion for an [[election petition]] in April, alleging that Fonseca's agents engaged in bribery of the electorate. [[Chief Justice of Belize|Chief Justice]] [[Kenneth Benjamin (judge)|Kenneth Benjamin]] granted him leave to bring the petition; it was the first election petition in Belize's history to be granted on the grounds of bribery.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.7newsbelize.com/sstory.php?nid=22149|title=Bribery Petition Against PUP Leader Granted Leave To Be Heard|work=7 News Belize|date=2012-04-04|accessdate=2012-04-24}}</ref>
2015: He became the President of the Senate, after the United Democratic Party won their 3rd term.
==Personal life== Chang's parents are Chinese immigrants.<ref name="Reporter20100820"/> He was born at the former Holden Memorial Hospital on the Marine Parade in [[Belize City]].<ref name="News520090806"/>
==References== {{reflist|2}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Chang, Lee Mark}} [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Belizean people of Chinese descent]] [[Category:Members of the Senate (Belize)]] [[Category:People from Belize City]] [[Category:United Democratic Party (Belize) politicians]] [[Category:Belizean businesspeople]]

revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contribs/96.28.68.114|96.28.68.114]] ([[User talk:96.28.68.114|talk]]) to last version by Balon Greyjoy
revision.text:
'''Low-cost country sourcing''' (LCCS) is [[procurement]] strategy in which a company sources materials from countries with lower [[Workforce|labour]] and production costs in order to cut [[operating expense]]s.{{Citation needed|date=July 2009}} LCCS falls under a broad category of procurement efforts called [[global sourcing]].
The process of low-cost sourcing consists of two parties. The customer and the supplier countries like US, UK, Canada, Australia, and West European nations are considered as [[high-cost countries]] (HCC) whereas resource rich and regulated wage labor locations like [[China]], [[India]], [[Indonesia]], [[Bolivia]], [[Brazil]], [[Russia]], [[Mexico]], and [[East Europe]]an nations are considered [[low-cost countries]] (LCC). In low-cost-country sourcing the material ([[Product (business)|product]]s) flows from LCC to HCC while the [[technology]] flows from HCC to LCC.
The primary principle behind LCCS is to obtain sourcing efficiencies through identifying and exploiting cost [[arbitrage]] between geographies.
Aside from price other reasons for engaging in global sourcing can include improved manufacturing capacity/ time frames, quality of goods, improved customer services and logistics benefits.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.resource2source.com.au/thinking-space/low-cost-country-sourcing-2/|title=Low Cost Country Sourcing|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.diva-portal.org/smash/get/diva2:318924/fulltext01|title=Problems and Challenges of Global Sourcing|last=|first=|date=|website=J Ö N K Ö P I N G I N T E R N A T I O N A L B U S I N E S S S C H O O L|publisher=Master thesis within BUSINESS ADMINISTRATION|access-date=}}</ref>
==Destination== Not necessarily all "low cost countries" are destinations for LCCS. Only those countries with relatively stable political and economic [[PEST analysis|environment]], modern infrastructure and acceptably compatible legal system are considered to be ideal for sourcing. Examples and most popular regions are China, [[Indonesia]],<ref name=ibtimes/> [[Thailand]], [[Vietnam]],<ref name=ibtimes>http://www.ibtimes.com/india-asean-economies-become-next-china-manufacturing-foreign-direct-investment-fdi-1039684</ref> [[Malaysia]], [[Ethiopia]], [[India]], [[Ukraine]], [[Romania]], [[Bulgaria]], [[Mexico]], [[Bolivia]], [[Cambodia]], [[Hungary]] and [[Czech Republic]].
==Labour costs== Labour costs have been rising across Asia as Asians now are more willing to pay a premium for the products and services they receive and thus causing production cost to increase. Many countries in Asia have seen a rapid rise in wages since the late 2000s.<ref>{{cite report|title=Rural wages in Asia|author=Steve Wiggins and Sharada Keats|url=http://www.odi.org/sites/odi.org.uk/files/odi-assets/publications-opinion-files/9186.pdf|publisher= Overseas Development Institute|year=2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Asia Soaring Wages Mean Rising Prices Worldwide|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2013-04-02/asia-soaring-wages-stoke-inflation-as-factory-costs-rise|publisher=Bloomberg|year=2013}}</ref> One factor contributing to the wage rises is due to the shift of labour from agricultural work into more productive jobs in industry, labour [[productivity]] has increased quickly thus leading to [[wages|wage]] growth. Workers will demand for better wages as [[Singapore]]'s [[economic growth]] and [[living costs]] are gradually increasing. Businesses will thus face pressure on their [[profit margin]]s as rising [[labour costs]] leads to higher [[production costs]].
Labour costs in China and India have been increasing over the years. China was initially one of the lowest labour cost countries known. However, due to the rising demands of people and the increase in the cost of goods, China is no longer regarded as the ‘cheapest’ country to manufacture goods anymore. China is now deemed as less competitive compared to other countries. The increased labour costs have resulted in some foreign firms exiting the country, in search of countries where labour cost is cheaper, like [[Thailand]] and [[Philippines]]. Other countries apart from China are beginning to provide [[raw materials]] at a lower cost, leaving manufacturers with more choices as regards their suppliers.
A 2012 [[E&Y]] report says that "Wages have been pushed up by long-term decline in the aggregate [[labor force]], combined with a rapid depletion in [[rural]] [[surplus labor]], which has until recently provided an ultimate source of cheap labor,".<ref name=ey/> But it warned that the massive reallocation of labor "from low productivity agriculture to higher productivity manufacturing is coming to an end".<ref name=ey>http://www.ey.com/Publication/vwLUAssets/China_productivity_imperative_en/$FILE/China-Productivity-Imperative_en.pdf</ref> Even before the Chinese economy started to turn down, there were concerns that it was facing a [[middle income trap]], widely identified by economists as showing the danger of a [[Lewis Turning Point]], a phenomenon observed in history of Japan, which showed that rapid [[urbanization]] led to a growth in manufacturing. However, eventually, the phenomenon comes to an end as wages rise and the country's competitive edge disappears. The number of [[migrant worker]]s in China has been increasing at a slower pace since 2005.<ref name=ey/> Although there are 320 million laborers still in [[agriculture]], only 20 million have the potential to migrate to cities, pushing the country to a point at which "the excess labor in the [[subsistence]] sector is fully absorbed into the modern sector, and where further [[capital accumulation]] begins to increase wages" - pointing to a Lewis scenario.
===Situation in China=== [[Labor shortage]] is not yet a major problem in China, as there are still governmental measures to free up the pool of rural labor, such as the further easing of the [[hukou system|hukou]], or household registration, system. “However, these are unlikely to reverse the trend of increasing labor costs".<ref name=ey/> They will continue to rise as minimum wages and [[social welfare]] improve, adding that on top of the 13 percent annual increase in the minimum wage as set in the 12th [[Five-year plans of the People's Republic of China|Five-Year Plan]] (2011–15), mandatory social welfare will add another 35 to 40 percent to the payroll cost.<ref name=ey/>
Because there is a large supply of workers, especially in rural sector, wage growth for unskilled labor will grow slowly. At the same time, “wage growth for skilled labor will also likely taper off because of the convergence of college wage premiums to international standards in recent years and the anticipated robust supply of university graduates and professionals returning from overseas”.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Yang|first=Dennis Tao|last2=Chen|first2=Vivian Weijia|last3=Monarch|first3=Ryan|date=2010-10-01|title=Rising Wages: Has China Lost Its Global Labor Advantage?|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1468-0106.2009.00465.x/abstract|journal=Pacific Economic Review|language=en|volume=15|issue=4|pages=482–504|doi=10.1111/j.1468-0106.2009.00465.x|issn=1468-0106}}</ref> Therefore, overall wage will slowly grow in the near future.
"Rising wages are most significant to primary producers and services industries, as labor takes the major share of total costs in these sectors,".<ref name=ey/> Apart from labor, capital - still relatively cheap in China - will also become more expensive as policymakers move the country toward interest rate liberalization.<ref name=ey/> Material costs, too, will continue to rise and will reach global levels. As the economy slows down, it becomes harder and harder for companies to pass on the costs to customers. For example, India, being a poor country, will soon emerge to be the cheapest manufacturer.
China's rising labor costs will help other South Asian countries gain a foothold in low-end manufacturing.<ref name=cnbc>{{cite web|title=China Labor Cost Rise to Boost Rivals in Asia|author=Katy Barnato|publisher=CNBC|date=2013-01-17|url=https://www.cnbc.com/id/100387910}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *{{cite news|title=Higher productivity to counter rising labor costs|date=2012-09-26| journal=China Daily |url=http://www.ecns.cn/business/2012/09-26/28372.shtml}}
==See also== *[[Global sourcing]] *[[International trade]] *[[Offshore company]] *[[Offshore outsourcing]] *[[Offshore software R&D]] *[[Offshoring]] *[[Resource curse]]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Low-Cost Country Sourcing}} [[Category:Procurement]] [[Category:International trade]] [[Category:Global business organization]]

{{BLP refimprove|date=August 2017}} '''Melody Harris-Jensbach''' (born 1961) is a Korean-American Manager. Currently she is [[CEO]] of the [[Germany|German]] outdoor apparel and equipment producer [[Jack Wolfskin]].
==Career== She graduated at the [[Parsons School of Design]] in [[New York City]]. Due to her marriage, Melody Harris-Jensbach moved to [[Germany]] in 1986 where she first worked for the fashion firms Cartoon, Triangle and later became Head Designer for Viventy by Bernd Berger. In 1993 she became Chief Designer Women's wear and Accessories at [[Escada]]'s label Laurèl, and a few years later, Chief Design and Product Manager at Fink Modelle.
As a next step in her career, Harris-Jensbach took the position of Design Director Women's Wear at [[Esprit Holdings|Esprit]] in 1998. In 2003, she took on the responsibility as International Product Director Women, and in 2005 she also took over the Women's Casual Division, Esprit's core business.
As [[Puma AG|Puma]] had stated in June 2007,<ref name=puma20070604>{{cite web|url=http://about.puma.com/EN/3/23/23/?news_id=3&year=2007|title=Puma's news archive, 4th of June 2007|website=About.puma.com|accessdate=31 August 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080103023755/http://about.puma.com/EN/3/23/23/?news_id=3&year=2007|archivedate=3 January 2008|df=}}</ref> Melody Harris-Jensbach joined the company's Board of Management as Deputy CEO in January 2008. She took over the position from [[Martin Gänsler]] and is responsible for the areas Product, Product Development, Design, Business Unit Management and Worldwide Sourcing for the Retail Business. This made her the first female Deputy CEO of a German company.<ref name=spon20080128>{{cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/fotostrecke/fotostrecke-28467-10.html|title=Mächtige Frauen: Internationale Wirtschaftsgrößen|website=Spiegel.de|accessdate=31 August 2017}}</ref>
In November 2014, Harris-Jensbach has been nominated CEO of the Germany-based outdoor apparel and equipment producer Jack Wolfskin, a company owned by [[The Blackstone Group]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sportswearnet.com/businessnews/pages/protected/Melody-Harris-Jensbach-appointed-CEO-at-Jack-Wolfskin_8917.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-02-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150220165226/http://www.sportswearnet.com/businessnews/pages/protected/Melody-Harris-Jensbach-appointed-CEO-at-Jack-Wolfskin_8917.html |archivedate=2015-02-20 |df= }} </ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Harris-Jensbach, Melody}} [[Category:1961 births]] [[Category:German businesspeople]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American people of Korean descent]] [[Category:American women of Korean descent]]

[[File:Männerparkplatz Triberg.jpg|thumb|Woman parking on men's parking space (''Männer-Parkplatz'' sign behind vehicle) in Triberg]] '''Men's parking space''' is an [[antonym]] to [[women's parking space]].
Normally mentioned only in satire, in July 2012 two men's parking spaces were opened in [[Triberg]] in the [[Black Forest]] of [[Germany]]. Planned as a practical joke presenting a specific challenge to unskilled drivers, they produced worldwide media interest in the combination of humour to lampoon the idea of [[political correctness]] and of successful [[city marketing]].<ref name=Euronews>{{cite web|title=Triberg Mayor boosts carpark as tourist magnet|url=http://www.euronews.com/2012/07/10/germany-triberg-mayor-boosts-carpark-as-tourist-magnet|publisher=Euronews|date=10 July 2012|accessdate=30 June 2013}}</ref>
==Technical and local background== [[File:TRIORANG.jpg|thumb|plan of a level of the parking garage, men's parking slot with [[Mars symbol]]]] Triberg, a small city of five thousand inhabitants, has an extremely steep topography. It has waterfalls. In 2010, Triberg was reportedly visited by about 250,000 tourists per year,<ref Name="TEW">[http://www.badische-zeitung.de/suedwest-1/erlebniswelt-triberg-steht-vor-dem-aus--27998858.html Millionenprojekt Erlebniswelt Triberg steht vor dem Aus] Mo, 8. March 2010 00:04 [[Badische Zeitung]]</ref> most of whom came to see the waterfalls on a day-tour basis. After the [[September 11 attacks|9/11 attacks]], Americans, who had been frequent visitors, became less likely to visit. That and the decline of the local [[Watchmaker|watchmaking]] industry have caused problems for Triberg's economy.<ref name=ChicagoTribune>{{cite news|last=Siegert|first=Alice|title=Time Running Out For Clockmakers|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1987-03-12/news/8701200045_1_cuckoo-clockmakers-clock-shops|newspaper=Chicago Tribune|date=March 12, 1987}}</ref>
In 2007 Max-Dieter Mack {{Who|date=July 2013}} presented preliminary plans for a €90 million [[Amusement park]], ''Erlebniswelt Triberg,'' on a former industrial site in the municipality. Mack, an architect, is a Triberg native and relative of leisure park mogul [[Roland Mack]]. The parking garage at Kreuzstraße is the only planned building constructed so far. Mack was not commissioned for this.<ref Name="TEW"/> Instead of the theme park, a smaller shopping mall and some comparably humble attractions are now on schedule.<ref name="ga">[http://www.suedkurier.de/region/schwarzwald-baar-heuberg/triberg/Parkhaus-statt-Erlebniswelt;art410964,5541249 "Triberg Parkhaus statt Erlebniswelt"], suedkurier.de, 9 June 2012. (in German)</ref> The back of the parking garage is angled to follow the course of the [[Gutach (Kinzig)|River Gutach]]. Therefore, two parking bays, one on each level, have a peculiar shape and can be reached only by a complicated parking maneuver. Mayor Strobel and the architects, Judith Haas and Mattias Huismanns, deliberated about excluding those two bays from the garage of 220 bays, which was built for €2 million.<ref>[http://www.pz-news.de/baden-wuerttemberg_artikel,-Maennerparkplaetze-in-Triberg-Besonders-schwer-zu-beparken-_arid,354954.html ''"Männerparkplätze" in Triberg: Besonders schwer zu beparken''], [[Pforzheimer Zeitung]], 6. July 6th 2012</ref><ref>[https://www.welt.de/vermischtes/article107919900/Darum-gibt-es-in-Triberg-Parkplaetze-nur-fuer-Maenner.html ''Darum gibt es in Triberg Parkplätze nur für Männer''], ''Welt Online'', 6 July 2012. (in German)</ref>
Strobel decided to declare them ''men's parking spaces''. Per the state garage regulations in force in [[Baden-Wuerttemberg]], ten per cent of all stalls (numbering twelve and of the standard shape and size) had to be declared for women in any event<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dejure.org/gesetze/GaVO/4.html|title=§ 4 GaVO Stellplätze und Fahrgassen, Frauenparkplätze - dejure.org|work=dejure.org|accessdate=28 August 2015}}</ref>, but their misuse by men is not punishable according to the StVO (the federal ''Straßenverkehrsordnung'', or Highway Code of [[Germany]]). Accordingly, the only recourse available to property owners is to eject the misuser for trespassing or to tow his (or her) car; the operator of this particular garage (i.e. the government of the city of Triberg) declines to take either of these actions and instead appeals to the [[honour system]] in the case of the women's spaces and to the skill of the driver, whatsoever his or her sex, for the 'men's'.<ref name="fo"/>
==General background== {{see also|Women's parking space}} According to Ruth Becker's {{Who|date=July 2013}} research about risk zones in town planning, women have more to fear in personal surroundings and at home, while men are the object (and dominantly subject) of attacks in the outside world.<ref name="rb">Ruth Becker Zeitschrift für Frauenforschung und Geschlechterstudien, Jg. 18, H. 4, 2000, p. 49-65 (5 Tab.); {{ISSN|0946-5596}} Standort: USB Köln(38)-FHM XG6137</ref> Becker refers to U.S. author Elizabeth Wilson's ''Sphinx in the city''<ref>''The sphinx in the city: urban life, the control of disorder, and women'', University of California Press, 1992 <!-- isbn needed --></ref> and assume that women overestimate the dangers of urban surroundings. Herbert Glasauer doubts that women's parking spaces have a positive effect, and sees them as a sort of backlash perpetuating a [[damsel in distress]] perspective instead of addressing actual violence.<ref name="rb" /><ref name="püt">Herbert Glasauer Gewalt ist nicht immer und überall, Georg Glasze, Robert Pütz, Manfred Rolfes: ''Diskurs, Stadt, Kriminalität: Städtische(Un-)Sicherheiten aus der Perspektive von Stadtforschung und kritischer Kriminalgeographie.'' transcript Verlag, 2005. S.206ff</ref>
Men's parking spaces, as in the Triberg example, are ''for the brave''<ref name="fo">''[[Focus (German magazine)|Focus Online]]'': [http://www.focus.de/auto/ratgeber/unterhaltung/deutschlands-erste-maennerparkplaetze-ist-das-sexistisch-hier-rangieren-nur-echte-kerle_aid_779440.html "Deutschlands erste Männerparkplätze: Ist das sexistisch? Hier rangieren nur echte Kerle"], focus.de retrieved 15 July 2012. (in German)</ref> and ask their users to cope with risk, darkness, wilderness, and skill. Even before the Triberg controversy, for example, German satirist Florian Willet demanded in 2011 that the riskiest places in garages to be reserved for ''"real men"''.<ref>"Deutschlands Frauen schaffen ihre Männer ab: Florian Willet erklärt weiblichen Chauvinismus", verlag-ludwig.de, 2011, p. 209. (in German)</ref> An American reporter in [[Utah]] noted that an American mayor attempting to set up a men's parking space would face greater legal risk compared to Strobel.<ref Name="mor">[http://www.ksl.com/?nid=151&sid=22114877 Gender-specific parking stalls: A lawsuit waiting to happen?] Rachel Lewis, ksl.com 12.9.2012</ref>
==Follow-up== The dedication, planned as a practical joke and a way to alert unskilled drivers to the specific challenge of the two parking slots, attracted worldwide media coverage.<ref name="spiegel">''[[Spiegel Online]]'': [http://www.spiegel.de/panorama/gesellschaft/maennerparkplaetze-in-der-schwarzwald-stadt-triberg-a-843013.html "Hier nur Männer!"], spiegel.de/panorama, 15 July 2012. (in German)</ref><ref name="SK2012">[http://www.suedkurier.de/region/schwarzwald-baar-heuberg/triberg/Parkhaus-Idee-macht-Triberg-beruehmt;art410964,5584050 "Parkhaus-Idee macht Triberg berühmt"], suedkurier.de, 7 July 2012. (in German)</ref>
[[United States|US]] television networks, including [[ABC News|ABC]] and [[NBC News]], reported the story.<ref name="abc">[http://abcnewsradioonline.com/world-news/sexist-parking-plan-german-mayor-creates-male-only-spots.html "Sexist Parking Plan? German Mayor Creates Male-Only Spots"], abcnewsradioonline.com.</ref> Becky Bratu, a news journalist with NBC News, suggested that Mayor Gallus Strobel had increased the threshold for drivers to attract more tourists. NBC News quoted Mayor Strobel's interview with ''[[Süddeutsche Zeitung]]'' to challenge political correctness, and his hope the tight spaces would be an attraction for ambitious drivers.<ref>[http://worldnews.nbcnews.com/_news/2012/07/10/12664764-german-mayor-designates-parking-spaces-just-for-men?lite "German mayor designates parking spaces just for men"], worldnews.nbcnews.com, 10 July 2012.</ref>
Mayor Strobel had media contacts and interviews with French,<ref name="lf">[http://www.lefigaro.fr/international/2012/07/11/01003-20120711ARTFIG00335-en-allemagne-des-places-de-parking-interdites-aux-femmes.php?page=&pagination=3 "En Allemagne, des places de parking interdites aux femmes"], ''Le Figaro'', 11 July 2012. (in French)</ref><ref>[http://www.iol.co.za/motoring/industry-news/german-town-s-male-only-parkings-1.1337765 "German town's ‘male only’ parking], iol.co.za</ref> and English<ref>[http://www.schwarzwaelder-bote.de/inhalt.triberg-weltweites-aufsehen.0e49a4ec-3ddd-49df-8097-7ed4cf57f0ad.html "Weltweites Aufsehen"], ''Schwarzwälder Bote''. (in German)</ref><ref name="guer">[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/jul/12/german-mayor-men-only-parking ''German mayor defends 'men only' parking spaces.''], guardian.co.uk, 12 July 2012.</ref> Italian and South African media. ''[[Le Figaro]]'' quoted Strobel as stating "Une ville touristique se doit de faire parler d'elle" ("A tourist town has to make people talk about it.").<ref name="lf"/>
''[[The Huffington Post]]'' reported: "A town in southwest Germany has drawn accusations of sexism after designating two particularly tricky parking spaces "men only".<ref>[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/07/13/men-only-parking-comes-to_n_1670852.html "'Men Only' Parking Comes To German Town"], ''Huffington Post'', 13 July 2012</ref> The [[Associated Press]] was on site<ref>[http://www.cbc.ca/news/world/story/2012/07/12/triberg-germany-all-men-parking.html "German mayor defends 'men only' parking spots"], Associated Press, 12 July 2012.</ref> and compared the Triberg Challenge to Chinese Woman only parking lots.<ref name="DM">[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2171709/Triberg-mayor-risks-sexism-row-designating-tricky-parking-slots-men-only.html "Achtung! German mayor risks sexism row by designating tricky parking slots as 'men only'"], ''The Daily Mail'', 10 July 2012.</ref> ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' in UK,<ref>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/germany/9393451/Easy-parking-spots-for-women-introduced-by-German-mayor.html "'Easy' parking spots for women introduced by German mayor"], telegraph.co.uk</ref> a women's magazine in [[Morocco]],<ref>[http://issuu.com/vamp_magazine/docs/vamp_06/search?q=triberg "Are women worse driver than men?"], issuu.com/vamp_magazine/docs</ref> and Norway's ''[[Aftenposten]]'' also all reported.<ref>Arild Færaas, [http://www.aftenposten.no/nyheter/uriks/Tysk-by-reserverer-parkeringsplasser-kun-for-menn-6937772.html#.UZ6Pu9jxeSo "Tysk by reserverer parkeringsplasser kun for menn Byen Triberg har reservert to plasser i et parkeringsplass for mannlige sjåfører. Årsak: Det er så vanskelig å parkere der."] ''Aftenposten'', 6 July 2012. (in German)</ref>
''[[The Times of India|Times of India]]'' reporter Kritika Kapoor wrote an article on the issue. She quoted Strobel about his secretary's failure to park on the slot, saying "Five times she tried and no success", and inviting women to stand for the challenge. "Women can come here and prove me wrong, and while they're at it, they can see the town's attractions." Kapoor pointed out that Triberg's introduction of gendered parking is not the first example of sexist parking spots.<ref>[http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2012-08-06/man-woman/33064457_1_spaces-spots-parallel-park "Women, a parking menace?"], TNN, 6 August 2012.</ref>
===Regional feedback=== [[File:Triboll.JPG|thumb|A lady with a traditional Black Forest hat occupies the spot]] [[The Greens (Germany)|The Greens]]' youth association of [[Ortenau]] wrote an open letter against the parking spots<ref>[http://www.gj-ortenau.de/shared/brief.pdf "Offener Brief der Grünen Jugend Ortenau"], gj-ortenau.de (in German)</ref> and gender equality official Anette Klaas of the neighboring [[Waldshut-Tiengen]] district criticized them as "a foolhardy provocation".<ref name="FB">[http://www.bo.de/Lokales/Ortenau/Geschlechterkampf-im-Parkhaus2 "Geschlechterkampf im Parkhaus Triberger Männerparkplätze sorgen für Furore/Für die einen ein netter Gag, für die anderen Sexismus"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304234442/http://www.bo.de/lokales/ortenau/geschlechterkampf-im-parkhaus2 |date=2016-03-04 }}, bo.de, 23 August 2012. (in German)</ref>
Strobel, who has a legal background and holds a PhD in the history of law,<ref>Gallus Strobel, ''Zum Fabrikarbeitsvertrag in Deutschland im 19. Jahrhundert. Vertragsfreiheit und Kinderschutz'', 1986</ref> countered that the critics were being humourless and described the dedication as usage of a cliché for city marketing.<ref>[http://www.suedkurier.de/region/schwarzwald-baar-heuberg/triberg/Strobel-antwortet-gruener-Jugend;art410964,5646777 "Strobel antwortet grüner Jugend"], suedkurier.de (in German)</ref> Dieter Stein, a writer living in Triberg, published a humorous booklet about the story.<ref>Schwarzwälder Bote: [http://www.schwarzwaelder-bote.de/inhalt.triberg-humorvolle-hotelgeschichten.2800066a-6355-4a74-8f39-9c5dfe1fbbbc.html "Triberg Humorvolle Hotelgeschichten"], schwarzwaelder-bote.de (in Germam)</ref> The men's parking slots are included in city tours, and Triberg also sells merchandising articles.<ref>[http://www.focus.de/auto/ratgeber/unterhaltung/jetzt-gibt-es-sogar-t-shirts-neuer-zoff-um-maennerparkplaetze_aid_801914.html "Neuer Zoff um Männerparkplätze"], [[Focus (German magazine)|focus.de]], 17 August 2012. (in German)</ref>
The gender-based parking has been featured in annual TV retrospectives in Germany and South Africa. In 2013, Gallus Strobel was a guest on several television programmes, and the local carnival association baptized and tested the parking lots.{{Clarify|date=July 2013}} The number of tourists and visitors to Triberg increased to almost 400,000 in 2012, compared to 250,000 annually before.<ref name="FB"/> Neighboring [[Sankt Georgen im Schwarzwald|St. Georgen]] came up with a temporary men's parking place, in the sense of ''a place where men are being parked'' ([[Männergarten]]).<ref>[http://www.schwarzwaelder-bote.de/inhalt.st-georgen-modeflohmarktmit-maennerparkplatz.efa1d01e-3f6c-4f5f-a095-bdf453a69a53.html "Modeflohmarkt mit Männerparkplatz"], ''Schwarzwälder Bote'', 19 April 2013; accessed 15 May 2013. (in German)</ref>
==References== {{reflist|33em}}
==External links== {{Commons category|Men's parking}} * [http://www.spiegel.de/panorama/gesellschaft/maennerparkplaetze-in-der-schwarzwald-stadt-triberg-a-843013.html ''Parkplätze in Triberg: Hier nur Männer!''], Interview of Strobel in [[Spiegel Online]] 6. Juli 2012 * [http://www.schwaebische.de/journal/vermischtes/video_videoid,56704.html Local newspaper Schwäbische], Video 10. Juli 2012 * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3Pbeewf77DQ parking exercise of the local carnival association in full gear 2013] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bxY_Qizvv4E Landesschau Baden Württemberg 2012] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KajyhRcJq7g TTV Südbaden]

{{Infobox magazine |image_file = Metal-Bulletin-logo.png |image_size = 220px |image_caption = |publisher = [[Euromoney Institutional Investor]] |category = Specialist information provider |total_circulation = |circulation_year = |frequency = Weekly |language = English |editor = |editor_title = Editor |headquarters = [[London]] |founded = 1913 |firstdate = |country = United Kingdom |based = London |website = {{URL|www.metalbulletin.com}} |issn = 0026-0533 }} '''''Metal Bulletin''''' is a specialist international [[publishing company|publisher]] and information provider for the global steel, non-ferrous and scrap metals markets. It is headquartered in London, United Kingdom.<ref name="ada">{{cite news|title=Euromoney Institutional Investor acquires Metal Bulletin|url=http://adage.com/article/btob/euromoney-institutional-investor-acquires-metal-bulletin/264982/|accessdate=24 February 2017|work=AdAge|date=27 October 2006}}</ref>
==History== ''Metal Bulletin'' was first introduced in 1913. Its mission then, as it is now, was to provide must-have timely information, including price indications, for the global [[non-ferrous metals]] and [[steel]] markets. Over the years, ''Metal Bulletin'' became established as the bible for the world's metals and [[steel]] trading communities.
''Metal Bulletin's'' breadth of product offerings extends from online news and prices services, magazines, newsletters and online real time services, to directories and databases, books, market trackers and forecasts, research reports, and consultancy and the staging of events around the globe in the form of conferences and exhibitions.
The magazine was acquired by [[Euromoney Institutional Investor]] in October 2006 for $408 million.<ref>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/2944817/Euromoney-snatches-Metal-Bulletin.html "Euromoney snatches Metal Bulletin"], ''Daily Telegraph, 4 Aug 2006</ref><ref>[http://www.dmgt.co.uk/mediacentre/newsreleases/20070412/4441/ "Euromoney sells Metal Bulletin subsidiary EIC"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081011150919/http://www.dmgt.co.uk/mediacentre/newsreleases/20070412/4441/ |date=2008-10-11 }}, ''Daily Mail and General Trust'', 12 April 2007</ref><ref>[http://www.foliomag.com/viewmedia.asp?prmMID=7317&prmID=249 "Metal Bulletin"]{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, ''Folio Magazine'', 31 January 2007</ref>
==Products and services== ''Metal Bulletin'' is the premium intelligence service for metals and [[steel]] professionals everywhere. Covering all global metals and [[steel]] markets, it provides a comprehensive package of the latest news, pricing information, expert market commentary and statistics.
Metals covered in detail include carbon steel, stainless and special steel, scrap and secondary, ores and alloys, raw materials, minor and precious metals, and base metals with additional coverage of freight news, [[capital markets]], and exchange news and prices.
==References== {{Reflist}}
== External links == *[http://www.metalbulletin.com Metal Bulletin] *[http://journalseeker.researchbib.com/?issn=00260533 The Metal bulletin ({{ISSN|0026-0533}})]

{{BLP sources|date=February 2010}} {{infobox person | name = Nick Michaels | image = Nick Michaels.jpg | birth_date = 1950 | birth_place = [[Canada]] | death_date = {{death_date and age|2018|5|26|1950}} | death_place = [[Miami, Florida]], U.S. | occupation = Voice actor, writer, producer, narrator | years_active = 1973–2018 }}
'''Nick Michaels''' (1950 – May 26, 2018) was a [[Canadian Americans|Canadian-American]] [[voice acting|voice actor]], writer, producer, and narrator.<ref name="tribune">{{cite newspaper |url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/chicagotribune/access/11023651.html?dids=11023651:11023651&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Feb+10%2C+1997&author=Steve+Hockensmith.+Special+to+the+Tribune.&pub=Chicago+Tribune&desc=%60COMING+UP+NEXT+.+.+.++THE+FACES+BEHIND+THE+TV+VOICES!%27+ANNOUNCERS+FOR+LOCAL+STATIONS+SPEAK+FOR+THEMSELVES%2C+FOR+ONCE&pqatl=google|title= `COMING UP NEXT . . . THE FACES BEHIND THE TV VOICES!' ANNOUNCERS FOR LOCAL STATIONS SPEAK FOR THEMSELVES, FOR ONCE |author=Steve Hockensmith |newspaper=Chicago Tribune |date=February 10, 1997 |access-date=February 8, 2010 }} ("Miami-based Nick Michaels (the commanding voice of WBBM-Ch. 2 and about 20 other TV and radio stations)")</ref>
==Career== Nick Michaels started in [[radio]] while still in high school in Canada. After copywriting for AdGroup International in [[Montreal, Quebec|Montreal]], he moved to [[Toronto, Ontario|Toronto]] in 1973. He became one of the top commercial voice-over actors in Canada with multiple national accounts such as [[Molson Brewery|Molson]], [[Kodak]], [[Texaco]], [[Kellogg's]], [[Procter & Gamble]], and [[Toyota]].
Michaels relocated to [[New York City]] in 1977, a move that resulted in several long-running campaigns for major advertisers,<ref name="AA 2018-05">{{cite news |url=https://www.allaccess.com/net-news/archive/story/177009/voiceover-giant-deep-end-host-nick-michaels-dies |title=Voiceover Giant, 'Deep End' Host Nick Michaels Dies |work=AllAccess.com |publisher=All Access Music Group |date=May 29, 2018 |access-date=May 30, 2018 }}</ref> including [[Excedrin]], [[Gillette]], [[Coca-Cola]], [[General Motors]], [[Coppertone]], and [[Maybelline]]. In all, Michaels' voice has appeared on over a billion dollars of paid advertising.
He moved to [[Miami, Florida]] in 1980, where he lived until his death.
In addition to ad campaigns for consumer products, Michaels provided creative services to many U.S. media companies. He created the [[NBC]] television program ''[[Friday Night Videos]]'' which debuted in 1983,<ref name="AA 2018-05" /> serving as the original voice-over host until 1986. His voice also was heard on the network's late-night promos throughout the 1980s. In 1992, he became the worldwide voice of topical promotion for [[CNN]] as well as other cable networks. As narrator, Michaels appeared on the series ''[[National Geographic Explorer]]'' and on the [[documentary film]] ''[[1992 Summer Olympics|Barcelona '92]]: 16 Days of Glory''. Michaels also served as the imaging voice for many television stations, including [[WBBM-TV]] in Chicago, [[WCBS-TV]] in New York City, and [[WCCO-TV]] in Minneapolis. In radio, he was the imaging voice for Chicago [[classic rock]] radio station [[WDRV]], "97.1 The Drive", since its debut in March 2001.<ref name="IR 2018-05">{{cite news |url=http://www.insideradio.com/free/voice-talent-nick-michaels-dies-over-memorial-day-weekend/article_772c57fe-636d-11e8-b60b-7f03bba1c118.html |title=Voice Talent Nick Michaels Dies Over Memorial Day Weekend |work=Inside Radio |location=Atlanta, Georgia |date=May 29, 2018 |access-date=May 30, 2018 }}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine |url=http://www.americanradiohistory.com/hd2/IDX-Business/Music/Archive-RandR-IDX/IDX/00s/01/RR-2001-03-23-OCR-Page-0005.pdf |title=Bonneville Goes For A 'Drive' In Chicago |magazine=Radio and Records |page=5 |date=March 23, 2001 |access-date=May 30, 2018 }}</ref>
Michaels established a creative services company, American Voice Corporation, to provide voice imaging and related services to advertisers and radio and television stations. It produces and syndicates his national radio program ''[[The Deep End with Nick Michaels]]'' and its spinoff, ''Stories From The Deep End'', in the United States and New Zealand. On August 31, 2015, Michaels launched ''The Stories That Made the Music'', a daily one-minute feature series focusing on [[country music]] artists, hosted by him and distributed by Envision Networks.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.allaccess.com/net-news/archive/story/145079/envision-networks-debuts-the-stories-that-made-the |title=Envision Networks Debuts 'The Stories That Made The Music' |work=AllAccess.com |publisher=All Access Music Group |date=August 31, 2015 |access-date=May 30, 2018 }}</ref>
A well-respected figure in the broadcasting industry, Michaels has delivered keynote addresses at numerous conferences such as the Dan O'Day Creative Summit, The Conclave, the [[NAB Show]], and RadioDays Scandinavia.
Michaels is the author of the book ''The Manifesto For The Over Communicated World''.
==Death== On May 26, 2018, at the age of 67, Michaels died of a [[heart attack]] at his home in Miami.<ref name="AA 2018-05" /><ref name="IR 2018-05" />
According to the official Facebook page of ''The Deep End with Nick Michaels'', the syndicated radio show will continue to air after Michaels' death until some affiliated stations go off the air.<ref name="IR 2018-05" />
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *{{official website |url=http://www.nickmichaels.com/ }} *{{url |1=http://www.thedeependwithnickmichaels.com/ |2=''The Deep End with Nick Michaels'' }} *{{IMDb name|1208027}}
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Michaels, Nick}} [[Category:2018 deaths]] [[Category:Canadian male voice actors]] [[Category:Place of birth missing]] [[Category:Canadian radio personalities]] [[Category:Advertising people]] [[Category:1950 births]]

revision.comment: Updating URL format for [[The New York Times]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Oliver Harriman | image = Oliver Harriman.jpg | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = September 16, 1829 | birth_place = [[New York City]], U.S. | death_date = {{death date and age|1904|3|12|1829|9|16}} | death_place = [[Mount Kisco, New York]], U.S. | death_cause = | residence = | nationality = | other_names = American | known_for = | education = | alma mater = | employer = | occupation = Businessman | title = | salary = | networth = US$20 million<ref name="leaves20mil"/> <small>(1904)</small> | spouse = Laura Low | children = 8, including [[Anne Harriman Vanderbilt|Anne]], [[Oliver Harriman, Jr.|Oliver, Jr.]], [[J. Borden Harriman|J. Borden]], and [[Herbert M. Harriman|Herbert]] | relatives = [[E. H. Harriman]] (nephew) | box_width = }}
'''Oliver Harriman''' (September 16, 1829 – March 12, 1904) was an American businessman and member of the wealthy Harriman family.<ref name="OHObitNYT1904">{{cite news|title=DEATH OF OLIVER HARRIMAN.; Prominent in City's Commercial and Social Life for Many Years.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1904/03/13/archives/death-of-oliver-harriman-prominent-in-citys-commercial-and-social.html|accessdate=20 July 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=13 March 1904}}</ref>
==Early life== Oliver Harriman was born on September 16, 1829 in New York City.<ref name=NYTObit>{{cite news | author = | title= Death of Oliver Harriman | url = https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1904/03/13/101388567.pdf | newspaper = The New York Times | location = New York, New York | date = March 13, 1904 | access-date = November 18, 2015}}</ref><ref name="brooklynobit">{{cite news|title=Oliver Harriman. |url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/53410741/?terms=%22Oliver%2BHarriman%22 |newspaper=The Brooklyn Daily Eagle|location=Brooklyn, New York |date=March 13, 1904|page=52|via = [[Newspapers.com]]|accessdate = November 17, 2015 }} {{Open access}}</ref> His parents were Orlando Harriman (1790–1867) and Anne Ingland (1795–1853).<ref name="Burke1908">{{cite book|last1=Burke|first1=Arthur Meredyth|title=The Prominent Families of the United States of America, Vol. I|date=1908|publisher=The Sackville Press, Ltd.|location=London|url=https://archive.org/details/prominentfamilies00burkrich|accessdate=20 July 2017}}</ref> He was the brother was Orlando Harriman, who was the father of [[E. H. Harriman|Edward H. Harriman]], railroad tycoon.<ref name="Delatiner2002">{{cite news|last1=Delatiner|first1=Barbara|title=Two Congregations Have Roots in Past|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/04/14/nyregion/two-congregations-have-roots-in-past.html|accessdate=20 July 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=14 April 2002}}</ref>
His grandfather, William Harriman,<ref name="Burke1908"/> emigrated from England in 1795 and engaged successfully in trading and commercial pursuits.<ref name=pbs>{{cite news |author= |coauthors= |title=Edward H. Harriman |url=https://www.pbs.org/harriman/1899/1899_part/participantharriman.html |quote=Edward Henry Harriman was born in New Jersey [sic] in 1848. His father was an ordained deacon in the Presbyterian Church, his mother a well-connected socialite from New Jersey. ... |newspaper=[[PBS]] |date= |accessdate=2012-11-22 }}</ref>
==Career== Harriman began his career in the dry goods commission house of McCurdy, Aldrich & Spencer.<ref name=NYTObit/><ref name="brooklynobit"/> Later, with James Low, his father-in-law, Harriman co-founded Low, Harriman & Co., "one of the best known and wealthiest" dry goods firms in New York City.<ref name="brooklynobit"/>
Harriman served on the Boards of Directors of [[Bank of America]], the Guaranty Trust Company of New York (which later merged with [[J.P. Morgan & Co.]]), and the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York (later known as [[Mutual of New York]]).<ref name=NYTObit/>
==Personal life== Harriman married Laura Low (1834–1901),<ref name="Burke1908"/> the daughter of James Low, the founder of Low, Harriman & Co.<ref name="brooklynobit"/><ref name="JLObit1898">{{cite news|title=DEATH LIST OF A DAY {{!}} James Low|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1898/05/19/archives/death-list-of-a-day.html|accessdate=20 July 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=19 May 1898}}</ref> They had five sons and three daughters who were prominent in New York and Westchester society:<ref name="OHObitNYT1904"/>
* James Low Harriman (1856–1928),<ref name="1928Estate">{{cite news|title=J.L.
